reviews.review_title: Faulty climax, but not even close to being as bad as critics say
reviews.content: RELEASED IN 1987 and directed by Joseph Sargent, "Jaws: The Revenge" (aka "Jaws 4") chronicles events when widowed Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) vacations in the Bahamas where her son, Michael (Lance Guest), lives and works. Meanwhile, a huge killing machine in the ocean has its eyes set on her & family. Mario Van Peebles plays Michael's associate while Karen Young plays his wife. Michael Caine appears as a small plane pilot who seems to be interested in Ellen. There's been a critical feeding frenzy over this movie for decades, no pun intended. But it's really a decent nature-runs-amok creature feature laden by dubious filmmaking at the climax. There's a nice build-up and the material is taken seriously by the quality cast. Ellen's developing relationship with the amicable pilot is kinda heartwarming and both Guest & Van Peebles are effective male protagonists. Moreover, the switch to the Bahamas keeps things fresh after the first three movies. Of course, the idea that a vengeful great white shark follows the Brody family to the Bahamas is absurd, but we've all heard of dogs or cats following a family hundreds of miles. This is just an imaginative stretch and we find Michael seriously wondering if that ridiculous premise could be true when just such a creature shows up. So the dramatic build-up is effective, not great, but certainly effective. Unfortunately, there's almost zero female eye candy despite the resort setting and, like I said, the climatic scenes are awkwardly done. It's like the creators really needed to reshoot some scenes and add others, but they lacked the funds so they tried to force the footage they had to "work" in the editing room. The four Jaws movies detract in quality chronologically, but "The Revenge" is still worthwhile if you enjoyed the first three, just disregard the closing sequences. Beyond that glaring weakness, it's not even close to being as bad as people criticize. THE FILM RUNS 1 hours & 29 minutes and was shot in Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts, and Bahamas, with studio work done at Universal City, California. WRITER: Michael De Guzman. GRADE: C+

Although it is hard to watch a Jaws movie without Roy Scheider, this is an okay movie. It isn't as bad as some people make it out to be, it is good to watch solely to see how the characters have grown up. Some parts can be quite annoying,yes, but you have to at least give it a try.

If you were to ask a serious movie fanatic what some of the worst films of all time are, chances are they would include Jaws: The Revenge. Jaws: The Revenge is the fourth and final film in the Jaws franchise and was released in 1987. The film was directed by Joseph Sargent and stars Lorraine Gary, Lance Guest, and Michael Caine. The film still performed fairly decent at the box office but is the lowest performing film in the Jaws franchise. Now, this film was universally panned by critics and audiences. So much so that the film is often considered one of the worst films of all time.We are back in Amity as we see one of the Brody brothers, Sean, gets killed by a shark. Mourning the loss of her husband and son, Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) moves to the Bahamas with her son Michael. But the shark wants revenge and this time, it is personal.I have seen this film a total of three times (as of the time that this review is being written) and I have come to the conclusion that this film is bad. The most recent viewing of this film, I decided to just turn my brain off and just let it all happen. It seems to work well that way I suppose but why should I do that? Even if I was to find any good, it seems insignificant because the negative aspects of this film are far, far, far, greater. Let me just put things into perspective here. Superman IV is worse than this film and if I could, would give it zero stars. This film, rightly deserves the one star rating that it will get from me. With Jaws: The Revenge, the only good thing I can truly say is that at least there are returning characters and the continuity seems to be picked right back up because it appears that this film may or may not ignore Jaws 3-D. But it is all still a big slap in the face to viewers who really enjoyed the first film. The film is highly absurd with it's plot that I am certain the film itself is aware of it's utter absurdness. The film likes to have our main character Ellen Brody to have sepia toned flashbacks of events that she never witnessed. Also, apparently there is an unexplained psychological connection between this shark and Ellen Brody. Apparently sharks are aware of the concept of revenge and somehow knows where a family is located by swimming from Amity to the Bahamas in a span of a couple of days. Those are just a few of a whole boatload (pun intended) of absurdities. If one is brave enough to watch this film, you will certainly find more. It is basically a given. The acting is not very good (though I can certainly say it is a minor improvement over the acting in Jaws 3-D). This film spends more time focusing on the characters and not really doing much with them. This film ends up being a sort of melodrama where a shark makes cameos. I feel bad for Michael Caine because this is one of those films that he worked on to just get a paycheck. Michael Caine just seems to be a really friendly person in general and I hate to see someone like him in a film like this. Gone is any sort of suspense. The music is not very good and as you may know, the original film relied on the music to effectively build suspense. This film's music for me, does not help build suspense and just feels off in key scenes. Lastly, the special effects are bad. People who know this film are aware of one infamous effect in this film so I just ask to see it for yourself if you are ever so curious. The shark itself oddly enough spends more time out of the water instead of in the water and looks even more fake.I struggle with whether or not calling Jaws: The Revenge the worst film of all time. It is certainly not the number one worst film, but it certainly is up there.

reviews.review_title: Legendary because of it's lame ending
reviews.content: Furthermore there is nothing to say about this really bad movie. The acting is horrendous,especially by Lorraine Gray.But the ending is,because it is so bad,very enjoyable to watch.Still,of course,that don't make up for it. 1/10

reviews.review_title: A Little Better Than 3-D To Me
reviews.content: This film starts out with the feeling of the first film... the way it's filmed and the fact they are back in Amity really helps this movie feel more inline with the original Jaws than Jaws 3-D did.The way this movie is, it makes Jaws 3-D more of a stand alone film... like 3-D is some sorta bonus movie to the franchise (or even a parody) because it's as if 3-D never happened in the lives of Mike and Sean Brody the way Jaws 4 plays out and is more inline with the first two films.In this film, Ellen Brody is distraught over the loss of her husband then the loss of Sean and does not want Mike to go near water ever again. That is a mother's natural way. But what's silly about it is Ellen becomes somehow psychically connected to Jaws and that is where I think this film fails. If she was just looked at as an odd woman then I would be fine with that but the psychic connection is silly.The movie is still watchable to me but just a bit, well, silly. Plus I find this movie a wee bit better than 3-D where this group of extra large great white sharks are suppose to live - not way off in Disneyland errr ummm Seaworld.6/10

Well, I always loved all the JAWS movies,More than ever the first one and by loving "Bruce" the shark i love all his family,but the one in this one takes the cake, I have heard the Alternative introduction which explains how for incredible it may seems whats going to happen we are the ones to choose from fact and fiction..yeah right!!! and the Alternative ending where Jake dies and we see the shark carry down part of the boat underwater and before that expell a lot of blood from its mouth,I taped this version from television a long time ago and then i kind of loved the movie more because it was part of the JAWS family..i have accepted all the bad about it and i applaud that Michael Caine still have a carrear after this one,Ill give it an 8 out of 10. And i love the videogame too where you can kill the roaring shark just like in the film. Question: -When does a shark roar? -When does a shark dance out of the water in his fins? -How can you have flashbacks about thing youve never lived? -How do sharks migrate from cold water to milder ones in a week? -Do all color guys love the jamaican look? ps: In the other version they used the same ending as in JAWS the original,I dont know if hey ripped it off,asked for it or payed for it but i knew it was the same,checked and yes...it is.

this is the character I most like to associate with Caine. Just a freewheeling pilot with a bit of the ol shaharazad. Forgiving the sometimes spotty cues and the somewhat silly premise,( although it could be said that the first jaws had a touch of fantasy to it, I mean we all know a giant shark couldn't hurt Robert Shaw.) I find myself watching this movie quite often. Honestly, the cinematography is amazing in some parts, and what can I say, I'm a sucker for pre-digital effects. so,yes, while you could certainly find a " better " scary movie to watch, jaws the revenge will remain one of my standby late-night go-to's, due to it's silliness, it's heart,and the fact that it seems like the producers kept the cast happy & were smart enough to supply Caine with a trunk full of rum and free reign to improvise.plus did I mention I love giant shark movies?a great movie for people who don't take movies too seriously, and a great movie to watch with friends.

reviews.review_title: "They spend half their lives looking for food & the other half eating it." Absolutely terrible film, this one deserves all it's bad reviews...
reviews.content: Jaws: The Revenge starts in an extremely familiar way with plenty of underwater point-of-view shots as a man-eating Great White Shark swims around the coast of Amity once more to a slightly remixed version of John Williams classic theme from the original Jaws (1975) while the credits run. It's Christmas time in Amity & Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gray) is spending it with one of her sons Sean (Mitchell Anderson) who is now the Deputy of Amity after his Father & Ellen's Husband Martin (Roy Schneider from Jaws & Jaws 2 (1978)) died of a heart attack. The Amity police department receives a call about a drifting buoy stuck on a channel marker that needs to be cleared before the local fishermen come back, Deputy Brody gets the job. While out in the harbour in his boat Sean is suddenly attacked by a huge Great White Shark & killed. Ellen starts to believe that a Great White Shark has started to specifically target the Brody family as some form of revenge. Ellen's only other son Micheal (Lance Guest), his wife Carla (Karen Young) & their young daughter Thea (Judith Barsi) immediately come for the funeral & afterwards invites Ellen to come back with them to the Bahamas where Micheal is researching for a scientific doctorate with an annoying guy named Jake (Mario Van Peebles) about, yes you guessed it, underwater marine life. Ellen agrees & together they all set off for the Bahamas, sounds good to me. Once there Ellen begins to forget about the Great White Shark & becomes involved with a likable pilot named Hoagie (Micheal Caine, oh dear Micheal, oh dear). While out on their boat one day Micheal is attacked by a huge Great White Shark that at first glance does indeed seem to be following the Brody family around, Jake wants to study it & convinces Micheal it would be good for their research. Along with their two assistants Clarence (Cedric Scott) & William (Charles Bowleg) they set off to find the Shark & study it but this course of action is not without great danger as both Micheal & Jake soon discover...Produced & directed by Joseph Sargent Jaws: The Revenge is conceptually truly one of the worst films you could have the misfortune to watch. The script by Micheal De Guzman is simply awful, the plot holes & the just downright preposterous nature of what occurs really sink Jaws: The Revenge without a trace & good riddance too I say. The notion that a Great White Shark is hunting the Brody family down for revenge is a concept that Jaws: The Revenge never recovers from, in my opinion. How does it know a Brody family member when it comes across one? How did it know to travel from Amity in the United States all the way to the Bahamas? What relationship is this Great White Shark to the Brody family anyway? The Great White Sharks from Jaws & it's sequel Jaws 2 were both killed, as was the Great White Shark from Jaws 3 which Jaws: The Revenge seems to completely ignore, so what has this Shark got to do with anything & why does it have a particular grudge against the Brody family & not just people in general? Why don't the Brody family just stay out of the water, problem solved & this film wouldn't exist, it would have been a blessing for both them & us. As a film Jaws: The Revenge fails miserably too, Sharks do not roar or growl like lions. Sharks can't jump out of the water & hover in mid air for a few seconds, well I don't think they can anyway. The idea that Micheal can out-swim the Shark on at least one occasion under a clear stretch of water is also somewhat debatable. I realise there are two different endings to Jaws: The Revenge & I saw the one where Jake survives with only minor bleeding after being severely mauled by an enormous Great White Shark & even has time to crack some bad jokes & I hated it. The Sharks death is also strange, the boat hits it & it explodes, eh? Director Sargent fails to inject any tension, atmosphere or scares into the Shark attacks which are far too short, have no build up or impact. Jaws: The Revenge sucks out of the water too with boring human characters & relationships. Sargent also films it like a T.V. program with flat, bland & uninteresting photography although the Bahamas look fantastic, maybe that's why Caine agreed to be in this. The bit in the Amity police station was embarrassing as for some reason they have a large framed cheesy photo of Martin Brody hanging up for all to see! The special effects on the Shark are absolutely awful, the worst of the entire series & you can clearly see some of the machinery operating it. The Shark itself also looks fake, stiff, rubbery & just plain unconvincing in appearance. The only gore is when someone has their arm bitten off, the only good scene in the entire film. The acting is bad throughout, Micheal Caine overacts when he pops up on occasion & is the only likable character in the film but Micheal, what on Earth were you thinking? He must have needed the money pretty bad to appear in this or he needs a new agent. I thought that Mario Van Peebles character Jake was one of the most annoying I've ever seen with some of the worst dialogue I've heard in a while, oh & lets not forget his accent which is one of the best ever & not off putting at all is it?! Overall I hated Jaws: The Revenge, like most people who have had the misfortune to sit through it. Don't waste your time & Jaws: The Revenge is most definitely worthy of it's appearance in the IMDb's bottom 100 films. One to avoid.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everyone says
reviews.content: OK, so maybe Jaws The Revenge isn't cinema at its finest. But, the amount of criticism levied to this film is ridiculous. I am admittedly a huge Jaws fan and have watched the original movie over 40 times. I have seen Jaws The Revenge possibly 25 times. I know that it isn't a classic by any means, but the movie really is good.First off the acting. It wasn't terrible. Lorraine Gary did a terrific job as the lead. I felt sympathy for her and she does have some ability. Lance Guest as Michael was fantastic also. I am still waiting for him to get his break out role in Hollywood because I think he has potential. Mario Van Peebles brings some Bahamian humor, and it sheds some light onto the movie. And Michael Caine maybe isn't at his finest, but he is decent enough.The cinematography is just beautiful. It just makes me want to go to the Bahamas every time I watch. The music score is better than the original. It has a sort of mystical, on the edge feel to it. It's too bad Michael Small didn't get any recognition for it, and anyone would be hard pressed to find the soundtrack, even though it's one of the finest ever.Joseph Sargent does an okay job directing. I admit that it isn't anything special, but it's not trash. A lot of people have problems with the special effects and some of the things the shark does. Yes, the shark looks fake. That's a given when the film has such a low budget and the studio behind the picture isn't totally committed. There is one scene in particular that many have a problem with and that is when the shark is doing a so called stand on the water. It's obvious to me that the scene is in slow motion, and the shark is leaping from the water, which makes it appear to be standing on its fin. There are many aspects of the film also that are very authentic. An example is when the shark is attacking the boat and it's eyes roll back in its head, which is what a real great white would do.The ending is terrible and totally brings down the film. But once again, I come with my defense. In Michael De Guzman's original script, the ending was much different and rather exciting. As I alluded to earlier, budget constraints kept this film from producing an adequate ending. If you are interested, there are many links on the Net with the original script.Jaws the Revenge is a movie that I guess you have be a really big Jaws fan to enjoy. I know that it isn't perfect by any means and that it never will be considered to be a good movie by anybody other than the "Jaws Junkies." But, for all the people that like to tear it apart and dissect its every mistake, remember that it's only a movie and not real life. 6 Stars

I gave this 5 because I thought it was directed really nicely. I was actually quite impressed. It's a crazy concept and you wouldn't want to bother focusing your whole attention on it but I had it on in the background while doing other things and thought it was OK.

reviews.review_title: JAWS: THE REVENGE - In A Class Of It's Own
reviews.content: Is this movie great? No its not. Is it entertaining? Yes it isThis movie has the distinction of being one of the worst movies ever made. Does it deserve it? Yes it does. Oh hell yes it does. Do I like the movie? Yes I do, for some strange reason.The whole premise of a shark carrying a grudge and chasing a family down to exact revenge on a family who killed two of its ancestors is completely ridiculous. And its not even explained. For that you have to read the novelisation. If the novel is to believed, this sharks mother is the shark which met its gruesome and electrifying end at the conclusion of JAWS 2. And get this, this new shark was born as its mother was dying. And its also hinted that the shark from the very first film was its father. Which in itself is a a stretch considering that shark died four years before the events of the second film. Then again everything about the movie and its novel is a stretch. I liked Lance Guest as Michael Brody. I thought he did a fairly good job. Michael Caine is great. Thats not too much to ask as he is great in everything. Lorraine Gary was also good. Whoever was her hair stylist on the film should have been fired however. That was almost as confusing as the plot itself.The movie did not take itself seriously at all. And it shows. We only get to see two death scenes in this one. Its a shark movie for christs sake. We get to see one death at the beginning of the movie, and the second (and last one) towards the end of the film. And thats it. The first death scene is pretty brutal. The best part of the movie is actually at the beginning on Amity Island.Despite all this, this is still not the worst movie I have seen. I do enjoy it. Its not the worst way to spend two hours of your time watching. I just wish that at the end of the day, we had more JAWS films. This pretty much killed the franchise dead in the water. It has been 31 years and there still hasnt been another one. Oh well, one day they may decide to do another sequel or a soft reboot

I wouldn't necessarily say that this was a bad film. In my opinion, it was nowhere near as bad as Jaws 3. I'm no expert on Oceanography, but a lot of the scientific aspects of the film seem very...off. Not to mention the fact that the sharks life comes to an abrupt end, that doesn't really seem physically possible when you think about it. I really think the Jaws films sort of took a nose dive after the second film. Though I still stand by my statement when I say that Jaws 3 was still my least favorite. One scene in this film shows very clearly that while they were in the plane, the effects were added in afterwards, meaning they probably weren't even in a plane at all and probably just the front half of one, with video shot from inside a real plane put in the background, though honestly, this was not the first time someone did that in a film.

This movie gets a 5 for the fun and cheese but even that can't save it from being one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Apparently Chief Brody died of a heart attack sometime between when the shark took a vacation to Sea World and then decided to follow his wife to the islands. Following in his foot steps as the town police chief, Sean is now a grown man. I'll make this short. Sean gets eaten. Mrs. Brody goes to the Islands to hang out with her other son, Mike (Lance Guest wondering when they will make a sequel to The Last Starfighter). Mike has become a marine biologist and has decided to follow the shark with his friend Jake (Mario Van Peebles who is a good actor even in this movie). Long story short. Mrs Brody starts knocking boots with Michael "how did I get here?" Cain and the shark eats some people. There are two things that make me mad about this flick. First of all, sharks do not roar like dinosaurs. They don't roar..EVER. Second of all there are two versions of this movie. In one version Jake dies and in another he manages to survive being nearly eaten by the shark and have a good laugh about it. WHY?????

reviews.review_title: This is Not a Bad Movie !
reviews.content: They told me that this is ugly. I read that it's the worst "Jaws" movie at all. I even saw Billy Crystal signing to Michael Caine in one of the Oscar nights: "Why did you make Jaws 4"?! Then finally, and very late I think, I had the chance to watch it..Yes, there are bad points. The shark doesn't look that scary. The storyline of it wasn't that thrilling. Since the shark was killed in the first, then its son was killed in the second; who was revenging in this one?!! Despite how Lorraine Gary is a good actress, she isn't an attractive lead. The reiteration of shots, and scene, from the original was boring and not in this one's sake. They killed the shark by the electricity; exactly like part 2 (!). There were 2 scenes where the shark attacks to turn out to be a dream. There were 2 identical tricks at the climax; where Michael Caine was considered dead, then he's alive, then the same with Mario Van Peebles after few minutes! By the way, I don't know how Peebles was alive at the end? The shark ate him already; so whether it vomited him after a short time, or he got himself released while the shark was exploding?; but even if, how he wasn't killed by the electric power that shocked the shark?? And yes, Caine's shirt was dry while he was getting out of the water!There are love scenes between the pilot and the mother. And maybe they added love scenes between the young son and his wife to compensate the oldness of first couple. But anyhow there is not enough focusing on Jaws. And that's the main big mistake that this movie did.Furthermore, it missed the substance. There is no serious shadow for anything. In fact, anything serious, or supposed to be, ended after the original. So it's a revenge story, and that's it. Sure being in TV-ish condition and less strong than its antecedent; part 3 as well, disappointed the fans very much at the moment.Nevertheless, that doesn't make this movie horrible. It wasn't a shoddy time. I didn't run into many idiot situations, or huge plot holes. In relation to the most hateful matters; I saw that the shark's roar is artistic touch more than scientific error. Strangely, in the super hit (Terminator 2: Judgment Day - 1991), the evil Terminator gave off, during pain, a screaming hiss, and nobody - from the critics or the regular audience - complained though, despite knowing very well that it's a completely insensible machine! The traveling of the shark after the family from New England to the Bahamas wasn't firstly perceptible for me; however, that was to assure the ravenousness of the revenge anyway. This stuff is nearly in every movie, but maybe there was no remnant mercy this time.The special effects were decent. The performance was so good, especially every moment of Caine. I loved some of the dialogue, along with the telepathy factor between the mother and the shark. The directing did it nicely. It's well-edited and well-cinematographed. The locations looked cool. Well, it's not a monster. It's the exploitative sequel and in low tone, but watchable and better than part 2 also.I believe the budget limited everything, defining what character was wanted for this movie from the start. So the script provided simple and harmless 90 minutes to entertain. Clearly, the audience expected more. And with the aforementioned points, they couldn't care less. But I do care.It's not underrated. It's just being cursed more than it deserves.

reviews.review_title: Makes Jaws 3 look like an Oscar winner
reviews.content: You didn't need a sixth sense to know how this installment was going to turn out. It never stopped studio execs from throwing cash at it, in order to squeeze every last dime this moniker had left to give. Subsequently and unremorsefully burying it's reputation deeper than the Mariana Trench.This time around, our shark seems to have gained some supernatural powers to go along with his cranky disposition. How clever. Not only is he telepathic, but he also seems to be able to levitate and let off a roar that would be the envy of Jurassic Park. It's always great seeing characters evolve. Seriously though, I'm surprised they didn't go the Mechagodzilla route and have the shark encased in armor.Along with the Brody bunch subplot being buried in the background, we also get to watch traditional Bahamian life of giant sea snails, welding wives, bad haircuts and watered down Jamaican accents. Michael Caine makes a splash as the witty, wise-cracking pilot named Hoagie. Caine has way too good of a time in this film though, obviously suffering from an undisclosed, obscenely vulgar seven figure salary.As for the rest, let me just say it's beyond words. You'll have to check out this little gem on dvd......if you can find it.

Jaws The Revenge is about Ellen Brody,the wife of sheriff Brody from the first 2 films.Her son is killed by a shark and to get away from it all,she and the rest of her family go to the Bahamas.There she is plagued by thoughts that the shark is coming to kill her family.People say this is one of the worst films of all time.I disagree.I think its just not what people wanted out of a jaws movie.Its more of a drama with a shark in it.Although the shark is very fake looking,the scenes deliver some good suspense despite its abrupt and absurd ending.The score is good,the acting is good,I just don't see what the fuss is about even if the ending sucks.I found it a lot of fun and I wasn't nearly as bored than with Jaws 3.Give it a try.

From Razzie nominated director Joseph Sargent (The Taking of Pelham One Two Three), this was and hopefully will be the last film released starring the large eating machine, and I had heard it was the worst, so I tried it. Basically Ellen Brody (Razzie nominated Lorraine Gary) is still living in the island resort Amity with her now adult sons Michael (Lance Guest) and Sean (Mitchell Anderson), who left Sea World after the events of the previous film, and their father Martin died some time ago of a heart attack. Sean is now a deputy, and one night, as the Christmas season gets underway, he goes out to sea to solve a buoy problem, he is pulled into the water and gobbled up by a large great white shark. After hearing this, Ellen is obviously devastated and convinced that this shark has come back to terrorise the family, and Michael agrees that they should go away. So along with Michael's wife Carla (Karen Young) and five year old daughter Thea (Judith Barsi), the family go the house in the Bahamas on a plane piloted by Hoagie Newcombe (Razzie nominated Sir Michael Caine). While there Michael's Jamaican marine biologist studying friend Jake (Mario Van Peebles) living next door go out to sea to do research, and soon enough the shark shows its face again. Unaware and trying to get over the recent tragedy, Ellen is finding herself falling for Hoagie's charms, he is obviously completely smitten. Secretly Michael and Jake are trying to keep track of the shark, using the special sea heart rate monitor and communication stuff, and soon enough their not telling anyone makes bad happen and the shark attacks on the beach. Carla is angry that Michael knew about the shark and didn't tell anyone, especially with Thea almost hurt, but he and Jake didn't want to upset Ellen. On a single-minded mission to teach the shark a lesson, Ellen takes Michael's boat to go out to sea and kill the monster, while Hoagie, Michael and Jake go after her in the plane. After surviving an attack on the landed plane, Hoagie joins the gang on the near sinking boat, and the plan is to confuse the shark, and then Ellen steers the boat to impale it, and the film ends happily. Also starring Lynn Whitfield as Louisa, Cedric Scott as Clarence, Charles Bowleg as William and Melvin Van Peebles as Mr. Witherspoon. It is obvious that the entire film relies on the rubber shark "Bruce", you never see a real life great white shark during the whole film stretch, you see plenty of bloody kills with it though. I know this was a terrible watch, but in honesty I found some of it laughably awful, i.e. funny when it isn't meant to be, that includes the casting of the likable Caine, but it is ultimately a silly action adventure sequel. It won the Razzie for Worst Visual Effects, and it was nominated for Worst Actor for "Bruce the shark", Worst Picture and Worst Screenplay. Pretty poor!

Mario Van Peebles said it best when, near the end of this movie, he said, "I'm gonna give dat shark a meal he never forget!"Ah, yes... a bad actor (in a bad film with an even worse script) IS a meal worthy of severe indigestion. I popped Tums like popcorn during the entire viewing time.I cannot recall the last time I actually heard a shark "roar", as does the one in this poor-man's Moby Dick. I knew that I'd heard that roar someone else, and my wife kindly pointed out that it sounded just like Spot, the Munsters' fire-breathing pet dragon who lived under the stairs. Moreover, the shark in "Jaws: The Revenge" performed such amazing aquatic feats that certainly it must have been trying out for the Olympic synchronized swimming team.If it's terror and vengeance on the high seas you're thirsting for, take my advice: bypass this last installation in the Jaws saga and curl up with a reliable volume of Melville instead.

After enough horrible shark attacks to fill three movies, it seems that the shark has decided it's going to go after the descendents of the man who killed its ancestors all those years ago. They were its ancestors, right? Or is this the same shark that was killed in the older movies? That would certainly explain why it swims lolling back and forth like its going to roll belly-up. And here I thought that was just jaw-droppingly bad special effects. Normally this would be pretty hard to believe, but the humans in this movie are so monumentally stupid that it's not so bad that they decide to add some extra cognitive ability to the shark. Lorraine Gary plays Ellen Brody, who was the wife of Martin Brody in Jaws 1 and 2. She loses her husband and then her son to the shark, and swears that she'll never have another member of her family going in the water. She heads to the Bahamas and much fighting erupts between her and her son Michael because he happens to be a marine biologist. He loves his job and doesn't want to leave it, but his mother can't have him working on the water anymore.Clearly, it is quite understandable that she would not want members of her family going near the water, since they have been getting eaten by sharks for generations. Which begs the question, of course, of why she gladly allowed her granddaughter to go get towed around behind a boat with her friend. Oh, the girl's mother will be there, so it must be all okay. To make matters worse, after yet another Brody barely escaped being shark food, Ellen decides she better get onto a huge sailboat and go out in search of the shark alone, dressed in street clothes and completely unarmed. What did she plan to do? Scold the shark to death? Maybe smack it around for a little while with those gigantic, gigantic sunglasses? (spoilers) Mario van Peebles, who you might remember from such crapfests as Solo and Sweet Sweetback's Ridiculous Mess, here giving a performance with a ludicrous fake accent that is not even closely rivaled by Don Cheadle in Ocean's 11. The movie is packed with extreme close-ups of the shark, since the one they had to use as a prop was so badly made. This thing is not for a second convincing, and the ending is clearly no exception. It's bad enough that this is a shark that likes to hold its prey above the surface of the water while it eats, but asking us to believe that it will respond to electronic stimulation in the form of flashing lights by standing up vertically and waiting to be stabbed with a boat is entirely too much.Michael Caine does what he can with his terribly written role, which includes the beginnings of a romance with Ellen that disappears from the movie as fast as it was introduced. Maybe they figured people would forget about it anyway when he brilliantly decides to crash land his plane at sea when Ellen's boat is being attacked by the shark. In keeping with the logic with which the rest of the movie is completely devoid, the question that arises is this - why should Ellen sacrifice herself unarmed to the shark when three more people could also sacrifice themselves unarmed to the shark?

reviews.review_title: One of the worst sequels ever...
reviews.content: I didn't see Jaws:The Revenge until recently, after hearing so many bad things about it. And I do wish I left it alone, this has a reputation on the whole as being one of the worst sequels ever, and as far as I'm concerned that reputation is deserved. Steven Spielberg's Jaws is brilliant, not only one of his best films but also the very movie that made me afraid to go into the sea.Jaws:The Revenge didn't have that effect on me whatsoever. In alternative to giving genuine scares and thrills, the whole film is laughable. Especially in the plot, which is really quite inept, and in the climax, which is the epitome of WTF? Jaws:The Revenge also has some embarrassingly cheesy dialogue and poor pacing. Then there's the direction, Spielberg's direction was one of the many things that made the 1975 film so good, but the direction here from Joseph Sargent is incompetent.The production values don't fare much better. The locations are quite nice but the cinematography and lighting are altogether unexceptional. The music is also disappointing, whereas the music was what made Jaws so unnerving in terms of mood, it was way too gimmicky here. The less said about Bruce the shark the better, he is not menacing at all, instead he is one of the many laughable assets of the film. Also he is not used well at all, and there is little to no build-up or suspense whenever he appears on screen. The acting is atrocious, the only actor who tries and the only redeeming quality is Michael Caine who deserves better. Lorraine Grey is annoyingly neurotic, while I was shocked that the talented late Judith Barsi would participate in such a mess, and her talents aren't even put to good use. Don't get me started on Mario Van Peebles, him, his character and his comic lines are annoying and get old fast.Overall, a terrible film and one of the worst sequels I've seen and I have seen a lot. 1/10 Bethany Cox

This movie is one of the funniest comedies in years. I mean, it has all the great qualities of a classic comedy: 1) JAMAICANS, BABY 2) old women with problems. reviews.review_title: New device replaces bullet to put an end to latest killer shark
reviews.content: Ellen Brody had witnessed the shark killing one of the young boaters in a Bahamas seashore. She thought she had seen the last of the killer shark and wanted to get her innocence back. But she can't.She already had seen enough of that and decides to commandeer a schooner on the beach in the seashore to do what I thought to kill the shark, but later on, I realized that she wanted to be killed by the shark by moving the schooner far away from the beach area.Then, as Jake and Hoakie on a small plane rescue Ellen from suicide, Hoakie gets caught up with the shark as it eats the plane. Ellen thinks that Hoakie was killed by the shark--but they get second life when Hoakie goes up from the water, not bloodied at all, to get on the schooner. Jake and Hoakie go inside the boat and prepare what I call two "shark shockers". The things are almost like theatrical light devices you see in theaters. When activated, there is a high-pitched radio-like shriek followed by a flash-bang strobe, which in turn sets off a ultrasonic shock wave that can cripple a shark's heart in its vicinity.Then, the shark goes by surprise and eats up Jake. And you think Jake was going to be gone forever as blood explodes out of his body.Then the shark appears again and tries its attack on the schooner.Hoakie then re-activates the shark shocker as he goes to the bow of the boat, and was able to do two series of a "high-pitched sounds followed by bangs", then the shocker fails for 20 seconds. Then it works again...two more high sounds followed by bangs...The shark then reacts to the noises by standing more and more erect and becoming incensed.So this shark shocker is almost like a reverse of a pyrotechnic device that has a whistling sound before the explosion.There were two edited versions of that grand finale that put an end to the last killer shark in "Jaws The Revenge" as the bangs caused the shark to be so jolted by the shark shocker that it seemed to stand erect from the water like a dolphin--right into the path of a long, sharp broken front end of a wooden stick of the schooner that would pierce the shark's chest. One of them bleeps out the intercutting of the famous scenes from Jaws and Jaws II, including the famous Chief Brody shooting the shot that meant deadly doom to the last killer shark in the original Jaws, and a few of the scenes of the victims being killed by sharks in Jaws and Jaws II, and instead focused only on the wooden stick that pierces the shark...as the shark goes into the water in its pool of blood for the last time.The longer, unedited version had the intercutting put in. It was purposely done to make Jaws fans remember the killer shark as the main antagonist. Usually, this film technique would be bad for most movies that don't have sequels.And the big twist after the last shark dies was when Hoakie, Ellen and Michael saw Jake re-emerge from the water---alive! Ellen was sighing in relief. It seems like with all of that bad luck by the killer shark, some good can be surprising.

reviews.review_title: Ranks Right Up There with the Best of the Bad
reviews.content: Jaws: The Revenge (1987)*** (out of 4) Sue me, it's not as bad as it's reputation and it's certainly a lot better than the previous entry. After the death of Sean Brody from a shark attack, his mother Ellen (Lorraine Gary) goes with her other son Michael (Lance Guest) to the Bahamas where he works. Ellen has a fear that the Great White shark is stalking her family and sure enough soon there's a beast in the Bahamas.If you read enough reviews you'll come away thinking that JAWS: THE REVENGE is one of the worst movies ever made. In fact, many people call it one of the worst films of the decade. Heck, the movie isn't nearly that bad and it's certainly much better than the third film in the series. I'm not going to try and pretend that the "revenge" of the shark isn't stupid because it really is. I'm sure they were originally meaning for this to be more psychological than anything else but even with the countless flaws I still find an entertaining "B" movie here.Roger Ebert's brilliant review points out the countless bad things in the movie but I still think there's quite a bit here to enjoy. For starters, I enjoyed the fact that they try to link this to (at least) the first two films in the series. Usually sequels head off with different and new characters but I always enjoyed that this series stuck with characters we're familiar with. The characters here are certainly ones we like and care for. Another thing that makes the film work is the beautiful underwater photography. Everything under the water looks terrific whether it's the attacks or the stuff dealing with the snails.Finally, I know there aren't too many actual attacks here but I enjoyed how much of the shark we get to see. Again, there are countless logical issues with the shark include how it seems to stand on its tail at times but at the same time I enjoy seeing it. People say the shark looks fake, which is true but then again, it is fake! Most movies hide the monsters for this very reason. If you show it too much people will see that it's fake. I enjoy that this movie didn't care if you knew it was fake and showed it.Gary isn't Oscar-worthy here but she does fine with the role. The same is true for Guest and Karen Young. Mario Van Peebles is fun in his role as are the rest of the supporting players including Michael Caine who skipped the Oscars to make this movie. Of course, there are two versions of the film out there and I prefer the original theatrical cut with the darker ending. Either way, JAWS: THE REVENGE wasn't meant to challenge the original film as it was just meant to be summer entertainment.

Brody has been dead from a heart attack. The son deputy Sean Brody is killed by a shark on Amity Island. Other son Michael Brody (Lance Guest) and his family come home for the funeral. Mother Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) is sure that the family is being hunted and she wants everybody away from the waters. They convince Ellen to come with them to their Bahamas home. Hoagie (Michael Caine) flies the plane to their island home. Jake (Mario Van Peebles) is their neighbor and fellow marine biologist.The concept is laughable. Apparently a shark is hunting this family for revenge. In case you wonder if Michael Caine could salvage the material, the answer is no. He's said many times that he was doing it for the paycheck at this time. It looks like it. Almost nothing happens for a long stretch. The story is boring. It's filmed in a boring way. This is all very boring.
It's a crap movie. This movie is an insult to the movie "Jaws" short and clear ! I didn't get bored watching it because I was watching it like a funny movie that was so bad. Shame on you !

That's a line from "Jaws 2" when a second shark attacks Amity. However, according to this one, sharks DO take things personally. This movie pretends that "Jaws 3" never happened. Sean Brody (Mitchell Anderson) is the police chief of Amity--his other brother Mike (Lance Guest) works with Jamaican Jake (Mario van Peebles) in the Bahamas. Sean is killed by a shark (who supposedly set up the trap!!!) and his mother Ellen (Lorraine Gary) is positive the shark is targeting the whole family (!!!). Mike brings her to the Bahamas to recover...but the shark follows. Ellen knows this because she has a telepathic link with the shark (!!!!!).Yep, it's as stupid as it sounds. It starts out OK with Sean being attacked and killed--and Anderson was actually very good in his role-- but I'd like to know HOW the shark was able to set it all up. It moves to the Bahamas and falls apart swiftly. First off, two white sharks were killed in the first two movies. What is this one? A cousin of them? Second--Gary having a "link" to the shark is just absurd. Third--van Peebles (a good actor) has to use an annoying accent and if he had said "mon" one more time I would have screamed; fourth--Michael Caine pops up as "Hoagie"--he deserves better; fifth--the shark looks fake; sixth--watch for the scene where Caine is pulled out of the water...and is completely dry and seventh--the ending is annoying stupid and abrupt. Also Gary looks terrible--but it fits the movie I suppose.On the plus side--Guest and Caine are very good and the Bahamas location looks breath-taking. Still that doesn't excuse the ludicrous script and lousy acting from everyone else. And van Peebles "comic" lines are painfully unfunny.At least Caine and Guest have excuses for making this--Caine said it was for a free trip to the Bahamas and Guest said he did it to work with Caine. Still, this can safely be skipped completely. A sad ending to what started out as a great series. A 1.

2.9? Okay, I know this film is the weakest of the franchise, but it doesn't deserve a rating THIS low. I gave it 7 out of 10 stars, at least. The shark may look fake at times, but were any of the sharks in this franchise even remotely realistic? And, don't even get me started on the "sharks don't roar" argument. Each film in this franchise depicts a shark either roaring or growling. So don't single out this film with that "logic" while ignoring the rest of them. You want real sharks? Go watch a documentary about them! These films are meant to be entertaining, not to be thought of as real.

The fourth and last official "Jaws" movie to date boosts supporting player Lorraine Gary to star status as the now widowed Ellen Brody. In the early minutes of the movie, her younger son, Sean (Mitchell Anderson), now a deputy, is gobbled up by yet another killer great white, prompting her to believe that that particular species simply has it in for her whole family. Despite this, she accepts the invitation of her older son Michael (Lance Guest) to stay with him and his family in the Bahamas, where - surprise, surprise - he works as a marine biologist. Yes, despite everything that happens to them, this stupid family just won't stay out of the water. And yes, you guessed it...the *same* shark that ate Sean tracks the Brodys to the Bahamas.The patently absurd script by Michael de Guzman is the worst flaw in this lackluster effort. The filmmakers actually go out of their way to show the shark as often as possible, which only serves to point up how obviously phony it is. There is, for the most part, a sufficient lack of tension, and the main reason why "Jaws: The Revenge" would be entertaining at all is because it's so laughable. Gary, sporting a none too flattering hairdo, does take herself pretty seriously, but the other cast members certainly don't look too happy to be there; Mario Van Peebles speaks in a ridiculously unconvincing accent, and Michael Caine offers his effortless charisma to a supporting role as a pilot who tries to romance Gary. It may not be a great role, but his presence in anything is always welcome. One worthy component is the music score by Michael Small; both adapting John Williams' legendary themes and adding his own compositions, he helps to make the scenes just a little bit better. Admittedly, this is also shot rather well (by John McPherson).Like many bad movies before and after it, "Jaws: The Revenge" is a compelling train wreck in spite of itself.Five out of 10.

That alone should tell you to avoid this like the plague.

reviews.review_title: A totally irrelevant and absurd final entry in the Jaws series.
reviews.content: First, there was Jaws  a suspense masterpiece from a young whiz-kid named Steven Spileberg that altered forever the summer box office trade. Then there was Jaws 2  a pretty poor sequel geared mainly to make a little extra money on the back of its illustrious predecessor. Jaws 3 came later  a really poor second sequel with gimmicky 3-D effects and an unrelated plot. But they saved the ultimate howler for last. Jaws: The Revenge is the fourth and final film in the series. and it is absolutely terrible. I'm talking terrible in its most pure form here. Jaws: The Revenge is an all-time clunker that will be looked back on one day by collectors of bad movies with the kind of fondness reserved for Plan 9 From Outer Space and Santa Claus Conquers The Martians.It has been several years since Police Chief Brody killed two Great White Sharks off Amity Island (that would be the story lines from Jaws 1 and 2, if you don't already know). Brody is now dead, having spent the last years of his life haunted by memories of his shark experiences. His widow, Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary), still lives on Amity Island and her youngest son Sean (Mitchell Anderson) is now the local policeman, following proudly in Dad's footsteps. Unfortunately, one Christmas Sean is called out to remove some debris from the harbour and, while going unsuspectingly about his work, he is attacked and killed by another Great White Shark. Distraught, Ellen leaves Amity and heads off for the Bahamas, where her eldest son Michael (Lance Guest) works as a marine scientist. Michael assures his mother that there's nothing to fear as Great White Sharks wouldn't survive in the Bahamian waters as they don't like warm seas. But by now, Ellen is convinced that the shark has a vendetta against her family and will not stop until it has killed them all. Stupid as it sounds, her fears prove correct. the Great White pursues her to the Bahamas and sets about finishing off her and her son.Let me just recap that if you think you've read a misprint: "The Great White pursues her to the Bahamas". Yes, a shark actually somehow figures out that its intended victim has travelled a thousand miles to a different part of the world. Yes, the shark then swims down to this different part of the world to find this victim. And yes, the shark goes there even though it means leaving its normal habitat. One must assume that the film is suggesting that the Brody family have had so many run-ins with Great White Sharks that some kind of telekinetic link has formed between the two. Such a plot device is so stupid - so utterly, utterly ludicrous  that it is insulting to the viewers. However, we might still find the charity in our hearts to forgive the films its moronic plot if it were able to at least provide some decent shocks. But even here our hopes are struck down in tatters. There is no suspense whatsoever in Jaws: The Revenge. The shark attacks are minimal and when they finally arrive they are predictable, dull and half-hearted. Even in the finale, when it seems that Michael Caine and Mario Van Peebles have been killed by the shark, both turn up alive and well shortly afterwards!! Jaws: The Revenge is truly, truly awful and what makes matters worse is the fact that it leaves such a bad impression that it almost makes one forget how good the original was.

Roy Schieder didn't return after part 2, so he is dead in the film, so its up to Ellen this time to fight the fish.Sean Brody is now the deputy of Amity, and his job involves shifting rubbish in the ocean. On one fateful rubbish removal, a vengeful shark seems to recall to actions of the Brody family of the last 15 years on sharks, and gobbles up poor old Sean.After a funeral, and many flashbacks, Ellen decides to to stay with Michael, and meets up with a pre comeback Michael Caine and Mario Van Peebles.Not wanting to miss a trick, Jaws four decides to join the family and kill a few people on the way.....Jaws is a phenomenal movie. It started the summer blockbuster legacy, but it should have stayed as a singular movie. Number 2 was literally that, 3 was amiable but too Quaidy, and the fourth part is beyond the borders of rational, and this is what makes it so watchable.Don't get me wrong, its terrible in many ways, but for heavens sake, its laugh out loud funny, never boring, and if your a shark enthusiast, there must be a wonderful drinking game to play every time the makers make an error.Suspend your belief for nearly ninety minutes, and you will enjoy the fact that sharks do have a voice, sharks do seek revenge and follow people halfway across the world, and the best one of all, Caine playing it straight and actually being watchable and the best thing about the film.The rest of the cast are almost autonomous, especially Grey, but this is one of those films that I can go back to again and again, and never get bored of.Essential viewing for the bad movie connoisseur ....

reviews.review_title: Thus bringing to an end the saga of Bruce

Hardly surprising, considering they killed it in the last three movies.

"Violent, nasty, crude. There was nothing in the picture (Jaws) that was personal to me. It was a calculated movie. I made each cut with glee, knowing the effect that it would have on the audience. I don't ever want to be involved in another picture like that." – Steven Spielberg "Making a sequel to anything is just a cheap carny trick." - Steven Spielberg (1978) Sooner or later all these slasher franchises become increasingly supernatural, their plots and audiences finally confronting the fact that their horrors were never remotely "real" in the first place. Were never anything more than an amusement park ride.We see this taking place in the "Jaws" franchise, in which the shark not only nonsensically reassembles itself after dying in each episode, but then develops a taste for vengeance. But not only is Jaws a supernatural and vengeful shark, but he is a master of genetics, detective work and propulsion as well, able to home in on whole family trees, pinpoint the offspring and spouses of those he hates and swim from New York to the Bahamas in less than three days.But that's not all, Jaws somehow manages to get larger and larger with each passing episode (he's resurrected in a bigger body each time?), is able to roar like a lion and even manages to kill the hero of the first "Jaws" film by provoking a heart attack. When did shark attacks start manifesting themselves as heart attacks? The heroes and victims of slasher films always behave in stupid ways, but this film exhibits some extraordinarily nonsensical behaviour. Our heroine is attacked by Jaws on the water (and loses her son to him) and so where does she decide to go on holiday? The Bahamas! Womanserious? An island? Not only that, once she's attacked on a boat by Jaws (how did he find her?) she then decides to go out on yet another boat. What the hell? Lady, stay inland! With the film so bad, it's nice to see actor Michael Caine not taking things too seriously. His dialogue is ridiculous - "Sweet Jesus, we are heading straight for it!" – but the guy delivers his lines with a camp quality which makes the film watchable today. In a sense, Caine's self mocking performance was ahead of the times, teasing an inept film that took itself far too seriously.7/10 – So bad it's funny. Incidentally, Spielberg all but disowned "Jaws", refusing to direct any sequels and denouncing the concept of franchises. Ironically he would later forge a career dependent on "Jaws'" gleeful machinations and carny tricks and himself direct numerous sequels.

News Flash: The world does NOT revolve around the Brody's. They drag in Lorraine Gary as a crutch to get the big bucks rolling. Ellen Brody knows its coming, she just knows. When little dad-copy-cater Sean meets his fate(which was sealed in the second), Ellen knows its personal, but the world could get better, if only to escape the scene of the crime for a few days (Amitty Island). Alas! the card board shark with a stuck up nose follows Ellen, Michael, and his family to the bahamas for christmas dinner! UGH! Gary tries hard to hold this one on her shoulders, and fails. Guest and Young were more than noticably put together for sex appeal, and Peebles is just not that funny. The worst part is that terrible excuse for a monster that looks more as though it tries to be more tough than the previous sharks...not gonna happen! Whats with the stuck up nose, and the .5 mph swimming? Something needed to be relooked at before release. Michael Caine is also wasted as a good hearted Hoagie...sad stuff. The producers really sunk into it this time, leaving many fans ready to set revenge on this movie. Realy bad in every department, Judith Barsi was cute as little granddaughter, so sweet and naive, but honestly, this is one of the worst films ever produced!

reviews.review_title: Revenge of the 80's: The definite unnecessary sequel.
reviews.content: Jaws: The Revenge (1987) has to be the worse sequel ever made for a good film. The JAWS series has gotten progressively worse over the years. After the debacle with the 3-D sequel, I didn't think that the producers could sink any lower. Well they have with this highly illogical and annoying sequel. All those involved with this project should lower their heads in shame. I have never seen such a terrible film. Okay I have, but this was a major released picture that actually was shot on film and played in movie theaters. The only one who should receive a pass is Maurice Micklewhite. At least he admits that he'll appear in anything that pays him a decent wage. A final nail into the JAWS legacy. Let's hope that there will be no more sequels made. Finger crossed people.Not recommended at all.

reviews.review_title: It's bad, but it's not *that* bad
reviews.content: Man, people really hate these last two sequels, eh?I don't even think 'Jaws 3-D' is as awful as most fellow reviewers think and that's the case again with 'Jaws: The Revenge'. It's bad, but it's not that bad. It makes little sense, though to be fair it is from a franchise that is all about a huge human-killing shark; despite sharks, in fact, not actually being all that keen on our rotten flesh.Michael Caine is somehow in this. Well, I say somehow... a trip to the Bahamas and a nice paycheck likely made it entirely logical from his view; as he reportedly stated himself. Lorraine Gary, meanwhile, spearheads an average support cast. Speaking of whom, I did find their dialogue and interactions to be very unnatural and forced.5*. There are many, many worse films out there though.
