Why people dislike this film is a mystery.  In view of the four "Jaws" films this film ranks number 3.  "Jaws 3-D" is the worst of the four.  The reason for this is due to "Jaws 3-D" being removed from the series (Mike and Sean Brody in Florida), whereas "Jaws the Revenge" begins where the first two were placed; Amity.  As such, the story is a continuation of the first two films; in the "Jaws" universe.  There is a bold move in the begining of the film (which must be seen in context of the other films to get its impact) involving an attack.  The acting during this attack is very well done.  It would be the actions and words of one in real life.Perhaps the reason people dispise this film as much as they do is due to the same reason they call the shark "Jaws".  The shark is not named Jaws; the title refers to a part of the shark.Another factor that places this film above "Jaws 3-D" is the music.  John Williams' score is used rather than mangled as it was in the third film. "Jaws 3-D" used an altered version, while "Jaws the Revenge" used Williams' music combined with Michael Small's score.Now, the film is not a strong film, yet it is a studio release and far better than many similar direct-to-video releases.  It is also better than the many similar plotted shark films released after the first film.The director of "Jaws the Revenge" stated on Entertianment Tonight, "Jaws 3 was not that good."  The errors here are due to the fact that the screenplay was written in such a short time.  The first film had many drafts by Peter Benchley.  This is what makes the difference.  Something that is worked on over a period of time will be greater than something done as a first (or close to first) draft."Jaws the Revenge" was a return to the series.  It is not as bad as it is made out to be.
I assure you that this is just a waste of your life

Why was this movie made? Whyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy?????? It destroys Jaws! I did not see the entire movie, I just went to YouTube and typed in "Jaws 4 Ending" and watched the final battle, but that was MORE THAN ENOUGH!! The acting was god-awful! Lorraine Gary gave a laughable performance as Ellen Brody. Mario van Peebles gives a flop as Jake, the badly accented Jamaican (if thats what he was intending to try to be anyway!). Why is Michael Caine wasting his time here? The plot here is AWFUL! Although I did not see the entire movie, I know the entire plot pretty much and who dies, yada yada yada. Sean Brody, Chief martin Brody's youngest son, is killed first in this movie by a shark who is mad at the Brody's for killing its relatives in the first 2 movies. OK, but thats ridiculous. Why would the shark know to go for the Brody family? How does it even know who they are? Well, anyway, something about Sean being the new chief of Amity and he goes to check a buoy and is killed by the shark or something. Afterward, Ellen Brody goes to the Bahamas to see her other son, Michael. But the shark FOLLOWS HER! (Why not just make him FLY while they're at it?) Then he munches on a victim once he's there to show he "means business" or something. After a long and boring story or something, the main characters are on a boat in the water and the shark decides to attack. Jake puts something in its mouth and is then dragged into the ocean and munched on in a pool of blood and dragged under. However we later learned HE LIVED! WHAT THE HELL? Anyways, then Michael pulls out a fancy looking blinking strobe light and it makes a camera sound like its taking a picture and flashes like he IS taking a picture. The shark then jumps out of the water and replies with "RAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAWWWWWWWWWWWWWR". At this point I was almost peeing my pants laughing. Then it shows clips of Martin from the final fight of the first movie and Ellen gets the stupid idea of driving the boat at the shark as if shes flying a missile into a deadly asteroid.(How is she seeing this? SHE WASN'T THERE IN THE FIRST MOVIE!) Then, by some miracle of god above, the spoke on the front of the ship hits the shark's fin right after Brody says "Smile you son of a-" In the flashback and the shark EXPLODES!! They then all jump off the boat for seemingly no reason and in the next scene the boat is GONE! NO trace of it anywhere! Then Jake turns up not-dead and blah blah blah OK I'm bored. This was the only movie I ever laughed at for being so horrible. Me and my brother make fun of it all the time. We always say "when jaws flies" rather than "when pigs fly". This was possibly the worst movie I have ever seen, my brother too. It ruins the Jaws movie(s) and stains the screen with its terrible plot and acting. Do not watch this movie if you're looking for a good movie.

reviews.review_title: This movie is worse than any damage a shark can do
reviews.content: Sequels were not usually good. However, Jaws: The Revenge is less than "not good." It is a disaster from one end to the other. Simply put: It's really, really bad! Various things I have heard make this movie bad. First of all, a shark chooses Chief Brody, and somehow travels over 1000 miles in two days just to reach him. This would have built up suspense, if it weren't so unrealistic. Second, the shark only kills people in water. Smart move staying right next to a home surrounded by it, don't you think? Third, it somehow manages to get out of the water and bite off somebody's arm in the beginning. Fourth, the shark can't stay in the temperature of water it was in. It's cold-blooded, right? Fifth, was that there was a plot hole some where near the end. The sixth reason is that the shark came up to a dock or whatever, and started biting it, when the people were so far away.But, I didn't notice many of these reason when I first watched it. The thing I hated the most about Jaws: The Revenge is how interesting it was, and it wasn't very interesting. If I could describe this film in one word, it would be: *yawn*.If you see this, see it somewhere where you can easily walk away from.Good: ...Bad: Unrealistic, boring, plot holes, etc.Feel free to send me a Private Message regarding this comment.

reviews.review_title: Based on a Really Dumb Premise
reviews.content: After her son "Sean Brody" (Mitchell Anderson) is killed by a great white shark in the waters off of Amity, New York, "Ellen Brody" (Lorraine Gray) flies to the Bahamas where her other son "Michael Brody" (Lance Guest) works as a marine biologist. Once there she gets premonitions of the great white shark coming after both her and Michael to order to get its revenge on them for one reason or another-it's not really clear. But what is clear is that this movie is based on a really dumb premise. I mean, let's face it, sharks don't take things personally! So to base an entire film around this ridiculous concept is just plain crazy. Add to that the fact that the scenes on land were extremely dull and essentially what is left is an incredibly boring--if not ludicrous-film. On the other hand the tropical scenery was nice and Lynn Whitfield (as "Louisa") was equally pleasant to look at as well. Unfortunately, those two qualities were hardly enough to lift this film into marginal territory. That said I have to rate this movie as below average.

reviews.review_title: Jaws V: This Time It's For Money
reviews.content: I am interested in making a fifth installment to the series casting Jaws in the complex role of an assassin. This time it's for money and nothing can stop this bloodthirsty shark. Features extras such as Jaws in the club, Jaws playing racketball, Jaws rockin' a mink.. the sky is the limit. Were you enthralled by the first film but disappointed by sequels that tried to come off as scary and suspenseful? Well, don't worry, because Jaws V: This Time It's For Money is strictly parody. Plus my film will be completely self-deprecating and won't try to be scary. You'll double over with laughter as Jaws chows his way through the courtroom. Starring Steve Guttenburg as the toughguy with a soundtrack from Air Supply and Trixter.

reviews.review_title: A great white shark is after the lives of the Brody family.Can they survive or go down to the murderous jaws one after another?
reviews.content: The worst Jaws movie I've ever seen. The shark roars like a tiger(I don't think a shark roars like that).Sean Brody's arm ripping scene was most idiotic to me.Another thing- can a shark know in which part of the earth you are in? In the movie the shark eventually followed Ellen Brody and her family to the Bahamas! The movie could do a bit better if it had Roy Schieder(or any other person in Martin Brody's role). The worst part is the climax.I actually could not understand the destruction of the shark.The shark was quite massive compared to the other sharks in the Jaws series.The sharks size was as huge as the sharks in the movie-DEEP BLUE SEA.But even though DBS had gone a bit further with it's action packed scenes.Another hating part is the kissing of Ellen & Hoagie.I had expected a lot better plot line from Michael De Guzman,the writer.The worst movie award should be handed over!
The plot of this movie is just laughable. A shark tracking down a family across America for revenge. I have no more words.

Between the obvious fake shark and being able to see the ropes that help it move, the idea of a shark following Ellen to the Bahamas, the fact that Michael is a marine biologist after having three close encounters with sharks and nearly dying, the shark roaring and standing up on the water like a dragon, the scene where Michael Caine goes underwater but then comes out with a dry shirt...it's all too much to handle. This is an extremely embarrassing film. Joseph Sargent obviously had no clue about sharks and no idea what he was doing...this film should never be viewed by anyone, not even to laugh at how stupid it is. It's a shame that Jaws only has one decent sequel, which is Jaws 2, but This movie makes Jaws 3-D look like a classic

If you thought that the vengeful killer whale from Orca (1977) was exceptionally resourceful, wait until you get a load of the malevolent great white shark from Jaws IV: it follows Ellen Brody (widow of Chief Brody from the original film, who has since died of a heart attack i.e., Roy Scheider said "No!") all the way from Amity Island, Massachusetts, where it snacked on her youngest son Sean, to the Bahamas, where she has gone to stay with her remaining son, marine biologist Michael (Lance Guest), and his family.Despite being told by Michael that sharks do not visit the Bahamas, Ellen (once again played by Lorraine Gary) is still afraid, her psychic powers warning her that the shark is nearby. Meanwhile Michael and best pal Jake (Mario Van Peebles) encounter the shark and attempt to study its behaviour, while pilot Hoagie (Michael Caine) tries to take Ellen's mind off all things finned and toothy by showing her the sights.Even ignoring the ridiculous notion of a shark somehow tracking Ellen's flight south for 1200 miles, Jaws IV is still a really poor film, with none of the great characterisation, atmosphere, suspense or sheer horror of the original (hell, it doesn't even come close to Jaws 3-D). Way too much time is spent on Ellen's romance with Hoagie, Michael's relationship with his wife Carla (Karen Young), and his friendship with Jake, when it really should be focusing on the shark.Even when it does get to the man-eating fish, the film is a complete let down, the rubbery shark completely unconvincing and not nearly deadly enough: only two people are killed throughout the entire film, Jake and Hoagie surviving their close encounters with the shark because it would be upsetting for the viewer if they died (they're too nice to get eaten). After plenty of silliness (including the shark pulling a plane under the surface of the ocean), the killer fish is stopped when Ellen rams it with the hull of Michael's boat, causing it and the vessel to explode.3/10, purely for the banana boat scene, which delivers the kind of human chomping action that there really should have been more of.

You try and put them together but its like trying to put a shark shaped peg through a Dreyfuss shaped hole. Jaws and Jaws: The Revenge. Two movies, the SAME series and yet one is a classic and the first summer blockbuster and the other is, er, well...I'm not quite sure. We'll attempt to work out what it is together over the course of the next 300 words or so. Where to begin? No doubt the producers of 'The Revenge' asked themselves a similar question. What was left? Amity had endured two shark problems which is quite a lot for a small coastal town, especially a fictional one and they'd tried the Jaws in a different setting thing but it was curiously one-dimensional, even with 3-D glasses. You could of course just have another shark wander into the waters off Amity's shore but that night be construed as stretching credibility in some way so instead they came up with something quite wonderful and zoologically spurious - a vengeful shark with a murderous grudge against the Brody Family! Absolutely brilliant! Except that this is of course the most insanely misconceived idea in movie history. It's so bad that the only explanation for its passage to production is that someone pitched it as a kind of joke only to be horrified when the backers gave it a resounding thumbs up. Screenwriter Michael De Guzman who strangely hasn't subsequently become an A-list Hollywood scribe must have been too embarrassed to correct his bosses and so off he went and the result may be not just the worst sequel of all time but possibly one of the worst movies of all time. It does however introduce us to the most intelligent Shark in the history of the world. More cunning than his predecessors no.4 can set traps, learn the details of local law enforcement and manipulate certain people to come out on to the water, use its contacts on dry-land to find flight information on the Brody family and alter its own bio-chemistry to survive in warmer waters having swam some 3,000 miles to pursue the unlucky Brody brood. Is it any wonder Roy Scheider's character had a fatal heart attack? Teams of experts should be descending on the Bahamas to study the most unique animal that's ever lived but instead Michael Caine wants to kill it, which is baffling frankly. So the script isn't so much Quint as Jack Sparrow but at the least there's the taunt direction, the polished production values and the impeccable performances and if believe that you'll believe a Shark can roar.

reviews.review_title: S for Shark, V for Vendetta and C for Crap.
reviews.content: Alas, Jaws: The Revenge; the fourth (count them) Jaws film and third successfully insignificant sequel to that of Spielberg's fantastic 1975 film Jaws but Jaws: The Revenge shouldn't just be compared to that of Jaws but also to that of any other film ever made in terms of quality. Jaws: The Revenge on its own is not even entertaining enough to be a second rate monster movie like an Anaconda (1997) or a Deep Rising (1998) or something along those lines.The things wrong with Jaws: The Revenge just spill off the screen like a barrel of grease down a water slide  anything that CAN go wrong in terms of logistics, what we're seeing or even the entire premise in the first place; DOES go wrong. Early on one character actually states about how the thought of the shark coming back for revenge on the Brody family is simply impossible  you know that and I know that  shark's don't know who's who on land so the fact one of the characters openly denies the fact this plot is even feasible on screen is mind blowingly backward film-making on its own merit.Another problem with this film is just its basic content which is split into two different pieces: dialogue on the land, sea or in the air and action scenes. A lot of the dialogue scenes at least to me just seemed pointless and to be honest, were rather dull. Examples of this are: the scene on the beach in the Caribbean as Ellen looks out to sea in a silly 'I know you're out there' sort of a way, the sea bed digging scene involving Michael Brody (Martin's son) as he looks for sea snails or something (we don't need to know what he does for a living) and the new year's eve party which serves as an overly long and tedious scene where the outcome is just Hoagie (Michael Caine) admitting some sort of a feeling for Ellen  this whole love side plot was very out of place and in the end, so pointless that the film could've chopped the whole new years eve part out.So many things backfire on so many levels, it's incredible. The fact we need to stomach this shark is actually out for 'revenge' against the Brody family and that it can swim from Amity to the Caribbean as well as pinpoint where it is the Brody family are now living; the fact the child is smart enough to recognise Ellen is called evasive by her mother and be able to imply it herself when Ellen is actually being evasive in front of her yet is not smart enough to know that you 'fly' a plane and not 'drive' it; the way in which Michael, Jake (van Peebles) and the rest of the characteristically non existent Caribbean crew are stupid enough to continue whatever pointless exercise it is they're doing even though the shark has struck  Jake even wants to go after it bringing back rehashed ideas Jaws 3-D had when the water-world employees wanted to capture it for their park.If there is any saving grace it's the finale where the shark and the characters do battle on a little boat that Ellen took out on her own  something I still can't fathom the logic behind. The film borrows so heavily from the first Jaws film that the flashbacks involved are practically retelling the way the first film concluded and as a result, it feels like we're watching the first film's climax! With continuity problems abound, an insane and impossible premise as well as a really comic atmosphere and rather bland film-making, Jaws: The Revenge is the slow and painful death of what was the Jaws franchise.

reviews.review_title: A disgrace to the series SPOILER ALERT!
reviews.content: I've been reviewing so many movies that I like that I have forgotten the pleasure of bombing on a movie that sucks. Let me take some time now to skewer this stinking turd of a movie. Let me start out by saying that this film should never have been made. Jaws should never have spawned any sequels, it wasn't set up that way. This movie is a classic example of Hollywood milking a franchise until it's completely dead. Other reviewers have listed some of the inconsistencies that abound in the movie. I have to point out some whoppers though. First of all, the shark ROARS. Since sharks don't make any sound let alone let out a corny roar much sampled by other movies, TV shows and cartoons, I think it's pretty damn hokey. The shark is following the family. It's interesting that a fish can follow a family on land. This must be some kind of mutant alien shark or something. Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) has flashbacks to scenes that she never was there for. Maybe she's all seeing like God or something. A strobe light drives Jaws nuts. If only they had known this in the first film, Robert Shaw might still be with us. Michael Caine agreed to do this film. He must have been really, really, really drunk to agree to this. "Jaws 4, that sounds like a right good film. Shark follows family to the Bahamas eh? A classic like this needs an Oscar winning chap like me. Where do I sign." The shark gets impaled by the bowspirt of Michael's sloop. Sorry to ruin the ending for you there but you see the shark was holding itself almost completely out of the water roaring because the strobe light was driving him crazy and Ellen smashed into him with the bowspirt and....it's just to much for a film fanatic to take. At least Mario Van Peebles got eaten. Depending on the version of the film you're seeing he could have lived. Let's just say that he died ok. It makes me feel better. Bottom Line: I could go on and on and on but you get the general idea. Jaws 4 sucks.
This is diabolically bad, plot full of holes, extremely irritating characters, bad casting, bad acting, idiotic character actions, etc.2 stars for the rubber shark, the best actor in the movie!

I believe that everyone who laughs at Jaws:The Revenge has a secret obsession for it. They really do find it to be the best Jaws movie. This is because Jaws The Revenge IS the greatest of all the Jaws movies.It has the best performances, the best photography, the best soundtrack and it has the best actor- Michael Caine. People who hate this movie do not hate it really.They love it more than the original yet refuse to acknowledge it publicly. Michael Caine excels in his role as a travel weary pilot, trying to find a reason to live and finding it in Lorraine Gary. Thus follows a tale of two lonely people trying to find company in their later years. Beautiful. True, the shark follows Lorraine Gary to the Bahamas, but so what? Have you never been followed by a wild animal on your way home from the supermarket? I was once followed by a cat. I went on holiday to Austria and on opening my chalet door, there it was, purring for meat. The cat had followed me abroad. These things can happen. Great movie.

WARNING! Might contain spoilers.A very underrated film. Sure it's junk, but it's not as bad as people make it out to be. I keep reading reviews about how it's the same hash recycled from the last three movies, and yes, they are right. But there were parts of this film where I wasn't sure what would happen next. Okay, I could, but I was never sure whether Michael Brody would live or die. I figured he'd live, but I thought they might kill him off to create some dramatic tension (killing off Sean wasn't enough). And eventually, they killed off Jake (though in some versions he lives) and I was kind of upset, I liked Jake and his reggae attitude. Frankly, Mario Van Peebles was probably the best actor in the movie. Bottom Line: Considering Jaws, BAD. But I think Jaws: The Revenge is better than Jaws 3 and about the same as Jaws 2. Doesn't compare to Jaws.

reviews.review_title: The tag-line should have been "This Time It's Pathetic"
reviews.content: Any movie that asks you to accept the idea that a shark could harbor such deep-seeded feelings of resentment that it would follow the widow of a man who killed two other sharks a decade earlier to the Bahamas and take up residence in waters completely opposite its natural climate so that it could lie in wait and pick off the widow's family members one at a time, clearly has some problems right out of the gate.So, certainly Jaws: The Revenge is a dicey proposition. But the inherently ludicrous nature of the story isn't actually the reason why this film is so awful. The real problem here is that the impossible plot isn't the most idiotic thing about the film, and if pressed to identify the key element that makes this fourth entry in the Jaws saga such a wretched mistake, I'd have to say it's the 90 minutes between the opening and closing credits.While the unquestionably retarded logic that drives the core thesis of the plot pretty much ensures that this is going to be a mess of a film, we have to at least give Jaws: The Revenge credit for being consistent, because every other absurd element in the movie reaches that same grandiose level of stupidity. In fact, when the film climaxes with our central protagonist flashing back to events she wasn't there to witness when they happened, our shark being rammed with a boat and exploding on impact, and a character who was bitten in half minutes before returning to the surface alive and well, we have to conclude that Jaws: The Revenge couldn't possibly end in a fashion that more dutifully encompassed its vision.By the time we get there, we've already been forced to adapt to the idea of a shark with the ability to leap out of the ocean and balance atop the surface of the water on its tail-fins. We've hurdled through the presence of a beast massive enough to swallow a man whole, yet svelte enough to maneuver its way through the narrow corridors of a sunken ship. We've also seen an abundance of lingering close-ups that plainly show us that this revenge-seeking predator has mechanical joints and glides along the sea floor on a clearly-displayed track.But, somehow, all of this fits in the warped universe of this film, as does Ellen Brody's decision immediately after a shark attack to commandeer a boat and follow the beast out into the middle of the ocean with the apparent intention of literally feeding herself to it. When confronted with the rashness of her actions, even her response is perfectly tailored to the skewed thought process behind the film: "I had to, there was nothing else to do".Ellen is exactly right, too. In the world of Jaws: The Revenge, staying out of the water where the shark can't get you wouldn't make any sense at all.So, at least in terms of adherence to its idiocy-laden logic, we can safely say that Jaws: The Revenge is a profound achievement. And every time we think things couldn't get more absurd, our shark eats a plane or zeroes in on a Brody family member within a throng of swimmers, so J:TR spends a great deal of its running time outdoing itself.It's worth noting that even the NES video game released in conjunction with this worthless offering is widely considered by those in the know to be one of the crappiest and most utterly pointless games of all time. That certainly adds another layer to the notion of consistency I mentioned earlier, but since spawning an awful video game and effectively ending a franchise are less-than-admirable legacies, I don't think there's any way around stating the obvious fact that Jaws: The Revenge is one of the most dreadful films ever made.If you consider that a selling point, then spread your chum and dive on in. But, please don't consider anything I've written here a recommendation. I couldn't live with that on my conscience.

If the directors of this stinkeroo just had the actors eat beans, sauerkraut, broccoli, and raisins and washed it down with prune juice. Then had them stand shoulder to shoulder on a beach with their backs to us then had all of them bend over at once and give us a recap of the Blazing Saddles "chili" scene and then it's the end, it would've made a better movie than this diaper pail of a sequel to a once great film.This movie is so bad the audience members had to plug their noses and wave the air when they left the theater. In fact, the ushers should have given them a gas mask after he ripped their ticket.First if all, one doesn't have to be an oceanographer to know that sharks have a brain the size of a walnut. They aren't exactly brilliant animals. How one knows the members, travel plans, and history of a certain human family is beyond any reasonable explanation. Second of all, the thought of an aging Michael Caine and menopausal Lorraine Gary doing the nasty doesn't make for a romantic plot. It turns your stomach.And last, when in the history of the world has a shark ever stood up on water and roared? I think a plastic blow up shark would be more convincing than the extremely fake looking herky jerky robot shark they used. At least in Jaws III, we got to see a very hot young Lea Thompson in a bikini. But this joke of a movie had absolutely no redeeming qualities. Even Michael Caine and Lorraine Gary themselves commented on what an awful movie this was. In fact, i'll bet this movie is the reason she left movies altogether. And I'm surprised Roy Scheider didn't demand they remove his background picture off the wall.

reviews.review_title: Not that bad. It's shot beautifully at some points as well.
reviews.content: The fact that they started with a shark attack at night is a big plus. The film has bad dialogue and bad shots of sharks. It's a bit bloody though....IMDB probably put this at the bottom list because they compared it to part 1. IMDB probably made it personal. Lol

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as some would have you think.
reviews.content:
There is a surprising number of people who seem to hate this movie for strange reasons. The main one seem to be they don't think its realistic, as if any of the other Jaws movies were! 
The concept of Jaws:The Revenge is that the family from the original movie are seemingly being targeted by great white sharks in revenge for the deaths of the sharks from the other movies. What I find strange is that this very same plot had been used in the movie Orca which no one seemed to take issue with, but because its Jaws somehow everyone has a problem with it?
The other big criticism is that Michael Caine is in the movie and his acting is bad, it isn't. Also we have complaints about Mario Van Peebles Jamaican accent, again its not that bad. 
The movie itself is not great but its certainly not as bad as some people want it to be. 
It may be the weakest of the franchise but not by much, what it is not is a carbon copy of the first two movies which seems to be what some people wanted for four times over.
Most of the reviews on here are exaggerated at how bad this movie is, some people obviously havent seen a truly bad movie. This has a decent story line, decent effects, decent acting and some gory deaths. What else do you want in a shark movie?

reviews.review_title: One of the most inept theatrical releases of the 80s.
reviews.content:
Lorraine Gary, whose husband is one of the head honchos at Universal Pictures (the company behind the entire JAWS series), reprises her pretty useless and uninteresting role from the first two films in this ridiculous, contrived and shockingly inept conclusion to the JAWS saga.
Gary plays Ellen Brody, the recently widowed wife of the late Sheriff Brody who believes that the great white from the original (yeah, the same one that was blown into a zillion pieces) is after her and her two sons. After one son is picked off near Martha's Vineyard, she and her surviving son (Lance Guest) flee to the Bahamas to escape, but the clever (and apparently, psychic) shark follows. Everything leads up to an unbelievable finale of the selfless Ms. Brody taking a solo trip out to sea to sacrifice herself so all the killing will stop!Michael Caine (!) is wasted in a romantic subplot as a pilot (in fact he skipped out accepting his Oscar for HANNAH AND HER SISTERS because he was on location filming this).Score: 1 out of 10 (AWFUL!)

Jaws: The Revenge, is ultimately the best Jaws from a viewer's standpoint. It is fantastic.  I love Ellen Brody's dream of being eaten by a shark, and her obvious fear of sharks and them hurting her family is splendid, although one would know this anyway.  This Jaws film finds new and creative ways to work in a shark.

reviews.review_title: I did not think it could get worse then part 3, I was wrong
reviews.content: Jaws Revenge tries to bring back the feelings from the original Jaws by bringing back the original actors and having the son be like his father, but it falls beyond short on every level. First of all, you cant have a proper jaws film without Roy Scheider, that man had passion, fear and bravery that he rippled into every scene. Secondly Jaws Revenge has next to no action. It's beyond boring as you follow the dull life of Mrs. Brody and her son. There is nearly no plot to the film as it drags on about nothing. For some reason almost no one dies in the movie. There is little to no suspense, as the shark barely does anything. Everything Michael does in the film makes no sense. The last part of the film is beyond bad as it literally makes no logical sense. And that scene with them in a pool with a painting as the background while they pretend to be in the ocean?? Cringe! The only pleasant thing about the movie was the filming of the crystal clear green water, the steady camera and the familiar cast. To sum up this movie in one word: Boring.

This movie might sound good at first but looks can be deceiving. This is by far the worst sequel to a good movie I have ever seen.The plot was OK but it was the special effects that made this movie horrible.I mean the shark was like a !%$#*@ puppet, I mean this movie had way worse special effects than the original Jaws and it was made 17 years later. I mean that just should'nt happen in todays film-making society.If this movie did'nt have the Jamaican guy this movie would TOTALLY suck.And even he dies, the guys you want to die like the old lady don't die but the Jamaican guy does I mean what is up with that? I would strongly advise you to not watch this,for it is inappropriate for young children and a dumb "horror" flick to adults.3/10 stars for the Jamacian guy.

By far the worst film. And I'm not just talking about the Jaws films. This is the worst movie I've ever seen. The shark is so fake. And what is with the growling? Sharks don't growl! And the plot is stupid. A shark hunts the Brody family and to get away from it, Mrs. Brody goes to another beach. And how is it a shark can get all the way Caribbean in a few days. And what is with the flashbacks? Was she there when the first shark exploded? Also, a stick through the neck. At least in Jaws 3 they blew it up. Jaws: The Revenge is the worst movie of all time.

reviews.review_title: The series that keeps getting better every movie
reviews.content:
The Jaws series just like Dracula, The Invisible Man, Insidious, Impractical Jokers, The Blair Witch, and Darkness falls is one of those horror movie franchises that keeps getting better and better every time. In this movie Ellen Brody is the protagonist instead of that awful Martin Brody who really brought down the series with his corny, witty humor and stupid ideas. Martin died of a heart attack before this movie due to his fear of sharks like a loser. The movie starts with the shark swimming towards the island with his eyes above water more like a real shark than the other shark scenes in the previous movies. The shark kills Sean Brody first in the beginning in a spectacular, sinister sense, the shark jumps on to his boat and kills him. Then shortly after Ellen freaks out and falls into the water while eating pie and gets eaten by the shark. The rest of the movie Ellen is stuck inside the gut of the shark trying to get out. Eventually Micheal Kaine destroys the shark one day when its swimming around the dock. He blows it up with one shot of a stealth bomber cannon killing the shark and Ellen. He then crashes into a banana tree killing himself and others.What I liked about this movie:Best shark kills
Oscar worthy performance from Micheal Kaine
Great nude shots of Ellen exposing her breasts and buttocks
I love that the shark has JAWS tattooed on its side
Less Richard Dreyfus
Pro LGBTQ

Ok, so it's not an oscar winner, but Jaws: The Revenge is still a great film.  Lorraine Gary as Ellen Brody is what really makes the film.  Her enormous talent is showcased in this movie.  The shark moves a little too mechanical, but that is what makes the film more fun to watch.  I enjoy this instalment of the Jaws series, more than all the others.  The soundtrack is top notch, the cast is superb, the story is well written, and the action is high.  I highly recommend this film.

reviews.review_title: This is what they mean by "so bad it's good".
reviews.content: Holy buckets, this film is definitely in the running for best bad movie of all time. This thing is laugh-out-loud funny in its ineptness. If you tried to make a parody of the Jaws films, you couldn't make anything more effective than Jaws: The Revenge.Even after the debacle that was Jaws 3D, someone at Universal Pictures still thought they could wring a little more money out of the movie-going public by cranking out a fourth Jaws flick. I can only imagine how much hookers and blow was enjoyed before they came with that idea. I can only guess how much more hookers and blow had to be consumed for the studio to go through with it after Roy Scheider turned them down and they had to resort to bringing back Lorraine Gary, who played Scheider's wife in the first two films. The studio executives must have then had to spend a year at the Bunny Ranch and snort the equivalent of the gross domestic product of Columbia to decide that their killer shark movie should have a subplot of middle aged romance.Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) is still living in the island resort town of Amity, years after it was terrorized by two great white sharks. Her husband has been dead for several years after a heart attack (although the film takes great pains to remind us that Roy Scheider used to be the star of these movies), her younger son Sean (Mitchell Anderson) is a town deputy and her older boy Michael (Lance Guest) is a marine biologist living with his wife and young daughter in the Bahamas. After one of the most hilarious shark attacks you'll ever witness, Ellen decides to spend some time with Michael and his family. She flies down to the Bahamasand the shark follows her. Yes, that's right. They don't even bother for a moment to pretend this murderous fish has anything in common with an actual animal. They might as well have put a mask on it like Michael Myers, Jason Vorhees or Leatherface because that's exactly the sort of character it is.In the Bahamas, Ellen gets romanced by a local pilot named Hoagie (Michael Caine). This goes on despite the fact that Lorraine Gary looks almost old enough to be Michael Caine's mother. She was certainly long past her freshness date when she made this movie. Eventually, Ellen, Hoagie, Michael and Michael's black friend Jake (Mario Van Peebles) all end up on a boat trying to kill the shark. That involves them turning a flashlight into some sort of "shark taser" and an explosion that defies every known law of physics.I can honestly say that if the shark had walked up out of the surf on its hind fins, put on a top hat and danced a jig on the beachthat would have been only slightly more ridiculous than what happens in this film. Between Hoagie apparently being able to walk on water, a great white that looks faker than the Landshark from Saturday Night live and a Greg Evigan impersonator whose acting consists of a variety of blank stares, there are more unintentionally funny moments in this movie than you can shake a stick at.If you want to watch something good, stay far away from Jaws: The Revenge. If you and your friends want to watch a bad movie you can make fun of, it doesn't get any worse (and therefore better) than this.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as people say
reviews.content: Ok let's start with the obvious this is the 4th film involving a shark attacking the same characters. It was never going to be anything amazing or Oscar winning. However it's fun. It's a silly shark movie. That's it. If you want something easy going and something you can leave your mind at the door then it's perfect. I've watched this more than some films with higher ratings it's fun silly and enjoyable.

This wouldn't be a movie you can just pop into your DVD or VHS player to watch on a family outing. Nothing really makes since in this installment.Oh a shark goes on a killing spree. He(Or is it a she?)kills Sean Brody(Mitchell Anderson)after the poor lad leans over the boat and trys to get a piece of wood that could possibly float out to sea or to the shore. Now here's the dumb parts. Ellen(Lorraine Gary)is now being stalked by this here shark. He wants to kill her. But Michael Brody(Lance Guest), and his mother have something up there sleeves.Not the best movie in the world.

This franchise just makes no sense. You'd think that after the events of the first two, none of the Brody's would ever want to go near water ever again. But then you have that 3D thing and they're working at Sea World, and here there's some Brody thinking a trip to Barbados would be a good idea. Never mind that some shark kills yet another Brody in one of the opening scenes, to the ocean they go! Are we really supposed to feel sorry for her when she gets into trouble? The great white and his trusty propeller soon find her, and then he kills some people that really have nothing to do with anything. We're led to believe that he's just after the Brody family, but the makers can't kill of any more of them so they just have him eat a couple of nameless characters with zero lines. Exciting times. Michael Caine appears for some reason, and he really just enjoys his free vacation and pads out the running time by playing the standard love interest. He brings in some class, which this movie is just seriously undeserving of. I know it had to be cheaply made, but that's no reason to deliver something this bad.

"Jaws: The Revenge" (1987), all of you know how much I loathe "Jaws 3-D" (1983). That film has a poorly conceived and executed storyline with mediocre special effects. Now, that being said, "Jaws 3-D" is a masterpiece compared to this worthless and retarded pile of filth! "Jaws: The Revenge" has a predictable yet confusing story, the acting is a joke, the special effects are garbage, and the soundtrack is cliched! The plot is, Ellen Brody is now a widow since Martin Brody died of fear between the third and fourth film. Then, after Sean dies from a shark attack a grief-stricken Ellen and she her family move from Amity down to the Bahamas where a great white shark actually follows them, seeking revenge. Yeah, it's every bit as dumb as it sounds. I may not be a fan of any of the "Jaws" movies, but the fact that a Martin Brody is killed off due to fear of fighting a shark is insulting to his character. That's about as lazy as you can get! It was their excuse for him not appearing in this "film". Then, after Ellen tells her family to stay away from the water, they decide to move to the Bahamas and be completely surrounded by water. Finally, to top it all off, the shark actually follows them from the United States to the Bahamas! I honestly couldn't finish typing the storyline aspects without laughing. This is easily, one of the worst plots I have ever heard of in any movie. There is no suspense, no thrills and on top of that, the story is boring! What were the writers thinking?! How does the shark know about the Brody family? Why did they move to the Bahamas where there's even more water than at Amity?! All right, I think I've ranted on about the story long enough. As for the acting, it's nothing short of dreadful, from the whole cast. Not even Michael Caine could save it! Yep, somehow he got bribed to be in this "film". He's the only one who appears to be putting forth some sort of effort with his acting. That being said, effort doesn't always result in a good performance. This is, in my opinion, Michael Caine's worst acting performance out of all his movies! Don't even get me started on the name of his character. His name in this "film" is, Hoagie. I guess Sub, Grinder or Grilled Cheese were already taken? Come on, writers, you seriously couldn't come up with any other name? Like, I don't know, a human name? All of the acting is an embarrassment, but the worst performance comes from Lorraine Gary as Ellen Brody. Her acting is, without a shadow of a doubt, some of the worst I have ever seen in any movie, I'm not kidding. Why did she deserve her own starring role and "film"? No one cared for her character in the other films, including me! Fun-fact, Lorraine Gary was married to the President of Universal Studios at the time. Maybe that had something to do with it? On top of that, her character is so annoying and obnoxious, that I was rooting for the shark to eat her! Really, whenever I saw her precious face show up on the screen, I wanted someone to slap her! Granted, I'm sure that she's a nice person in real-life. But, when she's on the screen, she sucks! All of the acting is terrible. As for the special effects, I have a lot to say about them. However, I'll keep it short, sweet and to the point. They suck! There are very few that are adequate, but the majority of them are trash. The worst special effect is the shark itself. You can see the hinges in it's mouth, the harness holding it up in the air, etc. Plus, are you ready for this? Jaws roars in this "movie". I'm serious, the shark roars! Did elementary school students write this script? Although, to tell you the truth, I think children would've been better screenwriters than the wastes of life who vomited out the screenplay! Sharks don't roar, they cannot roar, it's impossible. They don't have lungs, or vocal cords. At this point, an unborn fetus is probably smarter than these incompetent writers! The special effects are nothing short of a joke. There are endless logical errors and flaws that are so bad, that you can't help but laugh. In one scene, Michael Caine's character swims in the water and as soon as he climbs into the boat, his shirt is completely dried. I'm not joking with you. When I first saw that part, I actually shouted: "What?!" But, I immediately burst into laughter just as fast as I yelled, if not faster! That's barely scratching the surface as far as how bad the special effects were. Some of them were so horrible, that I said to myself: "was the budget $100.00, and $99 dollars went to the actors' salaries?!" Finally, the soundtrack is a disaster. It's about as generic and cliched as you can get. There is nothing redeemable in this film score at all! Now, let's get to the only good element in this piece of garbage, the sets/locations. They give a good atmosphere, but that one positive is just simply outweighed by the negatives. "Jaws: The Revenge" is easily one of the worst films I have ever seen. The only thing that keeps it off my top ten worst movies list, is the fact that it makes me laugh and that it actually merits a one-star rating. That being said, for a film to qualify for my top ten worst movies list, it has to have zero stars. For some reason, this "film" manages to salvage one out of me. It's a miracle! Even then, I'm struggling to give this "movie" 1 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 2 out of 10 IMDB stars. For the sake of your decency and intelligence, stay away from "Jaws: The Revenge". Thankfully, it's the last one in this apparent franchise. I'm actually embarrassed for it. Although, this film isn't even worth being embarrassed for at all! All of the "Jaws" movies are a total waste of time, especially "Jaws: The Revenge". Everyone involved with this worthless "movie" deserves to be eaten by sharks!

Perhaps the title refers to the revenge taken on anyone who said that the earlier Jaws sequels were bad.  This is quite the most monumentally massive mistake in movie history.  Even more so than Batman and Robin this film raises the question, 'which studio executive heard the pitch/script and said "hmmm, sounds promising.  Here's a budget - go make me movie..."?  Alan Smithee wouldn't put his name near this nonsense.This film was made 12 years after the original but has positively the worst effects of all 4 films. The Jaws 3 model was bad enough but this thing is barely a shark.  The fact that the shark has a gaping hole in it's belly means that the camera views are highly restricted and every time it jumps out of the water (which is nearly every appearance) it seems to pivot on its tail.  During the banana boat scene it looks as if its floating on the surface it's so far out of the water.For a 'scary' film, its death count is even worse than its predecessor (2 or 3 depending which ending is used).  Basically everything about this film sucks.  There's too much time wasted on land (there seems to be more emphasis on Ellen and Hogie's romance than on the shark), a ridiculous plot (Great White swimming to the Bahamas on personal vendetta) and, in the end, absolutely no feature worthy of anything other than ridicule.Give a ten year-old a video camera, a rubber shark and some ketchup and you'd have a more effective film than this.Maybe one day, a good script will be written and, with the aid of CG effects, the Jaws series will be put back on track. Perhaps the title 'Jaws 4' could be used just to wipe out all evidence of this.
Ok so it's a bit daft in places, but it's a good film. Good story. Along the same lines as 1 and 2 and miles better than 3. A good romp, very entertaining 👍
All the suspense is ruined by the fake looking shark and bad editing. The only good thing is the music from the original movie.

This is hard to put into words how terrible this film is. The acting is awful, the story is tripe, the effects are a joke and this film just makes a complete mockery of the first 2 films. Jaws 3 was trash as well. No wonder Roy Scheider didnt act in this movie, Michael Caine did, and I bet hes been regretting that decision ever since.You can see the actual machinery in the shark which the editor of director of the film obviously either couldnt be bothered or didnt have the talent to spot. A massive gaping hole with pullys and levers can be visibly seen as the 'shark' is chasing Brodys son into that ship wreck. Also, when did sharks grin?, the state of the sharks mouth is a joke, not to mention the roar of it, near the end of the film. I thought it was going to turn green and into the incredible hulk it roared that loud!.If they would have made this movie into a comedy then it would have been plausible and acceptable. Surely they cannot possibly expect a half intelligent audience to take this criminal film seriously??!!.Jaws for me, is only 2 films long. Jaws 2 was okay, mainly because Roy Scheider in it (not that I think much of him in Seaquest), the original Jaws was sheer genius. Fantastic film.Avoid Rubber Jaws:The Revenge, at all costs, except if you are feeling depressed and could do with a good laugh.Rating 0.5/10

reviews.review_title: VERY GOOD if you use your SUSPENSION OF DISBELIEF
reviews.content: This film is NOT as bad as you are all saying. You are all simply agreeing for the sake of agreeing. Sharks DO roar in South Africa - ACTUALLY. So that's shut you critics up. The plot is INTERESTING and ENTERTAINING, even if far-fetched. You are ALL MISSING THE POINT.Nobody set out to make a Biological documentary on sharks. This is a FICTIONAL piece. Hence, it does not have to make perfect sense all the time. So when you losers criticise the fact that JAWS swam from New York to Bahamas in days, take heed to my aforesaid point. This is ENTERTAINMENT. NOT INTENDED TO BE FACTUAL. Get over it you saddos. Utilise your SUSPENSION OF DISBELIEF (if you know what that is) + you will find the movie highly engaging. This is in fact my favourite of all the JAWS sequels. The cast is great, especially Lorraine Gary. The Shark does NOT look fake - AT ALL, despite what you may have heard. The banana boat attack is tense and done well.The film works well as it incorporates drama, romance, action + adventure, and comedy into its standard horror/thriller plot. CHECK IT OUT - this movie IS COOL.
This movie is dumb as hell. Do not waste your money and watch this.

My Take: Incredibly awful sequel to the incredibly terrific classic.(This is an extended version of the review I wrote on February 2007)Has it come to this? How did a classic film end up a big rolling turd after a few years time? We all know JAWS: THE REVENGE is bad, but it's made worse by the fact that it was a spawn of a masterpiece. It's hard to mention Steven Spielberg's JAWS right next to this awful insult of a sequel, even for simple sequel-sake. This is just bad. I liked watching the original "Jaws", the first two sequels were fine, but when it comes to "Jaws:The Revenge", things change. This film is obviously trying so hard to be, not like to be, the original. The film tries to turn Lorraine Gary as a fighter, turning her into something like Sigourney Weaver in 'Aliens", which is simply silly. She obviously allowed herself to be sucked into the role, and she even tries hard to be Ellen Brody's Husband Martin, like saying his lines before shooting the shark("Smile you son of a B#@*h!!!").The plot involves Ellen Brody's (Gary) attempt to avenge the death of her son's death. Fair enough, only director Joseph Sargent wants us to suck in as much lame-brained silliness and pass them up as willing suspension-of-disbelief. Just how much stupidity can this viewer take while watching this film? Well, once the real plot unfolds, I'm already losing track of the numerous moments of stupidity. I think I just found a film that reaches new heights of incompetence. Camp is probably one reason to see this, but as yourself: Do you really want to spend money of something you desperately want to laugh at but have to endure 89 minutes (that's long enough!) of tedium and insulting stupidity? Funny, in one scene, Mario van Peebles' (in a ridiculous Jamaican accent) says to some of the characters "If mediocrity were fat, you'd all be whales!". It's easy to say this to anyone involved in this mess. Rating: * out of 5.

reviews.review_title: The worst mainstream film ever made.
reviews.content: Why do they keep showing this film on that AMC channel? Who could possibly consider this a classic? The film is so bad that this is my second time pummeling it with an angry review.Jaws: The Revenge is in fact the worst mainstream film I have ever seen, and I've seen 'em all. The cast is good enough but completely wasted by an awful script, bad direction, and anything else that can make a movie bad.The story centers around a great white shark apparently seeking the Brody family out to get some revenge for all the others which have died in these films. Maybe it's just some kind of ghost that continues to haunt the Brodys. Anyway the films begins with some murky shots of the bottom of the harbor near the coastal resort town where the family has always lived. The camera work is nothing special, then the audience is hit over the head with some laughably unintelligible narration about fate and whatnot.The first shark attack claims young Sean Brody who is following in his late father's footsteps as a local cop. The grief-stricken mother then heads to the Bahamas to spend the Xmas holiday with her other son Mike and his family. You see, great whites don't like warm water, and there has never been one seen there before! So naturally, our shark would not dream of turning up to spoil their Xmas, would it? The film is terrible in many, many ways. Let's look at some of them...The shark is poorly constructed, and looks very fake. At times you can see the mechanical devices holding it up and making it move. The shark seems to float very slowly and almost on its side most of the time. When angry, this shark even has the ability to roar and growl.The editing is seriously flawed, as well. In one scene, Mike Brody and his partner Jake (Mario Van Peebles) are talking about how "the money is gone... the shark's gone... can't track it." That would be fine and dandy if only for the fact that these two clowns don't even see the shark for the first time until the NEXT SCENE!!!! What the hell?? How could have this slipped past the editor? The dialog is putrid and forced. Mario Van Peebles ad-libbed all of his lines, and it shows. Nobody has anything either important or interesting to say about anything. Even Michael Caine is hard to stand, and he has always been a very likable actor.The film has very little action. Huge gaps of dead spots buffer the shark attacks. There are flashback sequences had by people who were never there to see the incidents take place. The final showdown between Mrs. Brody and the shark is ridiculous from any standpoint. It defies logic, physics, and common sense all at once.What do you suppose the studio bosses at Universal said after they first saw this stinker? What could you say? This film has been criticized by everyone under the sun for the past 18 years, and deservedly so. It truly is the worst film ever released by a major studio.a very generous 1 of 10 stars from the Hound.

reviews.review_title: A movie sequel with real bite!
reviews.content: Why is it that co-called 'movie critics' always seem to hate sequels? I bet half the time they don't even bother to watch the movie themselves. If anyone had actually bothered to to watch Jaws 4 they'd soon realise that it's a great movie. Forget the first three movies in the series (I can't remember what they were called, but don't bother looking them up - it ain't worth it) this is the one to watch. It's got a great cast, a great script and a great villain. Some people complain about the low body-count in this movie. Well, I say if you want a high body-count go and hire out some 'dumb-a**' action movie like 'Cross of Iron'. Plenty of people die in that movie. What you get with Jaws 4 is a serious attempt to get inside the mind of Great White Shark. As it says on the movie's tag line "This time... it's personal". And it certainly is as the shark seeks to avenge the deaths of the other sharks in the previous movies by swimming off to the Bahamas in an attempt to eat Lorraine Gary (she's the wife of the guy in the first two movies). And who can blame it? Sharks always seem to be cast as bad guys in the movies (just look at all those James Bond movies - the bad guy always seems to keep killer sharks as pets). People seem to forget that the sharks were there first, no wonder they get a bit annoyed when idiots in boats keep chasing them, and anyhow they're only trying to get something to eat. How would you like it every time you went into Burger King for a Big Whopper you got some guy chasing you with a harpoon gun? Also, some people complain that the shark isn't very realistic, that its rubber teeth can sometimes be seen bending - well you'd hardly expect them to use a real shark!It's also great to see a major Hollywood movie with a 'mature' woman leading the cast, not some 20 year old bimbo with silicon implants. Maybe that's what a lot of the critics didn't like - a strong, intelligent middle-aged woman.
Quite possibly the worst movie ever.Who thought this was a good idea???

reviews.review_title: Ladies and Gentlemen , The worst movie ever made
reviews.content: Leave poor old Ed Wood alone, at least he respected film. Jaws the Revenge is a sin of nature, a film made only to make money. Jaws is one of the best films ever made, it was popular beyond belief and sadly the rule of sequels applied. Jaws 2 and 3 were so-so but 4 makes them look like masterpieces.The problem with Jaws is it's screenplay. It doesn't treat the movie goer with any dignity whatsoever. Even the lowest of the lowest of stupid movie goers couldn't take this trash seriously. Revenge tries to give it's shark a murderous personality. A rubber shark that looks less real than the ride at Universal Studios is supposed to invoke fear in us. Not only is this shark super intelligent, it can live in areas where Great Whites can't inhabit and it won't eat anyone who isn't in the Brody family tree. Yes this time it is personal but we really don't know who Jaws is having revenge on, the Brody family or the audience.You gotta love Michael Caine as Hoagie Newcombe(Where we high the day we named this character?) At least Caine is smart enough to admit he was only in it for the money because I couldn't believe any other reason.
