reviews.review_title: a bad movie, but still WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAY better than "Cruel Jaws"
reviews.content: well, everyone knows Jaws the Revenge sucks. I myself, am a die hard Jaws fan and i'm admitting it. JTR sucks. but what we're forgetting is, did JTR really deserve all the Razzies it was nominated for? in my opinion, no, it didn't. the only nominations/wins it should've received should've been 'WORST SPECIAL EFFECTS' (which it won) and 'WORST EDITOR'. the editor of this movie obviously did a poor job. the little 1/2 a second clips featuring the mechanics and hydraulics that operate the shark, SHOULD HAVE BEEN CUT OUT OF THE FILM COMPLETELY!!! this film has been on the bottom 100 for quite a while now, and i respect that. i think the really dumb thing about the film is it's climax. it is the most confusing scene i've ever seen in a film. First off, sharks cannot stand out of the water for two resons. 1-They're bodies are too bulky and huge and can't be able to balance themselves on their tales. 2-If they do manage to balance themselves, how will they be able to breathe? it's gills were flaring, but i didn't see any water on them!! also, the shark roars. this mistake was also made in jaws 3, but jaws 3 was actually better than this...thing. also, what i said earlier about the shark platform visible in some scenes? the other 3 jaws films succeeded in keeping the platform and machines invisible (except in jaws 3, but you can barely see it because its so dark underwater, and it's for an extremely short time). also, there's no jump scene. in the other 3, there were 3 corpses popping up here and there (ben gardner from J1, the boat driver from J2, and overman from J3). in JTR, there is no gross-scary-corpse part so that just takes away all the suspense. another thing JTR failed, was originality. If you think this film has an "original story", see the 1977 Jaws rip-off "Orca". On the film's poster it says "Orca is the ONLY creature who seeks revenge other than man" (i can't believe the creators of JTR missed that) and that the plot of JTR is strangely similar to ORCA, about a sea creature filled with rage and kills people for revenge. another bad thing about JTR is it's location. i'm not saying it shouldn't been set in the bahamas, the bahamas are beautiful, wonderful place. but great whites (as said in the film) can't survive in the water surrounding the bahamas. also, the wtaers in the bahamas are very clear blue. in the scene where they try to attach a transmitter to the shark, we see that the shark sticks out like a sore thumb in the ocean. when it dives underwater, and they lose sight of it, i just laughed. they're on a boat, in the middle of the most crystal clear ocean in the world. i don't know about you, but if a huge clunky, rubber, 27 foot long mechanical shark was in the water surrounding me, i'd notice it from a mile away. how the guys on the boat lose sight of it so easily and instantly, i have absolutely no idea. this brings me to m next point. the death/attack scenes. this film has the lowest death/attack count in the whole series. J1 hd about 5 deaths i think. J2 had i think 7. J3 had the highest if you count the 5 or 6 people killed by the shark plus the 7 or 8 people injured when the shark tore apart the dock. in JTR, there are only 3 attacks (two deaths, one injury). Sean's death was pretty awful. Aside from being graphic, when my sister saw that scene with me, she cried because she loved his "adorable" character from J1 and J2. also, the fact that this guy is getting torn apart by a giant shark while carolers from a distant away are singing "hark the herald angels sing", is pretty damn disturbing. the woman's death on the banana boat finally came just when the film had gotten really boring, so YAY!!!!! lol. when jake was attacked, i stood there with my mouth open, with a "WTF" expression on my face. i got over the fact that his character was attcked, but then at the very end, he turns out alive after getting his ass bitten off (literally). now THAT was dumb.now, as i'm saying this, i wonder, "Why did the creators of 'Cruel Jaws' decide to rip off scenes from the other 3 films in the series and 2 other shark movies, but not JTR?". well, let me answer my own question. that would mean featuring scenes from a BAD movie, and the creators of CJ did their best to make their movie "good"3/10

reviews.review_title: Unexciting, though a definite improvement on "Jaws 3-D"
reviews.content: While hardly bursting with excitement, and burdened by a particularly weak finale, "Jaws The Revenge" is at least well-photographed, mostly in the Bahamas, and has a sincere performance by Lorraine Gary (contrary to the urban legend, the movie never confirms - or denies - her belief that there is a great white shark targeting specifically her family), and an enjoyable turn by Michael Caine (yes he's in it for the paycheck but he's having fun with it). Nowhere near the level of Jaws 1 & 2 (it short-changes the audience in terms of actual shark attacks), but even if only for the scenery quite easily preferable to the dreary "Jaws 3-D". ** out of 4.

Certainly not the worst movie I've ever seen, but might be the most annoying. All of the characters are irritating and unlikeable. The little girl is probably the worst, she just whines and complains the whole time. Ugh! Enough already. Who on earth would write a script like that? Where everything everyone says and does is dumb and annoying?

This film really did have potential. I mean, (most of) the Brody family is back, it's set back in Amity Island (instead of boring Sea World), and we get to see some familiar locations. Unfortunately, the potential flies out the window right when you pop this movie into your DVD player. The film score is great, but that's all there is to worship about the movie.I may be wrong on this one, but wasn't Amity Island the Brody family's summer film? What the hell are they doing living in it in winter? Oh well, maybe since Martin's death, they couldn't pay for two homes. And speaking of Martin, I have to admit, the picture of him in the police office is pretty clever. He was supposed to be the one who dies, but Roy turned the role down. Instead, we get Sean, an interesting character, who dies. How sad. And is it me, or can you feel that Ellen is talking about Martin when she says "It's waited all this time and it came for him" and other phrases concerning Sean's death? Anyways, this movie has moments of bi-polar disorder, like when Ellen comes downstairs and is about to cook dinner, a bunch of pots fall and she's in an upset mood, saying "I want you to get out of the water!" and when Jake is yelling at Mike, he randomly stops and says "Sorry about your brother, man!" The shark was always a great part of the Jaws series. In Jaws 1 and 2, the shark was always memorable; in Jaws 3-D, the shark is pretty damn forgettable, since she's barely in it. It's all about boring humans. But in this one, it's shameless. It's pretty unforgettable, but for the wrong reason: The shark always has a "DURRRRR!" expression on it's face. It's always open-mouthed whenever you see it. I guess it has problems. Is that why it just randomly blows up when Ellen's boat hits it? Which reminds me, the ending fiasco is a real pain. The original ending was awesome! Sure, the shark looked like a dinosaur in some scenes and it looked a bit CGI in the scene where Ellen's boat tip hits it, but it still looked cool. It was spitting blood and everything. So after an unsettling feeling by the test audience, what happens? The ending is changed to a one that looks completely fake and makes no sense. So, Ellen's boat tip stabs the shark and it blows up for some reason. If you pause at the moment before it blows up, you can see how phony it looks. It looks like it was shot in a bathtub. The original ending at least made sense. The shark was stabbed and slowly fell down to it's death after the injury. In here, it's just... BOOM! When I was a kid I though the "bathtub" ending looked cool, but now... It looks stupid.The flashbacks are like the flashbacks in D3: The Mighty Ducks, it just makes us wish we were watching the movie (or in D3's case, MOVIES) in which the clips were taking from. That also doesn't make sense. Ellen is the one having these flashbacks, specifically the scenes where Martin shoots the shark and where he bonds with Sean at dinner. She clearly wasn't there in those scenes, but yet she's having them.The dream sequence is pretty non-sensical, as well. Ellen has a dream where she's swimming in the Bahamas, and the shark eats her. She doesn't like the water, so why would she be having a dream like this? Overall, this movie doesn't get me enraged like other things, but it's a mess. It's along the lines of "so bad, it's good" at moments.Also, great touch on not doing the cliché of having the black guy die! That's a movie cliché that EVERYONE likes to point out and say that every film does it.

reviews.review_title: A really terrible shark film with a few bright spots within
reviews.content: After the death of her son, a woman decides to go visit her other son in the Bahamas where everyone comes to believe that the killer shark that killed their family has arrived and is stalking the area forcing them to race to stop it from attacking the rest of the community.There isn't a whole lot to like in this one. One of the few bright spots here is the action sequences when they occur as the few attacks the shark has aren't all that bad. The opening attack, where a victim is savagely ripped up and bitten savagely before being pulled underwater, is quite stunning and really shocking as it sets a great opening for the film, a later attack on a crowded beach where a victim is snagged off a marine toy in front of a small group of kids is really a great sequence for its cruelty and viciousness than anything else and the chase sequence in the sunken galleon does have an air of suspense as the shark does manage to constantly get at the victim after every possible method is used to put distance between them. Beyond these, though, there wasn't much to really like about it as there's a lot to really dislike in this one. The utmost flaw is that the film has the most unbelievable and nonsensical plots ever. Beyond the fact that sharks are incapable of living in the location chosen, the fact that it manages to get to there in a short amount of time is very hard to believe. There's also the family history of the sharks that the film brings up. Using the film, the shark is in fact the first film's third-cousin twice removed, and would have no motive to carry out the vengeance issued. That's assuming that the connection is correct, and if it isn't, then it's even more off in terms of where the shark falls in the family circle. The other big mistake in the film, beyond trying to figure out where the shark comes from, is the very slow pacing involved. Scenes drag on for far too long or have no reason to be there other than padding out the length. The biggest one is the family quarrels about being in the water, which was done nicely enough at first but then it happens twice in a half-hour span, and nothing comes of them since they all go into the water afterward. The struggling marriage scenes have no bearing on the plot and seem needlessly thrown in as well. There's a couple of other big problems in the film, the biggest of which is that the film feels really flat. In fact, the film flat out ignores all opportunities to create tension or fear. Just about all the attack scenes seem perfunctorily rushed and no effort is whatsoever made to make them frightening or even suspenseful. The ending, which should've been a big rousing affair to finish off the shark once and for all, plays out really flatly and the stupidity found within has a lot to do with that. Finally, the shark does look really fake, and there's really no scenes where it looks the slightest real. It simply floats along with minimal movement, being even more distracting. This really wasn't all that great.Rated PG-13: Violence, Language and children in danger.

reviews.review_title: How do you even begin to describe it!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?
reviews.content: Jaws the Revenge, is quite possibly the worst film ever made. The shark is fake, the acting is terrible, and it has the worst ending of any film. There is a line Lorraine Gary says that is just... Embarrassing. The entire film only contains 2 deaths, and the child in it is a little brat. PLUS, the ending has footage from the original of the sharks corpse floating to the bottom of the sea, Lorraine Gary has flashbacks, to things which she didn't even see, and if you look really closely at the banana boat scene, one of the sharks teeth falls out.The whole concept of a shark hunting a family is just pathetic! Plus, Mario van Peebles is attacked on screen, where he is ripped in half. He then appears at the end of the film, intact and swimming. Micheal Caine was swallowed by the shark, which you can briefly see, and then appears climbing onto the boat afterwards, complaining that the sharks breath smelled bad. The shark had previously eaten his airplane as well, which is the stupidest thing I have ever seen in a film.The B story, of the romance between Gary and Caine, is just pointless. Just another thing to laugh at. Many scenes in this film are just to bad to describe in writing. The plot, acting, script, special effects and everything is just terrible in this film. Someone needs to make a 5th, and make it the best film ever made, just so everyone can forget about this awful movie.it's ashame I watched this movie, as I am a bit of a Jaws Fanatic.

Second sequel to the 1975 blockbuster jaws, as the movie ignores the events of jaws 3, the plot in this movie is beyond stupid , the idea wouldnt even make it on an episode of the twilight zone , a great white shark following a potential victim from new jersey to the bahamas ???? Please!!! a vengeful telekenetic shark ??? uh, how did the writers dream this rubbish up? its unbelievable the film ruins the legacy of the original and pulls the curtains on the entire franchise, the producers should have left the brody family out of this production and take the franchise in another direction , which was already tired by the end of jaws 2 , some missed opportunities because the writers chose to leave the same characters in a long drawn out story which was barely believable by jaws 2 but jaws the revenge has no excuse they could have come up with something better than this drivel, apart from a good music score and a poignant scene mirroring a scene from the original , this is definately ONE of the worst films of all time !

okay, i was wrong. My previous review was a little too harsh. This movie can be quite enjoyable, on 3 conditions:you have to be a fan of bad movies;not think about anything that happens in the movie; ...and, let's face it, you have to be a little drunk.Enjoy!

that's what this movie is. Acting is awful from everyone involved. Lorraine Gary looks pathetic as grandma heroine. Shark looks faker than ever. That Michael guy with his jamaican friend isn't too bad. Michael Caine is totally spoiled. The ending is the worst part, the shark just gets poked by a stick and blows up, along with the whole ship. Pathetic. Director Joe Sargent tries to cheer us up with some footage from the original movie. He must've realised he screwed the movie up totally by the time he shows us Martin Brody shooting the shark. I mean, how much lower can you sink as a director?

The tagline for Jaws: The Revenge states, "this time it's personal." Really? I thought it was already personal after the second Jaws film was made and another shark attacked poor Amity Island again. If Jaws: The Revenge should be seen as anything personal it should be viewed as a personal attack - better yet, an assault - on a tremendous horror film that capitalized off of suspense and editing.I should've reviewed Jaws: The Revenge three weeks ago, but I've been putting it off because I've needed to review other films since then. And also, what can be said about Jaws: The Revenge that hasn't already been reiterated and restated time and time again? The film is a dreary slog that consists of waiting for suspense and atmosphere to build, waiting for the shark to appear, being disgusted when the shark finally does appear, and then finally being greeted with the end credits, concluding the mess we just witnessed. If you still want to classify the film as a horror film, even though I'd argue the series thrust its way into the action genre after the second film, then this is one of the worst, most redundant horror films I have yet to see.The film stars Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary), whose husband Martin from previous films has died of a heart attack, which is believed to be brought on from the stress of dealing with sharks in Amity Island. Ellen now lives with her son Sean (Mitchell Anderson), who is sheriff deputy, and his fiancée Tiffany (Mary Smith). Despite normality seemingly coming back for the gang, Ellen is convinced she is being followed by a great white shark when she vacations to the Bahamas to visit her eldest son Michael (Lance Guest). Now it's a matter of killing another shark before the shark can kill them.It's no wonder Steven Spielberg had no interest in pursuing a sequel to his original Jaws film and had no involvement with any of the three sequels. I imagine he recognized that a "man vs. shark" is only really fresh the first time around and that doing the same thing film after film would begin to become monotonous and painfully familiar. Even if Jaws: The Revenge wasn't plagued with such lame acting, terrible effects work, and collectively sterile camera-work, it would be hard to convince us that a fourth movie about a group of people going after another shark would be something worth paying to see.I recall when I watched Jaws 3 and got so tired with the characters and the plot that I just wanted to see a shark attack. Then I saw how painfully cheap and ridiculous the shark looked and kind of wanted more exposition. Then when I received more exposition I kind of just wanted the entire thing to end. The film was a muchness. Jaws: The Revenge suffers from the same form of monotony. One is constantly waiting for something to happen, then upon being rewarded, they wish they had never seen such a thing. For the purists who complain that the shark was clearly artificial in the original Jaws, I'd love to see how they responded to the shark in Jaws: The Revenge. I doubt there's enough howling in the world that could do justice to its artificiality and stunning banality.Thus concludes the Jaws franchise for now, thankfully. This is one of the few franchises I know of (next to the contemporary Paranormal Activity series) that failed to have another "good" film after its first film, which, in both series' cases, was phenomenal. One should take the hint how in conversations about the original Jaws, rarely do the sequel names come up, and by God is that for the better.Starring: Lorraine Gray, Mitchell Anderson, Mary Smith, and Lance Guest. Directed by: Joseph Sargent.

This is the third and final sequel of the original Jaws, where Chief Brody's widow, Ellen, decides that she has had enough of Amity and heads off to the Caribbean to join her son Michael, daughter-in-law Carla and granddaughter Thea. However, the Great-White Shark shows up again, taking younger son Sean's life and causing uneasiness to Ellen. Therefore, she wages a personal revenge mission against the shark that has caused her and her family so much grief.The plot sounds pretty interesting but, to sum it all up in a few words, this movie is pretty boring. It is basically just mediocre drama with sub-par acting, showing the characters preaching endlessly about their livelihoods and plans on what to do with the shark, which appears in a few scenes only. There is really not much shark action or suspense until the climax of the film. Overall, it's the worst off of the Jaws movies and one you can definitely stay out of the water.Grade D--

I hate it when people have to put down such a good movie, thinking it sucks! Well, it's not at all a bad movie! It has really good story, fine dialogue, cool characters, and stunning cinematography. However, the shark did act a little flimsy on screen, it looks like broken robot. And there are mistakes if you watch closely. And sharks don't roar, but it was the director's choice to make the shark roar, to emphasize its monstrosity. I thought the actors who play the characters are really good at acting and make the movie worth being seriously taken. So I would recommend this movie to anyone who likes sequels, rather than those Jaws fanboys. But I hope people enjoy this film!

reviews.review_title: At least its better than Jaws 3 and a masterpiece compared with Shark In Venice!
reviews.content: OK OK...Sharks don't take things personally. Sharks don't roar etc. BUT Sharks don't like eating humans so in the first hand Peter Benchley's best selling novel is not based on accurate facts. What i am trying to say? Movies are fiction hello? So ANYTHING can happen. I admit that the shark's personal quest for revenge is stupid even for a fictional movie universe, but at least makes the movie work because Jaws 3 was a total mess, and in my opinion is even worse than Jaws 4.Now lets think about it. After the first movie (a true cinema masterpiece) everyone got the "jawsmania" and wanted to go to the theaters and watch the shark eating his victims. So the shark became the driving force behind the whole franchise (even they never planned to make it one). Bottom line we all watched the sequels for the shark and the shark delivers big time in this one. This movie its mindless fun and full of carnage.In conclusion. The producers wanted the Brodys in the film, (this family with sharks is like John Mclane with terrorists), they had the shark and they needed to find a way to make the Brodys get in a situation against a shark again. Someone said to make it personal, and the others agreed! So what? At least is not Shark In Venice!. Sure the movie could been better but it's entertaining and a fun movie to watch with a couple of beers.

reviews.review_title: "I have an irresistible urge to kiss you, Ellen Brody."
reviews.content: I went to the doctors the other day with severe stomach pains. He gave me some pills. When I got home, I had an incredible urge to use the toilet.Sitting on the toilet, I let rip and the diarrhoea flowed. I heard a loud thud in the toilet. Looking inside the toilet, I realised that I had excreted a copy of Jaws: The Revenge. No wonder I was in pain.Days passed and I was still in agony. Running to the toilet, I released my bowels again. THUD! There it was again. Another copy of Jaws: The Revenge.I began to realise then that this movie really was full of shiit.

Jaws: The Revenge is a masterpiece. A masterpiece of crap! This is a horrible movie. Jaws: The Revenge is a tad bit better than Jaws 3-D. I never saw Jaws 3 in 3-D but it probably stunk just as bad as regular. Here are a couple of reasons why this is a BAD movie. 1.The shark looks like it's already dead. 2.This movie is cheesy. 3.This movie is boring. 4.How did the guy survive after he already sunk? 5.The Jaws series hasn't been good since the original. I never saw Jaws 2, but I know that it's better than this crap! I give Jaws: The Revenge a 3 out of 10! Only thing good is the way the shark dies, and that's still stupid! This is horrible. This was made for the money. This is a joke. What is this? It's just a horrible movie. I can't stop hating! Arrrrhgh!

reviews.review_title: One of the worst films ever/ Shark looks fake
reviews.content: Not only the worst film in the series, but one of the worst films ever made. You would think after three previous efforts they would at least make the shark look real. I used to play with a toy shark that looked more real.

This film should have been called Eminem the Revenge, it stars Lorraine Gary as Ellen Brody as the wife of the late police officer's chief as she tries to get over the death of her son and fight against a Great White Shark who has followed her and her Family in the Bahamas, Michael caine is wasted looking after an Academy Award, Karen Young is terrible and her character screams THEA! THEA!, Mario Van Peebles has a bad Jamaican Accent and the rest of the cast is boring. Why not cast the Silm Shady as a great white shark and get revenge against the Brody family, not the shark, because it's fake. Movie Review Zero Stars.

reviews.review_title: Hey, Jaws, spit your guts out!
reviews.content: What the hell happened in this series? I know that after Steven Spielberg and his magic wand of the original film left for better projects, the "Jaws" saga started falling down the cliff where each sequel gets worse by the number. Jaws 3-D? What the hell was that? The special effects were so faked that I bet those who saw that film just walked out when the special glasses didn't work. Why do we need more sequels to films that should've been left alone in the first place? Somehow there's a disease with the Brody family where sharks just keep to be coming by the numbers and bothering this poor family. Roy Schinder is not in this sequel but is seen through flashbacks from his wife (Lorraine Gray in her final film) after the family's young son Sean (Mitchell Anderson) gets his arm ripped off before being devoured by a new menacing shark. The remaining son Michael (Lance Guest) is in Jamaica working in oceans and studying the effects of fish while seeing that his mother comes to visit after the death of Sean where that pesky shark keeps returning. Is there a radar on the Brody family? Other stars include Mario Van Peebles in a Jamaican accent and Michael Caine who skipped his Oscar win for Hannah and her Sisters to do this hunk of junk.AHHHHH!!!!

This was so bad, it was almost unwatchable. It suffers from bad acting, bad dialogue, bad accents, bad effects and sloppy directing. The characters are annoying and the shark attack scenes are laughable. The shark attacks are stocky without any suspense whatsoever, and the shark itself looks like a blow-up doll! The actors stand around like dummies because they don't know what to do. It is just so illogical and unconvincing. The climax is absolutely terrible!! I'd love to know what Steven Spielberg thought of this mess...

This film was well and truly awful. A dumb shark with an attitude goes off to chomp Ellen Brody and her family, instead, it creates a lot of collateral damage. Ludicrous. The actors were pathetic, just like in many other bad movies I have watched and the plot was a diseased, worm-ridden, lame piece of scum that had come out of some godforsaken trashcan. The shark was a failure: it leaped out of the water and roared when the actors sent some weird kind of sound waves at it, and it wanted to pick it's revenge on the Brody gang. Pathetic. Since when have sharks declared blood feuds on human beings??? This is uselessly dumb!!!!! It's a pity the Brodys didn't end up as shark chow at the end of this pastiche of Jaws, it could have earned a five out of ten then. Things I learned from this movie: -Sharks roar under certain circumstances. -Ellen Brody is a psycho. -Sharks declare blood feuds on people but still manage to spare the lives of their intended victims. -Minisubs are a favourite chew toy of sharks. Well, those who wrote and directed this movie are fit for the execution block for all I care. Both thumbs down for Jaws 4.

reviews.review_title: I guess you could say "Jaws" has jumped the shark
reviews.content: "Jaws: The Revenge" isn't just one of the worst movies ever made. It is one of the worst experiences of my entire life. I couldn't even tell that I was even watching a movie. It looked more like some never ending short film made by college students who don't know how to even use a camera. This is notable in being the lowest rated movie that Roger Ebert ever gave zero stars to and it's great that we all agree with him. From beginning to end, this film is an exercise in stupidity. The main character from the first film has died, so there's almost no one from the original film here. He died of a heart attack, but his wife thinks he died from fear about a shark. Wha...? Most of this film is dreadfully boring. There's a bunch of subplots that are never resolved but to be honest, I didn't even notice them. I may have had an even harder time keeping awake watching this movie than "Jaws 3" and that one literally put me to sleep. The special effects in this film are horrendous. The shark looks like some giant puppet plopping around in the ocean and it probably IS a giant puppet plopping around in the ocean. It's simply incredible how with all the new technology that comes in the past twelve years since the original, the effects get worse and worse. There's this one Jamaican guy who's so annoying.When I first heard that guy's voice, I seriously thought there was something wrong with the movie I was watching. I thought I had accidentally turned something else on because it seemed like I was listening to some stupid parody. The best part is that the guy does get attacked in the end. They even manage to mess that up, as he actually survives being bitten and dragged underwater! Brody's wife goes after the shark by driving a boat out by herself with no weapons. What?! How stupid is she?! Was she going to just wrestle the shark to death or something? Was she trying to commit suicide? She just says she did it because she had no other choice. Worst of all, at the end the shark roars and it gets stabbed and literally blows up! How does a shark just get impaled and then blows to pieces?! I had no idea at all what was going on in this stupid movie. Brody's wife has flashbacks to things she wasn't even at. In fact, no living person even witnessed those events! Well, it is kind of implied she has a psychic link with a shark, but that's even dumber! It's the worst sequel of any kind I've seen in my entire life! Zero stars

"Jaws: The Revenge" is the fourth movie of Jaws and this one is the worst movie of all. The plot is about the same with the previous but in this movie we have a shark which attacks the boat of Michael Brody and Jake a friend of Michael.I did not like this movie because it's a movie that none have to watch it. This movie is an insult for the first and best movie "Jaws". I also did not like the interpretation of Mario Van Peebles who played as Jake and Lance Guest who played as Michael Brody. I believe that direction and plot were really horrible and Joseph Sargent did not do his best at this movie.Finally I have to tell you that you really do not have to watch this movie, it's a not worth seeing movie.

When Ellens son Sean Brody is killed by a great white shark, Michael invites her to stay with him in the Bahamas over Christmas. While Michael undergoes work as a Marine Boiologist, he is confronted with the shark who resurfaces once more...I was hoping to see a mass improvement after Jaws 3, but the series got a whole lot worse. Normally sequels ruin the aspect of the original film, but I didn't think it was possible with Jaws. Having a giant shark in the water would surely scare anyone, but the only thing lurking in the water for Jaws the revenge, is a bunch of plastic cogs.There's nothing natural about the shark, it moves too mechanically and even roars, not too mention the indescribable end scene when the shark blows up by getting stabbed by a piece of wood...Its obvious that this film was a desperate attempt to scare us once more by doing everything and anything possible...

The final installment in the dreaded "Jaws" group of films is by-the-numbers all the way. This time Lorraine Gary returns and goes down to the Caribbean to be with older son Lance Guest after younger son Mitchell Anderson is killed in an Amity shark attack. Gary believes that there is a shark that has it out for her and her family while Guest (who is a marine biologist, go figure) thinks she may be losing it mentally. Also along for the ride is fellow scientist Mario Van Peebles (terrible Jamaican accent, dreadlocks and all) and pilot Michael Caine (who missed receiving his Oscar for "Hannah and Her Sisters" because this film went over budget and beyond its shooting date). Just a totally wasteful movie as the turkey finally defeats the shark. Turkey (0 stars out of 5).

You won't find the late great Roy Scheider reprising his famous role as Chief Brody in this installment but his wife Ellen Brody(Lorraine Gary) still lives in the island resort town of Amity, Sean is now a deputy in Amity. during the Christmas season, Sean is called to untangle a log from a buoy, and when Sean goes to the buoy, he's killed by the eponymous great white shark that scene is actually a inspiring sequence that recalls the 'original and best Jaws opening attack scene) Mrs Martin Brody heads to the Bahama's with her family but uh-oh guess who's coming to dinner? believe it or not but the giant fake fish follows and this time it's personal! it's also unbelievable that Sir Michael Caine is in this giant turkey! legend has it's one of his famous roles for 'the money' which apparently has enabled him to build a house from the proceeds!

reviews.review_title: A rather bad but entertaining movie.
reviews.content:
I have seen much worse movies in my life. That said, this isn't a good movie at all! But it is also not that 1* movie many reviewers want to make you believe it is.Acting is mostly believable, if it weren't for the character "Jake". I do accept the character only because he's not taking the whole thing very seriously, which is understandable because:Effects and story are weak! Especially compared to the original jaws movies this one has a very unbelievably bad shark animatronic - which makes the whole movie feel trash-ish.And that's what makes it so hilariously fun. The whole "serious" acting around a bad manufactured robot shark + the nonsense story is quite some fun. I enjoyed it and I think, if you don't take this movie to serious, you might be entertained as well.I personally will never understand 1* rant-ratings. There are movies really worth 1*, this one isn't a 5+ but definitely not as bad as many other horror flicks.
I think jaws 3D had a better story but, due to 3D, worse effects and no real connection to the jaws series. Both are a 3* to me.

Lorraine Gary is very hot for this final fight. She is like Sigourney Weaver on Aliens and Jamie Lee curtis on Halloween. She has to kill the shark for a last time. A lot of action and terror, Lorraine Gary is really a good actress, I like her.

With no expectations and expecting this sequel to be bad, it is quite as expected. After watching Jaws 3 and noticing how bad it was in comparison to the previous Jaws film. Jaws: The Revenge is quite worse.Here the location is set in the Bahamas and features more unlikeable and irritating characters. Giving the wife the lead was a bad decision as her character is far more annoying than the original two films. She came across as too whiny and nagging. Michael Caine comes off across as obnoxious as well and the son Michael Isn't interesting either.The main lowlights include the climax with the shark roaring than exploding for little to no reason. Easily the worst looking and low budget shark of the series. Also very little shark kills in this film (only 2- the lowest deaths of the franchise).Featuring virtually no suspense and thrills, this film is just boring to get through. We also wonder as to how Jake survived in the end after being brutally attacked by the shark and taken underwater for a long period of time. Overall this film was not needed and is as terrible as the low ratings suggest.

A reunion of sorts in this the last Jaws film(for the moment at least). I think it a solid action movie with good enough acting. This installment is no worse than any other save the first of course. Lorraine Gary returns and Michael Caine co-stars,who I believe is one of the better actors in the series. The movie wraps up the franchise well by bringing the family back (minus Scheider) to settle things once and for all(at the moment at least)Jaws is one of the biggest blockbusters with some of the biggest names in directing and acting and Michael Caine is right up there with them. I don't honestly believe this is a 10 star movie but it sure as hell doesn't deserve 3 going by the other installments ratings in this franchise. Hell anyway Mr Caine gave up an appearance at the Oscars and best supporting actor win for this movie.

What I really despise about Jaws 4 is that it completely ignored the events that happened in Part 3 and chronologically set itself up after Part 2. I can't stand that in horror franchises, it's extremely lazy writing! Another aspect of the film that was completely absurd lies within the idea that the great white is out seeking revenge against the Brody family. Lastly, it mentioned that Chief Martin Brody died earlier from a heart attack caused by a great white. What a joke! No wonder why this film is constantly bashed and often seen on worse movie lists. This loss falls squarely on the director and writers.The only redeeming aspect of The Revenge was scoring Michael Caine to be in it and bringing back Lorraine Gary but let's be honest the two of them couldn't save this film. Half the budget for this movie had to go to Caine or he just wanted to vacation in the Bahamas, maybe both. It was odd too seeing these two great cast members having to try and sell these really cheesy bad lines. The beginning of the film had a surprising twist, which is respectable since it took some stones to pull off but it was way too rushed. From there, a lot of flashback scenes were inserted, with laughable dialog and crappy shark effect scenes. The Revenge was a really poor attempt to create a meaningful Jaws movie and solidify the series, it might have ruined it for good.

This is a stupid movie! Irrational, illogical, even more cheesy than Jaws 3-D, and cheap, useless special effects. This is probably the worst of all the Jaws films that never had clear reasoning to exist.

Jaws The Revenge is in terms of the series of films,the last and least. Lorraine Gary is pretty good,and so is Michael Caine.Lance Guest,Karen Young,Mario Van Peebles and Judith Barsi are decent.The opening scene with Sean is  pretty good.Joseph Sargent tries his best,but can't make a silk purse from this sow's ear.The shark looks fake,not enough attacks,the movie is way too short,Caines instant drip dry shirt and the ending are a bit ludicrous,and the music isn;t too good. The novel by Hank Searls was better,leading me to think they had a decent first draft and then somebody messed it all up.Still,there are worse ways to pass the time.Even Cowgirls Get The Blues,for instance. 5 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Recommended only for die hard fans of the "Jaws" series. Or for masochists.
reviews.content: I wonder if Mr. Michael Caine is ashamed of this piece of crap. I have to admit it, when it first came out, I kind of liked it mainly because it featured flashbacks and references to previous "Jaws" movies. Also, I liked Mario Van Peeble's character; I always rooted for Uncle Jake. Also, it was the 80's and "Jaws" needed a final sequel.Sadly, this movie is terrible in every aspect. The plot is beyond bad although it has a decent opening sequence. This scene is underrated in my opinion, but then the movie terribly falls and becomes a mess.The body count is minimal taking in account that these kind of movies need many death scenes. The gore, F/X are very cheap and don't have nothing to do with the original "Jaws". The movie is a disappointment and I can understand why it's on the Bottom 100 on IMDb. What else to say? I would only recommend this movie for die hard fans of the "Jaws" series. If you are not a fan, stay away from this horrible sequel.

reviews.review_title: Such a pain to sit through.
reviews.content: I mean, it's not even enjoyable bad. It's just flat-out ish. It was made on a budget of $23 MILLION but obviously that money was spent on hookers and cocaine in the Bahamas. (And Michael Caine's wardrobe.) Nobody attached to this movie has any idea what a shark is or what it can physically do. Every minute of this movie is being built up to an anti-climatic -- not to mention embarrassing -- sharksplosion. The sheer ludicrousness involved in the so-called plot was mind-numbingly awful. This movie is a toddler's understanding of the original "Jaws".There's literally nothing else I can say that will describe how bad this movie is (though not as bad as the Holocaust). Never ever mention this to me again.

It is the worst Jaws movie out of all of them. The acting is bad, the shark looks SO fake, and it is not nearly as scary as the other 3 Jaws movies. It is dumb to have Sean die at the beginning.  And do you actually think that the shark that killed Sean in the beginning could actually swim down to the Bahamas and kill again?!! I don't think so!! THIS MOVIE IS A BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!!!!!

So this is what a train wreck looks like..."Jaws The Revenge" is the fourth and, not suprisingly, final installment of the famous "Jaws" series.  All right so the series isn't really famous, so much as the first one is.  I haven't seen the middle two, but I don't think that would have helped me comprehend this weird movie any more than I did.Now I understand that movies, especially horror movies, call for the suspension of disbelief.  Skeptics could say I'm jaded, but I disagree.  I do suspend disbelief, to an extent.  When I see a "shark cam" shot, I accept that.  When the shark cam shot is above water and we cut to a wide shot of just the fin sticking out the water, my suspension disappears.  Unless Jaws is a super-shark, he has no eyes on his fin.Then again, maybe he is, given the laughable behavior of this crazed fish in the movie.  The essential plot is that this shark is still on the loose after all these year, even though I'm pretty sure it's been killed at the end of every single movie.  I guess it decided it was tired of being killed by the Brody family (Stars of all the "Jaws" movies), so he decided to start offing Brodies one by one.  The wife of Sheriff Brody, Ellen, is the only one who believes that the shark is out to get her and her family.  Well, you know, it sounds so logical that I cannot imagine why anyone would disbelieve her!I tried to understand this movie, I really did.  But it is so completely devoid of talent and thought that it's impossible not to laugh at its total stupidity.  The fin-cam is just the tip of the iceberg.  Jaws not only can spot his prey well out of the water, and even on boats, but he can nimbly hop out of the water, up to the deck to chomp on his victims before quickly returning to the depths.  And let's not forget Ellen's recollections of scenes she didn't even witness!  The shark is so intent on revenge, that he swims from Long Island to the Bahamas in about two days.  Someone sign that fish up for the Olympics!  And the climactic confrontation with the shark is edited so poorly, I honestly couldn't tell you what happened.  I know the characters lived, but as for Jaws, it's a big bloody mystery to me.While making the first "Jaws," director Steven Spielberg realized his shark didn't look very realistic.  So he intentionally kept it out of sight through the whole movie.  I guess the director here had a little more confidence in his aquatic creation, because you see a lot of the shark in the movie.  Of course, the thing looks as fake as ever, maybe even more so now given the ridiculous situations he is forced into.  The worst detail about the fake shark?  It always, always, has its mouth gaping wide open.  I just felt like I was looking at something someone made in shop class.Again, this movie is dumb and goofy and ridiculous.  If you're looking for a scary movie like the first "Jaws," rent the first "Jaws."  Looking for that here will only cause you great pain and discomfort.  If you're watching to see how NOT to make a movie about a revenge obsessed shark, well, look no further.

I disagree with the masses with this one, because I think Jaws: The Revenge is up there with Jaws and Jaws 2. The story is intriguing, and keeps you wondering what'll happen next. I went into the movie thinking it would be maybe a 3 or 4, which is still better than Jaws 3-D, but WOOOOOO was I wrong! reviews.review_title: Sharks don't jump on boats, or drag helicopters down either...
reviews.content: I'm laughing at people hating this movie, just because it's not realistic enough. The whole point of the Jaws franchise, is showing a shark that is monstrous, evil and completely out of this world. Like plague from the sea, set upon mankind. At least residents of the place that was picked on the map (?). Either way, I'm also of those who can't get past 3-D's atrocious special effects. I like it, it's one I used to watch a lot as a kid. Especially because it took place at Sea World. But « The Revenge » is set in the Bahamas... I mostly blame the chaotic production for its hard to overlook flaws. At one point in the movie, it was like nobody really cared about making a good product, and couldn't wait to finish the film. Saying it was rushed, is an understatement. As scary as the shark is, the way it was shot sometimes, shows how botched post-production was. The special effects during the showdown, were a real insult to viewers who paid good money to see the movie in the theaters, back in late 80s. So for that, I could've understood the outrage. But that's not why people hated the movie. Critics maybe, but not viewers. No, they couldn't get past the fact that the shark roared, when it did in the first movie too. And can't grasp the notion that it might explode, after being given several violent and repetitive jolts. As far as unrealistically big shark goes, it's not a big stretch. Making Helen the heroine, was a questionable choice, I get that. But it could've been worse. And we get to see a Michael closer to the one we left on Jaws 2. Michael Caine was decent, but his character was not very like able. But that was the point, wasn't it? The acting is good overall. And that dreamlike setting was perfect for the theme of the movie. Jaws 2 remains the best sequel, but Jaws (4) has its moments, and looks aesthetically better than Jaws 3-D.

reviews.review_title: This wasn't as bad as many made it out to be.
reviews.content:
Before I begin, I will say that no other Jaws film can live up to the original that remains in a class by itself. Also, Jaws has unfortunately created a destructive stigma regarding great white sharks; thus causing many people to be incapable of separating reality from fiction. Anyhow, let's begin.Was Jaws The Revenge a cinematic masterpiece, absolutely not. Arguably this movie was made following the epic failure of Jaws 3; no disrespect to Dennis Quaid and Louis Gossett, Jr. who carried the film.Nevertheless, (from a narrative standpoint) JTR followed the events of Jaws 2. It involved one of nature's fiercest predators having a bloodline of monster sharks and seeking vengeance against the Brodys nine years later.In addition to Ellen Brody suffering from depression following the death of the youngest son Sean, she decided to leave the horrors of the monster shark attack and Martin's death behind her, and traveled with her oldest son Michael Brody and his family to the Bahamas, only to be revisited by the beast again.Now, I can see what the writer was trying to do, but as a fan of Jaws and a shark lover, I have to say that this was a narrative failure. It can also be argued that the writer piggybacked of the plotline from the movie Orca. Killer Whales are intelligent creatures and only have one mate until death. Sharks on the other hand swim depths exceeding 4,000 feet whenever another shark's blood is spilled. If you don't believe it, Google it.There's no way a great white shark targets specific people as a means of vengeance. In my opinion, the movie would've been fine as Jaws 4 instead of Jaws The Revenge. In fact, it could've been a coincidence that the shark popped up in the Bahamas and began doing what it's known to do. At that point, Ellen, Michael, Jake, and Hoagie could've lured the beast away from the beach, and squared off out in the open aboard the Neptune Folly.To reiterate, this was a narrative failure, but the movie wasn't all that bad. In fact, I couldn't get enough of it growing up. With all the hiccups involved pre and post production, kudos to the late Joseph Sargent who gave it his all while directing this film. I really like the dramatic score by the late Michael Small which undoubtedly lived up to John Williams' original rendition to make it feel like a Jaws movie. I hope to find the theatrical version instead of the recently updated copy; you know, the one with the deleted scene of the backdrop falling apart. 😒
Lastly, if I had to choose between this film and Jaws 3, I'd gladly take that plane to the Bahamas with the Brodys and Hoagie as the pilot any day.

Writer of Poltergeist) has had that happen in those three films I mentioned above. I was amazed that a sequel could be any worse than the stupid and gimmicky Jaws 3, but it was. When this first starts, it seems like it might be an okay film, with interesting camera angles and direction, but it gets worse. The protagonist of this film is Brodie's wife, and she gets really annoying. This movie also houses perhaps the dumbest scene in any movie I have ever seen where the shark comes out of the water and roars. Later we hear the roar in the end credits theme song. reviews.review_title: Michael Caine gets a paid trip to the Caribbean
reviews.content: I read an interview with Michael Caine once on how he selects which films to appear. If I remember right, he one looks that whether the role is different from what he last played and two he looks at where the movie was being filmed. I'm guessing he chose to appear in "Jaws: The Revenge" because of latter for it's warm Caribbean setting. How could there be any pretense that this was going to be a good movie when the poster tag line is, "This time it's personal." How is a shark going to take things personally from the prior three films? And when the shark got killed in all of the prior films, is this film's shark supposed to be the third cousin twice removed coming to get revenge on Chief Brody's wife (the only person from the original film appearing in this fourth installment). There is no reason to watch this film outside of put camp. It's awful and is only watchable when the mechanical shark appears.

I've commented on all the other Jaws films so I thought I might as well comment on this one, the final (we hope) one. This one is even worse than part three and that one was awful. This one is an insult to the viewer and a kick in the teeth to the people that made the original classic Jaws film. A pity Spielberg couldn't have blocked all these Jaws sequels from getting made, I mean there isn't an E.T IV out there is there? Michael Caine despite being a terrific actor is no stranger to bad films but Jaws: The Revenge has to be the worst of the lot, yes even worse than The Swarm. The storyline here is awful, the special effects are dreadful and the actors look like they know they are starring in a pitiful movie. Avoid this movie, watch the original again or even Jaws 2 which is acceptable enough. Jaws 3D and The Revenge should be deleted forever.

This film holds great promise.  The title music and camera-work in the early scenes are eerily effective and the death scene of one the younger of the Brody brothers and the build-up to it are well-handled.  But after that things go downhill and you get the impression you're watching a film which has had all its scarier moments removed by the sensors.  The shark only manages to kill two people, much of the film being taken up by boring family-drama padding.  Michael Caine appears as a pilot, but he's completely wasted in an undemanding and thankless role.The plot of the film is just complete gibberish.  A shark somehow finds out that Mrs Brody, now a widow, and family are off to the Caribbean and follows them, managing to travel halfway across the world faster than an aeroplane. Mrs Brody has flashbacks of things she never even witnessed, the shark roars and seems to be floating above the water in one scene.  The older Brody brother escapes the shark underwater by letting the air out of his oxygen-tanks and rocketing up to the surface, somehow managing to avoid the bends.  And the last ten minutes or so of the film are packed to the gills with characters seemingly coming back to life after inescapable deaths. Surely this kind of thing only belongs in cartoons.Overall, Jaws 4 has a few memorable moments, is certainly better than that terrible 3-D outing, but it's just a might-have-been.

reviews.review_title: RIP .. once was a great film
reviews.content: With so many talented people associated and the mere passage of time since the original, you'd think it would be possible if not to surpass the original in quality, to at least manage to build a more realistic, ergonomic, technologically advanced shark. Not so apparently when you see what this shark does to a banana boat looking more rubbery than a latex muppet and at a reported forty feet (!) giving way to the sheer absurd.Same old story rehashed with Lance Guest now assuming the lead role (taking up where Dennis Quaid left off in 3D), his long suffering mother (played by the original Lorraine Gary, though one wonders why she waited nine years to return for this abomination; perhaps it was the Caribbean location) hell-bent on taking revenge on the most recent predator to rip a limb off her diminishing family tree. And then there's Michael Caine playing a care-free helicopter pilot named "Hoagie". It's a toss-up between this turkey, "The Swarm", "Beyond the Poseidon Adventure" or "Blame it on Rio" as to which is his all time worst effort. Caine dances in this film while romancing Gary, so it's a tight contest.Not an ounce of suspense or even mild shock is created by the director of "The Taking of Pelham 123", Joseph Sargent apparently absent from the director's chair for most of what ended up on the screen. Good to see younger and elder Van Peebles together, even if they have to share the ignominy of it being in this film. There's little to recommend, needless to say if you're a fan of the franchise, then you absolutely must see this to fully appreciate just how good the others are by comparison.

reviews.review_title: If mediocrity were flab, this bloated, blubbery goldfish would be a whale.
reviews.content: In this fourth (although the studio promoted it as being the third film in the "trilogy") and presumably final entry in this once proud series, Bruce the shark has undergone a transformation from great white shark, to a bloated, blubbery goldfish flushed down the toilet bowl years earlier, only to end up as this insultingly stupid, poorly written, blandly directed waste of film, good only for unintentional laughs, and a lot of them. Christmastime setting is the only novelty here, as Ellen Brody, mourning the death of her husband from parts I and II, loses one of her sons in another shark attack. Her other son convinces her to go to the Bahamas with him and his family, to take her mind off everything. That just makes her go even more crazy, and insist the shark has targeted her family as part of some ridiculous voodoo curse. Yes, you read that correctly: a voodoo curse is the reason why her family has been beset by shark attacks. Voodoo curses, revenge, drug smuggling, the return of a little-used supporting character having flashbacks to events that she was not present for, and a large plastic shark (which roars!) are all thrown into this mix, then Puréed in a blender, and thrown onto the screen, in one giant *splat*This is the only Jaws film not written by Carl Gottlieb and Howard Sackler, whether that's good or bad is open to debate. There is a difference between fictional story writing, and insultingly stupid story writing. The makers of this thing thought that the audiences would accept, with perhaps only a minor suspension of disbelief, any story at all, no matter how ridiculous or implausible it is, as long as it has the "Jaws" name attached to it, and as long as someone from the original cast returned. It expects you to not only suspend your disbelief, but also requires you to be dimmer than a one- star restaurant, and pretend to not notice the footage from part I being reused at the ludicrous climax, and not question how characters miraculously return to life after being devoured by the shark. And repeatedly ignore the very obviously visible tracks the shark is "swimming" on. And ignore the support beams used to lift the shark into the air. And ignore an obvious miniature, which explodes for no apparent reason, and does so four times, for the film's quickly reshot alternative ending. And, is that duct tape I see, holding the body of the shark together? Supposedly a twenty million dollars budget for this, and that's the best they could do, duct tape and stock footage? The Jaws theme is used all throughout the opening credit scene, quickly ruins its effectiveness; it is a dramatic piece, not to be used during something as mundane as the opening credits, seemingly just to remind people they are watching a Jaws film. Michael Caine's potential love interest for Lorraine Gray's character is filler material; it goes absolutely nowhere, and his character could be edited out almost completely and his absence would not even be noticed. But the same could probably be said for Gary's character, also. Good shock of the boat suddenly being attacked from underneath in the opening shark attack, one of the few memorable shots. The rest of the film is only good for lots of unintentional laughs, which is why I rated it as highly as I did. If one doesn't include the three or four minutes long opening credits, and the four minutes long closing credits, the film's real run-time drops to about 81/ 82 minutes.

...unfortunately, this wasn't supposed to be a comedy. Let's see, the shark swims down the coast as though following the family to the Bahamas. Then there's Mario Van Peebles trying to sound Jamaican but sounding instead like Miss Cleo's long-lost brother. But here's my favorite: there's a scene where Van Peebles gets crushed in the shark's jaws but later escapes only with blood-soaked clothes and a noticeable limp. Hysterical. If you treat this film like a comedy and forget that a good director named Steven Spielberg directed the original, you should enjoy this one. Jaws the Revenge proves one thing: sequels are often a perfect example of failing to quit when one is ahead (and in the case of Dumb and Dumberer, failure to quit when one is behind).

After losing her husband to the demonic great white shark known as Jaws, Ellen Brody loses her youngest son...before nearly losing her eldest son and granddaughter to the same shark.Is it possible for a shark to be so vindictive that it is able to hunt down an entire family, no matter where they are in the world?Well, no.Unless you are in the Jaws cinematic universe that is!Joseph Sargent directs this fuzzy sharked cheesefest, that takes us from straight from Amity to the Bahamas...with robotic shark in tow.As Ellen relocates to be with her sole remaining son- who works as an aquatic scientist, studying the migration of conch snails- and his family, for the holidays.However, she is not the only one to head for warmer waters.As Jaws is not far behind, seemingly, on the hunt to finish off the family who did her dirty in the previous installations of the series.The whole thing is part action film, and part psychological thriller.And, Sargent wastes no time getting into the action.Sure...it might not be the most plausible story...but it certainly is a mighty entertaining film.Despite the fact that, as a shark-bot, she has definitely seen better days.If you don't like the plot...at least stick around for the sweetest performance ever, from the little girl who plays Ellen's granddaughter.What an actual angel.6 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: "Jaws: The Revenge" is the worst "shark movie" I've ever seen
reviews.content: Let me just say that this film has to be one of the most terrible and embarrassing films I've ever seen in my entire life.The first "Jaws" movie that Steven Spielberg directed back in 1975 was an absolute classic, one which didn't even need any sequels to it whatsoever.Although "Jaws 2" was a surprisingly good sequel and "Jaws 3-D" was a fairly okay sequel, "Jaws: The Revenge", this is a movie that shouldn't even have been made if it was going to be this terrible.Though the beginning of the movie starts out pretty good, it slowly begins to go downhill right from there. I can see now why this film was nominated for so many Razzie awards because it most certainly deserved it.Let me begin shall I: the actors: To be honest I was so disgusted to see Lorraine Gary reprise her role as "Ellen Brody". Her being in a movie like this made me never want to see another movie with her again. And then we get introduced by even more lame actors. Mario Van Peebles comes into this movie as an annoying fast-talking Jamacian freak. This is where the film takes place in: The Bahamas. They make the shark swim in warm water. Wow! What an accomplishment! NOT! Lastly, Michael Caine also stars in this movie. Now, let me ask a personal question, how is it that a great actor such as Michael Caine be put in cast of a really terrible movie like this? This film just had a lot of unnecessary actors who each gave a very poor performance in this film. Plus, it says here that Lorraine Gary had won a "Saturn Award" or something for "Best Supporting Actress". I don't know how the hell she managed to win an award for something like that being in a movie like this.the dialogue: The worst scripted movie I've ever listened to in my life. This "Jaws" movie is the only one in the series that's rated "PG-13". My guess is that it's because the writer felt that he needed everyone using the word, "s***", scene after scene, so that it would help make the movie more interesting and good. It absolutely didn't! The action was so slow-paced and there was hardly any suspense built up in this movie whatsoever. The dialogue was just awful, in every sense of the word.the special effects: The special effects in this "Jaws" movie weren't at all better or even improved since the last "Jaws" films. So, you mean to tell me that they made the shark stand on its tail and roar like a lion? In case the filmmakers didn't know, sharks do not even roar and they most certainly cannot stand up on their tails on water. The special effects really were dull and it was so obvious to tell that the shark was fake.the acting: The acting in this movie is probably one of the worst I've ever heard. Really, it's absolutely atrocious. I was so sick of having to hear that little girl, whatever her name was, Thea, singing and screaming almost half the time throughout the whole movie. I can understand that they're all on vacation and she wants to have a fun time, but you know what, when it comes to "Jaws", right when people see the shark swimming around, they should have to scream as if they're really scared. This girl, every time when I heard her scream, it sounded like she was screaming in a very hysterical manner, and that was just sad to see.In conclusion, This is one of the worst movies that I've ever seen in my entire life. Heck, on the back of the DVD case it says that it's a "suspense-packed thriller" and that it's "the scariest 'Jaws' of them all". Yeah? Well, that's complete bulls***! It is in no way, shape or form a suspense-packed thriller and it certainly isn't the scariest 'Jaws' movie of all time. It's just like any other regular B-monster movie with poor actors, poor script and poor special effects. Only this one doesn't even show the shark most of the time, there's barely any action in this movie whatsoever, and not a lot of people get killed or eaten in it too. I've finished counting up exactly how many people actually get eaten by Jaws in this movie. The result is 2. How disappointing is that? That in the other "Jaws" films, more people got eaten by Jaws and in this one, the filmmakers made only 2 people get eaten by Jaws in a 1 hour and 31 minute film? I don't even need to explain how terrifyingly bad this movie was any further. I think I've pretty much covered all of it up. If you're a fan of the first "Jaws" movie, I would recommend avoiding watching this poor excuse of a sequel. Trust me, it's totally not worth it.With all of that said, I give "Jaws: The Revenge", 1 star out of 10.
One of the most awful movies I ever watched. Even for the '80, which was all about "trash". But this is just a joke. Rather go to sleep, than waste your time and watch this!
Sorry but I liked this film - sure it's got its flaws but I thought the actors did really well with it and it did a reasonably good job in continuing the franchise .

reviews.review_title: I am a Micheal Caine fan--I enjoyed watching him.
reviews.content: Jaws 1 is a classic in suspense--in this film, the rubber band was stretched way too tight and it snapped. Sometimes a classic needs no sequel.  Just leave it alone.
