reviews.review_title: Terrible, Unrealistic, and Just Plain Bad
reviews.content: What is up with this movie?  What was the point of making it?  I mean, Jaws is like in the top 10 greatest movies of all time, and that's cool with me. After all, Jaws was the first movie I ever saw, and is still one of my favorite movies.  Jaws 2, a good sequel, showing the aftermath of the original and showing how the Brodys are coping with what happened.  Jaws 3, pointless.  Mike Brody (the oldest son) works at Sea World?  After all the problems he had with sharks and the ocean he works at Sea World?  And that brings us to this one.  Where to begin?  There may be slight spoilers ahead. Okay, number 1:  The sharks attacks and kills Sean Brody (the younger of the two sons).  The shark is apparently to blame for the death of Martin Brody, who died of a heart attack.  The shark tries to kill Mike Brody.  The shark comes close to killing the annoying Thea Brody.  Notice a pattern? The same shark is hunting down the whole Brody clan.  Not only that, but it follows Ellen Brody from Amity all the way to the Bahamas.  Does it has radar or something?  Number 2:  At the end, Mike uses some sort of device to torture the shark.  This device makes the shark roar like a lion and stand on its tail.  Number 3:  Why did Mike become a marine biologist if he hates the water so much?  Number 4:  Jake (another marine biologist) is attacked by the shark and dragged under the water.  About 10 minutes later he pops back up, very much alive?  How the hell did he survive the attack and staying under water for 10 minutes?  No wonder the TV version cuts that out, leaving the viewer to believe that he died.  Number 5:  How can Michael Caine land his plane in the water and have it float on the surface?  Number 6:  Why did Michael Caine miss out on the Academy Awards (which he won an Oscar but was too busy filming to accept it) to make this piece of trash film?  To sum it all up, very, very bad.  In the future, the next clan of sharks should hunt down a new family, preferably the ones who made this one.

reviews.review_title: The three things that will make you hate yourself for watching this film...
reviews.content: Lorraine Gary's hair. And her shoulderpad wardrobe. Gone is the strong yet understated character from the first and second films. A capital offense.The shark roars like a dinosaur. Allow me to repeat this. THE SHARK ROARS LIKE A DINOSAUR. Not only is this physiologically impossible, it's also f*cking stupid.Ellen Brody has flashbacks of her husband's climactic face-off with the shark from the first film. And then she rams/impales the beast with the broken prow of her boat. And the shark EXPLODES. (Note: after viewing the alternate ending where she still rams the shark but only impales it, causing massive trauma and bleeding out of the beast, I've come to the conclusion that the production team and/or the executives responsible for the final product were clearly out of their goddamn minds.) This film is total balls. And not in a good way. You have been warned.

reviews.review_title: One of the Worst Films of All Time!
reviews.content: I can suspend my disbelief to allow for a vengeful shark to come after the Brody family.  After all, he was killed in two other movies (#3 was a different shark, with different people) by the same guy (Roy Scheider's Chief Brody.  He was smart and didn't come back for this one.)  But a lot of inconsistencies and idiotic, laughable things occur in Jaws the Revenge. One of the most famous is the scene where the shark stands on its tail in the water and almost leaps onto Mrs. Brody's tiny boat.  Apparently she wasn't told of her husband's quote about getting a bigger boat.  Her dreams/nightmares provide her with memories of things she couldn't possibly have seen but not that one.  Michael Caine brings nothing to the film, except for the novelty of the fact that he couldn't pick up his first Oscar because he was filming this movie!  Lucky for him he won a second one (I think they felt sorry that he missed out for this trash film).  No suspense, no horror, bad acting, horrible writing.  They only green-lighted this based on the concept, you see.  They thought 'Gee, we can make money with another Jaws movie.  How 'bout if the shark is angry and wants revenge.'  That would've been fine...if they had attempted to make a smarter movie.I've seen a lot of bad movies but this one is among the very worst.  It goes on my list with "Godzilla 1985" and "Dracula's Dog" as one of the worst horror films on record.

Jaws The Revenge was a very poor effort at a film and agreeably, has far too many plot holes. Ironically, but to be fair, the film does start reasonably well, it has to be said, but the problem with the first attack is that it is predictable and in that, you know what's going to happen and the suspense has disappeared - they could've made the appearance of the shark a bit more unexpected and dramatic and that would've made the opening scene more effective.It was nice to see Lorraine Gary again - she is a good actress but she shouldn't have returned to this vehicle. The premise that a shark can hold a grudge is ridiculous in itself in the notion it killed her son. They should have changed the plot to show that it was a random attack and that Gary should've taken the shark on herself or done something following a few more attacks.Michael Caine and Lorraine Gary's relationship is an attempt to go in the right direction though and it is simple enough and not much can be faulted there, in fairness.The problem is, the attacks are few and far between and all family targeted by the shark - the banana boat sequence I thought was a good idea but the problem is, its too familiar and by this time, people knew the shark was rubber. Now we have CGI, who knows what they could do with Jaws.As said, the premise would've been better had it begun with Sean's demise as a random attack and various other attacks, leading to a showdown with Gary and the shark under different circumstances - a lot of things needed to be changed and that's why it failed as a film though its certainly not the worst film I've ever seen - that accolade belongs to Traffic.

I think there must have been a deleted scene where the shark is hiding in the airport with dark glasses and a trench coat to determine where the family was heading, if not the big bugger must have tapped the phones.I'd note a spoiler alert but this little gem is spoiled the second you start it, it's pre spoiled. If they make a "Jaws the 13th" it should begin with a global network of great whites on a conference call plotting an attack on the Brody family on their planned vacation to Kansas.Up off your stool Lorraine, one more round!
How he could make this crap I do not know. Almost as bad a Last Crusade.

reviews.review_title: What did you expect? The clue was in the title!
reviews.content: I can't believe some of the commenters on the IMDb bemoan the idea of the shark taking revenge. Yes I know it's utterly absurd too, but you could have at least guessed from reading the film title surely...Like every series of films, each installment attempts to bring something new to the party. The original was a classic of man vs. nature, fear of the unknown; Jaws 2 - a pale imitation - introduced the idea of a group of friends in peril; Jaws 3 - utter bilge - at least restricted the boundaries by setting itself in an aquarium; and I like to think Jaws 4 set out to be the comedy version of the franchise.Personally I believe the mistake made here was focusing on the shark itself. It seems tiresome to mention it again, for so many others have pointed it out, but for a family who've suffered such numerous and deadly shark attacks as the Brodies, the answer really is simply to move inland. It's here that the opportunity was wasted.Since we know it isn't the same shark doing the attacking, no-one can credibly believe that a family can be this unlucky. So why not pursue this angle instead? The "bad luck family"? "Jaws" is a fairly generic term, no-one said it had to relate to sharks. So how about this as a proposal: Brody family up sticks and move to Canadian wilderness, start new life in small town community, before being terrorised by rabid free-roaming bear (Jaws 5). What's left of them up sticks and moves to China to settle in dirty Shanghai suburb, only to again be confronted by a ferocious maneating street panda (Jaws 6). Geddit? Lovely jubbly, franchise restored, Oscars all round.In the meantime, sit back, stick "Jaws: The Revenge" on, open a beer and laugh a la Naked Gun, for that is all this tripe really is.

I hate this movie.  I hate it with such a passion!  Where the hell do I start?  Okay, the film opens with the present day Brody family still living in New England.  Sean Brody is eaten in the first few minutes.  So Eileen Brody goes nuts.  She says the shark deliberately killed Sean cuz' he's a Brody and that Sheriff Broady died of his heart attack years ago cuz' he was thinking about the shark.  So Eileen wants to get away from sharks.  Hmm, Nebraska? Iran? NO! Bermuda!!! Not only that, but this shark somehow got the Brody's flight arrangements and swam to the exact right island before they even arrived!  Aside from the fact that this is completely ridiculous, a question comes to mind.  If there is a drive behind this shark what is it? Is it the same shark from the previous flicks and just keeps regrouping itself like the T-1000?  Or is simply a family member?Anyway, Mike Brody works down at the Bahamas with his Jamaican stereotype friend collecting conch shells.  Oh did I fail to mention that every time a Broady family member is attacked, Ellen's shark radar hits in? She can be clear across another island parting with Mike Caine and just go into trances. No need to worry though.  Michael Brody can escape no just the shark, but the bends by using his oxygen tank to shoot himself to the surface.Bad plot, bad acting, bad writing, maybe you can just sit back, hit the mute and just watch the flick like a mindless slasher, WRONG!  The body count is 2 (maybe 3), and the shark is the most fake piece of muppet scraps ever put in the water! And the people who do get killed just fall into the shark's gaping mouth! no lie! And ah, the climax.  If you are a MSTie, this is the sole propose of watching the movie.  The ending will shock you in the worst way ever. *Spoiler*Weeeeeel, Eileen has had enough.  She decides to steal a yacht and go out into the ocean for a final battle.  How she's gonna kill the thing, well she'll cross that bridge when she gets to it I guess.  The cast catches up to them, gets killed by the shark, oh wait, no they don't. Then they put a light in the shark, which makes it roar (Yes roar! As in lion roar!). Apparently, by now the writer decides that he's killed the movie totally, he decides to throw in some dolphin-esque aerobatics to the shark.  We're talking big, full out of the water, 5+ seconds of hang time.  In the past 3 films we've seen a shark get exploded (2 times) and electrocuted.  How does he bite it this time?  Poked.  Yep, poked by a damn stick! Instant head explosion, complete rip off of the classic film.  Hell it even had footage from the first film! In flashbacks! In flashbacks where no other living human could remember!! I've learned there is a directors cut of this movie.  They completely changed the ending for home video.  I thought for a second "Damn right they changed it!".  I see the movie, all they changed was allowing the Jamaican guy to live! That's it! Of all the things to change in that movie they make that comic relief bastard survive falling into the shark's open mouth! His explanation for surviving "I guess he didn't like my taste Mon!" ARRRRRGGG I hate this movie!!
This one is even worse than 3-d you don't even watch this one because your eyes are already tortured by 3-d don't watch this please.

reviews.review_title: Listen it's bad but it's entertainingly bad
reviews.content: Look I agree with the general public (by a little) that this is a pretty bad movie, BUT and this is a HUGE BUT.....i was entertained? Look the first jaws is my all time favorite movie ever since I was a child, jaws 2 is a decent sequel but it's just not the first, JAWS 3 is legit one the worst film's I've ever seen, even as a kid I thought it was terrible, and this one is just so bad it's good. Like yes the story is stupid and the acting is hilariously bad but that's what made this movie for me, the entire time I was just laughing at how ridiculous this film is. Yes it's a bad movie, it's story is truly garbage but again for the millionth time, this is a sharknado situation where the movie is so bad it's entertaining while I watched jaws 3 it bored the hell out of me, it's the first time I watched a movie and was dreading for it to be over. Now if you haven't seen this movie and your looking for a story like In the original jaws, this film will make you lose your mind, BUT if your a sucker for stupid shark movies, this is one of my guilty pleasures.

(spoilers ahead) Despite the horrific Jaws 3, this one tops the charts as the worst Jaws film ever invented. Ha, had it not been for Shark Attack 2, it would probably be the worst shark film ever invented. Cheap humor, horrible story, no good acting, and a rubber shark makes this the worst movie I've seen in my 13 years of life.For one thing, I disliked the plot. I mean, really: a great white SOMEHOW is able to track the members of the Brody family and attempt to kill only them, while a 9,000 year old Ellen Brody (still played by Lorraine Gary; don't ask why) tries to hunt it down and kill it.Still awake? All right then (yawn). I also hoped to at least some good shark special effects. This movie ranks a 0 on my rankings list; it might have made a 4 with a good shark. But (and this is not a lie, folks) THE EXACT SAME SHARK ROBOT IS USED FROM THE PREVIOUS THREE MOVIES.
If I didn't know better, I'd have thought this movie was making fun of the original film in the trilogy. But it wasn't. It was a total waste of film. After I saw it, I decided to throw this movie, and everything connected to it and the third one in the garbage, and I advise every Jaws fan to do the same before they do something they'd regret.Oh, and not to give away the ending or anything, but the shark explodes when punctured by a piece of wood, and the shot of it sinking down to the depths of the ocean is exactly the same shot as in the original film after Brody blew it up with the oxygen tank and shotgun. Pathetic, huh? It almost seems to me like they were rushed to get this film out and wasted good opportunities for better shots. Heck, I wouldn't be surprised if that was the truth.

reviews.review_title: Go on, have a good laugh watching this.
reviews.content: This is MCA Universal Home Video's official film account for JAWS 4: The Revenge:Once again the peace of Amity and the lives of the Brody family are shattered by a bloodthirsty shark in this suspense-packed sequel to the original classic chiller. Lorraine Gary reprises her role as the now widowed Ellen Brody who finds herself reliving the horrors of the past when a mammoth shark kills her son. Grief-stricken, she travels to the Bahamas to be with her other son, a marine biologist (Lance Guest), and his family. There she meets and falls for a carefree airplane pilot (Michael Caine). But just as she is putting her life back together, the nightmare of the past returns when her granddaughter is attacked by an all-too-familiar Great White. Determined to end the terror once and for all, Ellen sets out for a showdown to the death. The action and tension build rapidly to a shattering climax in this, the most incredible Jaws adventure of them all. And this time, it's personal!NO IT'S NOT, IT'S RIDICULOUS!This film is a must see for all the wrong reasons. It's one of those films that's so bad it's actually brilliant. Don't confuse it with such abysmal films like Independence Day, Armageddon or the truly obscene 2012, these pictures are just big-budget garbage that trivialises the subtext. No, what I'm talking about is a film that's has noticeably lost its way during filming. Whether it's down to costs, script changes, actor hitches or good old fashioned executive interference, a film that's so fragmented the bloody thing should've been abandoned.A good comparison I suppose is David Fincher's Alien 3; it's believed that three endings were filmed (I've even read many more scenes were filmed post-production) coupled with endless script changes, actors walking away due to other commitments and many production fines meant that filming became a nightmare.In Jaws IV something similar has clearly happened; what you see is a plot of such ludicrous incredulity that you cannot believe your eyes. Ignore MCA Universal Home Video's official film account because in one sentence the story goes something like this: The great white stalks Chief Brody's widow to the Caribbean for a final showdown. Thereby inferring that sharks have scruples, can reason, have the ability to track humans on-land and can hold a grudge; I mean, I knew they were intelligent but c'mon?!!Okay, let's start with the main protagonist THE SHARK: it's still a cheap prosthetic and in some clips the unobservant amongst you can see the vehicle driving the contraption; the observant should just be laughing and shaking your head. I don't think this 'glaring error' is meant to be included in the final cut, but whatever the reason for its inclusion, the Director didn't feel the need to 'fuzz-it' out. Perhaps he was contemplating suicide at this point! (Later edits have masked the mechanics, so try and get hold of an old VHS/DVD of the original release and laugh out loud)ELLEN BRODY (played by Lorraine Gary): As wooden as a work-mate and as 'hammy' as Derek Jacobi in everything he's ever done! This was Gary's final acting role; I wonder, was she pushed or did she jump?HOAGIE NEWCOMBE (played by Michael Caine): I just don't know what to say; he dances in one scene, brilliantly awful (oxymoron for you) as ever!I'm going to sign-off now, but listen-out for Mario Van Peebles' (Jake) dreadful West Indian accent!The film doubled its money, so who am I to judge?Box Office (Source: IMDb) Budget: $23,000,000 (estimated) Opening Weekend: $7,154,890 (USA) (19 July 1987) Gross: $51,881,013 (Worldwide)Other rubbish, but unintentionally funny films are: Shocker, Judge Dredd, Speed, Highlander, Backdraft, Rambo: First Blood Pt 2, War of the Worlds (2005), Total Recall, Contact, The Abyss, Dracula (1992), The Time Machine (1960)...the 2002 version was 'rubbish' only, The Black Hole...oh my Lord they're endless.
Not the movie, the comedy routine Richard Jeni came up with after watching this travesty!My advice to you if you ever accidently happen upon this film, disconnect your cable and watch snow!

reviews.review_title: Jaws 3D looks like an inspired work of art in comparison
reviews.content: Joe Sargent is a more than capable director with several Emmy's under his belt and Michael Caine is a fine actor who had the misfortune of working on a film that is not only the worst of his career but which also prevented him from receiving his Oscar in person because of location shooting for this movie."Jaws: The Revenge" is almost too easy to pick on. Sure, the island scenery is gorgeous to look at and there are plenty of pretty girls but, yikes, that first reveal of the shark is the final blow to any credibility that this movie was hoping to have.The alternate TV version, in an attempt to make some sense of what the viewer is about to see, adds a needless voice over that only serves to make the entire premise of the movie even more absurd.This was near the top of my bad movie list (just before MANOS: THE HANDS OF FATE) but both have been displaced by Timothy Hines' THE WAR OF THE WORLDS. No easy feat, to be sure.

There are a lot of bad movies out there, some would argue there are more bad movies than good. Of course, that would depend on one's taste. For this movie, taste does not even need to play a factor. This movie is bad. Really bad. Some bad movies are actually enjoyable to watch in small doses. For example, look at Battlefield Earth: the screenplay is poorly-written and almost painful to listen to, the science is completely wrong, and there is no effort put into the acting. However, if you interpret it as an unintentional comedy, it can be pleasurable. There's also Alone in the Dark: Horrid script, wooden acting, but at least the visuals are somewhat nice to look at. This movie... has no redeeming value. I hate it. I hate it so much that if given the chance, I would obliterate every copy of it and erase it from history.The first Jaws was brilliant: Masterfully-placed suspense, dedicated acting, and a crafty plot. The best part was the shark model. In this movie, Steven Spielberg was careful not to overuse the shark model so that it would look authentic. That was the main point of brilliance. The first Jaws is definitely one of the 100 best movies I have ever seen in my life.The second Jaws was okay. It wasn't as exciting or as developed as the first, but I still had fun.The third Jaws... almost immediately I saw things that could be improved. I thought it was really bad, definitely the worst of the three.Little did I know that a certain abomination was lying just around the corner:Jaws... THE REVENGE.This may not be the worst movie I have ever seen in my life, but believe me; it's at least in the bottom five.I'll tell just what it is about it that makes it so horrendous:First of all, there's the actual premise: A SHARK trying to get REVENGE on humans? Okay, so the Brodys have previously killed four white great white sharks. Why would another one suddenly want revenge? And for that matter, how would it even know how to sort humans out?You see what I mean? Just the idea itself is beyond ridiculous. But here's the actual movie:After killing Sean, the shark actually FOLLOWS Ellen Brody from Amity to the Bahamas. Again, how does a shark track human that is not in the water? It can't!Also, almost straight away, you notice how such little effort is put into the acting.They also have Michael Caine. Here's what's sad: Michael Caine MISSED receiving his award for Best Supporting Actor at the Oscar ceremony in 1987 because he was busy filming THIS pathetic excuse for a film. Good lord, Michael; you should know better!Then there's the introduction of some new characters: Michael Brody's wife, his daughter, and his Jamacian friend. All three of these characters are so annoying that I wish I could have just fast-forwarded through their scenes. But, alas, I sat through every moment of torture.This movie is also more focused on the lives of the characters than it is on the shark.Speaking of which, here is by far the worst part of the movie: the shark model.This shark model is about as fake as they get. It makes the models from the Shark Attack films and the Mega Shark vs. Whatever-The-Hell movies look authentic.It did not scare me. Not for one millisecond. In fact, only the shark from the first movie really took my breath away for any amount of time. I was too busy laughing and crying at how fake this model was. I was laughing because it was stupid, and I was crying because it was ruining the first Jaws with its terrible quality.But there's more! The shark actually ROARS. Yes, it freaking ROARS. Guess what people! Sharks now have vocal cords!But wait until you hear about the fate of the shark: They impale it with the bow on their yacht, and it... explodes. Yes, apparently Sharks have nitroglycerin or something for blood now.Words cannot express how much I hate this movie. My hatred for this movie is so great that it's almost unhealthy.People, do not see this movie. You will regret it. You will regret sitting through even one second of this sh*t fest.If you do decide to go see it... be ready.You've been warned.

It's a toss-up as to whether Jaws 3 or Jaws the Revenge was the worst movie I ever saw. Too bad I couldn't rate this worse than a 1. It doesn't even deserve that high a rating. Why does Hollywood insist on knocking out sequel after sequel and why don't they know when to stop? Jaws 1 was exceptional with Jaws 2 being okay, still very watchable. Jaws the Revenge was so far fetched that only an idiot would enjoy it.We are supposed to believe that a shark somehow knows who is a Brody and even knows when these Brody's leave Amity and head down to the Caribbean! Did you know sharks were that smart? Why aren't scientists doing way more research on them? Naturally all the Brody boys still work on or near the water, when most certainly after what they witnessed as children, they would be living in a desert somewhere nowhere near any body of water. But then the makers of this film couldn't have blessed us with this 2 hour waste of time.The ending is so ridiculous as to be almost funny. Someone please tell me why Ellen Brody thinks she can catch this shark all by herself to finally end "The Revenge". Give me a break. Then she acts like she's on tranquilizers and needs serious help mentally. But she manages to actually spear the shark on a part of the bow. HURRAY! Maybe we will never be subjected to a sequel as dumb as this.

reviews.review_title: A very disappointing movie, but I can't say I was expecting much better.
reviews.content: The whole idea of a shark "out to get revenge" is beyond ridiculous. This movie has far too many impossibilities like a jet speeding shark (a shark beating a plane to the Bahamas?), a growling shark, a roaring shark, an exploding shark, a sharks that sets traps up, a shark and human with some sort of psychic interaction. It never ends!The really sad thing is that the first Jaws movie (which was fantastic by the way!) didn't even have half the budget of The Revenge but made almost half a billion dollars in profit, whereas The Revenge had over double the first movies budget but made less than $30M profit. It really goes to show that modern technology doesn't pay off, doesn't it?Apart from all the crazy ideas thought up in the storyline, it seems as though there was absolutely no effort whatsoever put into the making of this movie. There are endless mistakes that are clearly seen throughout the movie like the wires and tracks where the mechanical shark is swimming, the shark skin tones changing, fake backgrounds... Many of which could of been prevented or at least made less obvious.Sequels almost always seem to ruin the original movie. Perhaps this movie was made to try and get everyone to forget about the disaster of a movie Jaws 3 made, but compared to this movie, Jaws 3 deserves a golden globe.1/10

reviews.review_title: big moma shark versus kinda skeleton-like moma Brody
reviews.content: Well, I own both the original film for television and cinema version, and the original film for video version as well as the latest supposedly widescreen version.. which is basically the video version with bits of black electical tape across the top and bottom of the screen! Why? I love Jaws, and I love sharks.. personally I HATED jaws the revenge with a passion! But I had to get the whole set :D I didn't realise just how bad the television version was until last night when it was shown on BBC1. Basically the shark effects on Baywatch are better! To make the shark look like it was biting down on something they had to reverse the video because the model shark could not close its mouth, multiple teeth fall out when the shark attacks the boat, as the shark swims chasing Mike, who is doing his best to swim clear of the submersible you can visibly see the crane which is operating the shark.  Although the worst bit is when u get a clear view of the belly of the shark and see the huge gaping hole full of bits of wood and wiring attatched to the crane!   How on earth did they get away with this?! Did the guys who made this know anything about sharks? I think not! Sharks arent dinosaurs! They dont roar!!! They don't swim on their tails! AND they dont have a huge gap between their teeth and their gums!!! The book? Excellent.. the film? pants...

reviews.review_title: By far the worst of the series!
reviews.content: The film begins in the town of Amity (where the first 2 movies were set) and focuses on Ellen and Sean Brody (also from the other films in the series). Why this family is still living right on the water after 3 previous life-threatening encounters with great white sharks is beyond me. After Sean is killed by another shark, Ellen decides to head down to the Bahamas with her other son Michael (from the first 3 films). According to Michael, there has never been a great white shark down there, because it is too warm for them. Things get ridiculous when the shark follows them to the Bahamas to seek revenge. The movie has some good points; the cast was decent, the effects were alright, and really might not have been that bad of a movie...However, the idea of humanizing a shark is simply absurd.

reviews.review_title: What the hell is going on here.
reviews.content: This is probably my nomination as the worst example of film making I've ever seen. Sure, there are more worse movies, but they may not have had the advantage of a budget or the backing of a major studio, OR of being a "Jaws" for that matter.  This is a travesty from start to finish. The movie should have been titled "Jaws, The Quest To Be Eaten".  Every character seems to go out of their way to literally throw themselves in the path of the shark.  Correct that, "character" is the wrong word. Caricature is the term.  Also, even "shark" is inadequate to describe our wee beastie of nature.  Supersonic shark is the more correct description as "Bruce IV" manages to swim half the length of a continent in three days.  He also, honest to god, roars. Yes, roars.  Sure, whatever.  The plot is a meandering mess, establishing certain story and character development points, only to completely forget about them when the next scene roles around.  Though it's not like you particularly care about any body anyway.  The acting would embarrass Anson Williams.  Again, it's easy to pick on the likes of Lorraine Gary or Lance Guest.  They are obviously not real actors and are merely taking a paycheck.  If they themselves think they can act, well, delusions delusions.  It is Michael (pay me! pay me!) Caine and Mario (I'm not a stereotype!) Van Peeples that should know better.This movie makes "Yor: Hunter From the Future" look like a taut, masterfully crafted artistic triumph. nuff said.

I watched this movie and all I can say is.................... I really can't put into words how terrible this movie is. A shark gets revenge on the Brody family. Plot terrible, acting awful. Everything that had to do with this movie was just down right terrible. Another thing that really confused the crap out of me was the roar. The Great White Shark literally roared like a lion or something. They would send these shock wave things and the shark would roar in pain. STAY AWAY from this film. Even if you are a Jaws fan like me, do not watch. It takes away the fear of Jaws and fun of Jaws eating people. Just simply do not watch this film.

Wow just wow. SMH.Poor wouldn't begin to describe it.
The acting is terrible, the fake shark ridiculously fake, and there is no suspense whatsoever. I did give it one star since there are some laugh out loud moments due to the poor quality of the whole movie.
Sometimes it looked like the shark was suffering from gingivitis, when it was attacking boats and I felt bad for it. Had to fast forward through some scenes that were too long. Other scenes that could have made the movie watchable were way too short leaving the viewer to fill in the gaps.

reviews.review_title: Dear lord, I can't believe I watched it all!!
reviews.content: Unbelievable in its complete lack of any worth. THE SHARK ROARS!!! I swear, it has a dinosaur like howl. What the @@$#%!! I honestly wonder if Speilberg ever even saw it, and how depressed it left him to know that he spawned it.

This film is absolutely ridiculous.  I can't believe michael caine took a part in this movie.  The great white shark, "Jaws" growls and jumps out of the water.  Laughable.  Why anyone produced this movie, or directed it for that matter, i will never know

reviews.review_title: Looking for stupidness... you got it right there!
reviews.content: The first Jaws was a work of art, a suspensful incredibly strong movie.... and the fourth? Just guess! The stupidess movie you'll ever seen! So unbelievably low, boring, no-brainy! I could go on and on talking about the infinite bad sides of this movie.  Good sides, you ask... I haven't find a single one!Believe me, if you want to see a good movie this weekend, go rent either Jaws (the first one of course!), Pulp Fiction or The Matrix... at least you'll get some action for your money!

reviews.review_title: Just when you thought it was safe to go back to the cinema...
reviews.content: Dear God. Dreadful. Awful. A dire film whose association with the 1975 classic only goes to emphasise how bad this really is. How did the plot synopsis get past studio executives: "Well this time the shark (forgetting that the previous three in the saga have been blown up, electrocuted etc and therefore would have no knowledge of the Brody family) targets Chief Brody's wife after killing her son. She flees in a plane to Bahama and the shark follows thereby leading to a showdown which not only defies belief but also treads on territory that even comedies would not dare to offer. What was Michael Caine thinking? He is so much better than this dross. Avoid like the plague. Rent the original.

What makes this film such an outlandish waste of reel? The real question is, what doesn't? The only good part of this movie (and I mean ONLY) is Michael Caine. I don't fault him for being a part of it, because an actor who doesn't act is, well, nothing. Plus, by his own admission, it was certainly an effective way to remind moviegoers of the dozens of excellent pictures on which he has worked. He was paid for his performance, and given his remarkable talent, he deserved it. But his natural screen presence was so utterly out of place in this vomit-inducing train wreck. Caine aside, the acting is horse manure, and the already inept cast members are not helped by a disgraceful excuse for a screenplay. A shark that singles out the relatives of the man who killed a couple of other sharks once? Where does this nonsense come from? Finally, the mud on the worm cake is Joseph Sargent's utterly by-the-numbers direction. Granted, he had so very little to work with, but he still failed, as did this movie.

reviews.review_title: I thought nothing could be more worse then Jaws 3-D...
reviews.content: It was in the start of the Swedish summer (that includes rain) and Swedish Chanel 3 showed Jaws:The Revenge in the late evening. I had just seen Jaws 2 and 3-D so I thought I'll watch number 4 to expand my "have seen" movie list. Oh Boy! Could I have used the time much better?? Oh Yes I could have!!This movie was even more worse then Jaws 3-D (and thats B-A-D!). I wonder if Michael Caine had a money problem in those days because what else made him be a part of this piece of crap?Although the beginning of the film is a little terrifying it doesn't help that the shark is unbelievable fake and the story unbelievable dumb and dumberer. The big nasty (fake) Jaws is probably a relative to the earlier sharks in Jaws 1,2 and 3 and he want's revenge on the Brody family...incredible silly!But the dumbest in the movie is when the shark is supposed to have been swimming from the little cold harbor village of Amity to the warm seas of the Bahamas...I did my duty 1/10.

reviews.review_title: What The Hell Were You Smoking!
reviews.content: Now this is an outrageous slap in the face to any Jaws fan; Jaws 2 was totally unnecessary, Jaws 3-D was completely ludicrous, and now, now they have completely insulted our intelligence with this most utter slop, this plate of drivel they call Jaws: The Revenge. Apparently, a shark is intelligent enough to cradle a grudge, and apparently it can remember its parents (the sharks from the first two films, who in an even worse piece of script writing were supposedly soul mates, when male sharks practically just rape a female they momentarily fancy and move on). They have applied human logic to a brainless instinctual fish, and it has resulted in this garbage, this pinnacle of idiocy, sharks don't take mates, they don't have families, they are loners except for perhaps in the occasion of a frenzy. And as for the destruction of this shark, the viewer has literally no clue as to what has just happened, I mean literally they do not. The shark begins to roar like a lion, and rears upright, (like it can do that somehow), and is being shocked by some electromagnetic device they fed to it, and then having a flashback to her husband killing the first shark when she was never even there, Ellen Brody crashes the jagged bow of her ship into the shark and pops its head, and as far as I can fathom, she must have stabbed the device, or some such nonsense, because next thing, the ship has fallen to pieces from the force of the collision. Michael Caine has never even seen the monstrosity he was involved in, but it did build him a nice house so good for him, now I suggest you forget that Jaws ever had any sequels. Oh and last thing, final thing, that I just thought of, this film forgets, ignores, rejects the events of Jaws 3-D, and this causes massive continuity aneurysms, furthermore do not ever watch it for the love of all that is good and holy. I really do mean it when I say they raped a classic.

reviews.review_title: Probably the best of the franchise. Certainly the most rewatchable.
reviews.content:
By far teh most rewatchable of the Jaws films - 1987's Jaws: The Revenge thankfully ditches the boring stretches of the original 1975 movie ( Quint's monologue comes to mind) and focuses solely on entertaining the audience.Whereas the original movie crawled at a snails pace - especially during the tedious fishing trip that devours the last half of the movie - Joseph Sargent's Jaws grabs us immediately and never lets go thereafter.Michael Caine makes for one of the better series protagonists. Caine gives a casual and relaxed performance - unlike Richard Dreyfuss who wanted us all to pat him on the head and tell him he did a good job at playing Hooper. Dreyfus was eager to please and it came across as a desperation to hijack the movie at times.
None of this unnecessary and silly 'I'm a better actor than you' crap plagues the cast of Jaws: The Revenge. They don't have to prove anything and it makes for a less irritating experience.
I lasted 15 minutes. Threw the DVD in the bin. Absolutely awful movie. Zero plot, zero effects, terrible story and acting. I'm amazed Michael Caine agreed to participate in this disastrous movie.

reviews.review_title: so bad you have to see it
reviews.content: horrible. one of the worst movies ever. see it becuase its so bad.here are some things in the movie that are so bad its funny.the main character thinks the shark is out for revenge on her and her family.cain crashes into the ocean, then climbs onto a boat COMPLETLY DRY!the main person seems to remember things that she wasnt eevn present at the time of the event.cain actuallly is in this movie. its really him. why did he do this movie?

I think that the whole of Hollywood was really trying to milk the whole Jaws pizzazz that was brought about by the first film which will remain one of the best scary movies in cinematic history. However, with Jaws 2 coming just up to expectations this is more than can be said for Jaws 3-D and the fourth and final picture in the series. The shark in jaws 3-D was laughably fake and the plot in jaws , the revenge somewhat comical. I mean, Ellen Brody thinks that this shark has some kind of vendetta against her family after her husband dies of a heart attack brought on by his fear of sharks and after her youngest son, Sean is killed by a great white whilst out at sea at a buoy. For crying out loud, why didn't the family just move to another costal place if they were that fond of the sea. Why, oh, why did they insist on staying at a place where 4 great white sharks have hunted and killed a multitude of people in the last 20 odd years? Surely that's enough to make you never want to go into the sea again, particularly if the population of great white sharks is after you and your family... Make up your own minds about it but my advice, give it a miss.

reviews.review_title: "Sharks come and go, Ellen." Indeed they do.
reviews.content: If you've seen Jaws' Revenge, you're probably wondering where my review is. Well, Bam. Anywho, Jaws and the Revenge is the story of a shark who swims around looking for people named Brody. Oscar winner Adrien Brody, rocking guitarist Brody Dalle, ostensibly foreign pro wrestler Bruiser Brody, if your name is Brody, the shark would like to have a quick this-and-that with you. Ellen Brody is a mother who lives on Amity Island and after losing a husband to post-traumatic disorder after killing not one but two of the these buggers, and seeing her son turn into Dennis Quaid for the last movie, is letting her young son work in law enforcement. Her only caveat is that he only go close enough to the water where the shark can lunge (and baby, the shark in this movie got some moves!) and chew his arms off. The shark does, but then the son leans forward to yell at it. The shark then eats the rest of the son. Ellen has had enough of this and moves with her surviving son, who is no longer Dennis Quaid, to the Bahamas. The shark decides that's cool with him, and he swims down there before they can get there in their plane. Not exactly a fast plane, there. Upon arriving we meet the rest of the cast. There's Lenny, played Jamaicanly by Mario Van Peebles, who you may recall from his other work, unless you've never heard of him. And of course Chewie, played by Michael Caine, who like Louis Gossett Jr before him, used winning an Academy Award as a stepping stone to get involved with this franchise. (Look it up). How Jaws got Revenge is about the mind of a killing machine, who swims, eats, and gets revenge. Ellen takes things into her own hands and drives a boat to find this shark. Peebles' character is grabbed by the shark and dragged under water. Don't worry kids, he's totally fine though. This shark is aggressive though. He roars, bellows, moos, coughs, and growls. Chewie is very attracted to Ellen Brody, who after four movies of this would probably like to change her name from Brody. Chewie, in a role that would establish Michael Caine as a legend, is insatiable in his quest for her. He roars, bellows, moos, coughs, and growls. At the end of the day, The Revenge of Jaws will keep you on the edge of your seat, white-knuckled, biting your lip, making you wonder what will happen next. After seeing this film you will know what the words "revenge" and "personal" truly, truly mean. And knowledge, unlike sharks, is something that will never just come and go. RRRRRROOOOOOOOOAAAAAAAARRRRRR!!!!

reviews.review_title: This movie is such an atrocity, i admire its guts.
reviews.content: If i could put into words what a bad film this is, i should receive an Academy award. Its true, seldom does one come across a film so awful, that it actually inspires admiration for the people who made. Whoever they are however, i'm sure that they have long since been fired from the film industry. I might be a tad mean, but the gap in quality between Jaws and Jaws the Revenge is so massive, i don't think another one exists in the entire history of cinema. The one star a gave to this film is for the guts of the filmmakers to actually attempt putting such a lame, and utterly pathetic film on the film reel.The only good aspect of this film is the music, although it variates on the classic John Williams tune, as it allows one to close their eyes while watching the film, and admire the music. But then there's the roaring shark (really, a roaring shark? you must be kidding? sharks don't roar!) Oh, they do, in this film apparently. Actually both the shark and anyone watching this film has something in common when it comes to jaws. the shark is using its jaws to chow people, while your jaws are hitting the floor. Oh yes, and did i mention that the shark also seeks revenge on the Brody (Sharks don't seek revenge! What are you talking about?) Yep, thats what makes this film truly unique. A shark, probably a second cousin 5000 times removed from the original Bruce. Apparently Matin Brody has died from a heart attack from "FEAR"! Like he new another Great White was coming to attack the town. Its like he had some sort of telepathic link with it. (That's impossible!) I know it is.I don't think anyone enjoyed seeing young Sean Brody getting killed like that, especially considering that he is the little kid from JAWS, who everyone thought was so cute for imitating his father's movements like that. AND, you know what? The SHARK LAYS AN AMBUSH!!!!!!! Wow, i bet you'd never heard of that in the history of cinema. In fact this film is so bad, that almost every Jaws spinnoff is better than it, and that's just insulting.Also, this film leaves Amity island and takes place in the Bahamas. Unless the shark flew, or hitched a ride on a speed boat, which is the only way it would have gotten there in time, this doesn't help the credibility of this picture. Oh, and for peaks sake, in the sharks death scene, they actually had the nerve to steal a shot of the original film. That i admire. That, and the whole roaring shark shark thing. Apart from that, the film has undeveloped characters, a crappy story, and is 87 minutes long, which is just unbearable for such junk. Oh, and just for the record, great white sharks cannot stop moving, or else they stop living. Someone should tell that to the films director.
I usually am an optimist... but this movie is the worst movie i've ever seen. It just makes no sense... a shark isn't going to follow people around the world.

reviews.review_title: Just When You Thought it Was Safe to Watch Another Jaws Movie...
reviews.content: Like so many others, I watched--and loved--the original Jaws. I managed not to think too badly about Jaws 2, and I thought Jaws 3D was a very well-done self-parody of the franchise.What can I say about this turkey? I can only imagine Lorraine Gary asking, "Who do I have to sleep with to get OUT of this piece of garbage?" There are some roles that are feathers in an actor's cap; not only is this not one of them, it is actually a stain left on the baseball cap by some large and incontinent seagull.The best thing I can say about this ridiculous waste of celluloid is the the whole cast must have been in this piece of garbage as a result of losing several large bets.Is this a spoiler? I don't think so, because all I'm trying to do is to keep you from wasting an unrecoverable hour and a half of your lives.IN SHORT: it deserves a PG rating: Pure Garbage

I'm not sure what is worse: The Ellen Brody Character? Mario Van Peebles haunting attempt at a rasta accent? The foam shark? The fact that the shark swims 1000 miles for revenge? The shark eats a plane? Conch migrate in formation? She spears the shark which then explodes with the bow of a sailboat??? They fly off into the sunset at the end in the plane that was just destroyed one scene earlier? Let's face it. This is the worst movie of all time, especially considering that it stars Michael Cane and derives from the original Jaws, which all in all was a good movie. Jaws 4 The Revenge should be celebrated and praised for its badness. One could ask how much worse this movie could be...None worse.

reviews.review_title: Come on, Michael Caine is in it...
reviews.content: Michael Caine is at least somewhat humorous. Oh wait, its a movie about a shark eating people. Its not supposed to be humorous. But it is, its quite laughable, and actually the special effects are more humorous than any of the characters. Except Ellen Brody, of course. Lorraine Gary's performance is...well, melodramatic (I suppose with the tragic death of her husband, she should be). Really, her performance is inspired...by needing money, I suppose. Maybe she had a heroin addiction to feed. Doubtless, she made millions from this film. I'm sure that the famous Joseph Sargent (who was mostly a TV director and has never actually made a decent film) thought that the script was money, and the film would make his career. Or end it (he has not directed a film since, only television). All in all, Jaws: The Revenge is an epic (as epic as a flatulent attack) end to an exciting motion picture quadrilogy. I'm still waiting for the nine-disk boxed set, complete with the 3-D version of number 3 (which is quite possibly even worse than Revenge).

reviews.review_title: "What could be more terrifying than Jaws: The Revenge?"
reviews.content: This is the worst sequel I have ever seen. It is terrible to the point of insulting. For those of you who have not seen this appalling film, please click back now.Now this is set some time after the events of Jaws 2. For some reason Jaws 3-D never happened. Anyway Ellen Brody's son is on patrol one night, until he is ambushed and killed by a Great White Shark. This is one of the least suspenseful death scenes in movie history. It tries to get you into the classic Jaws spirit, since you can't exactly see the shark and it has the same sort of music. But you can't help but notice its many mistakes. For example it is implied Sean's arm has been taken off by the shark, so why is almost all his coat sleeve still intact? Ellen is devastated at this, but then seems oddly alright with it after-wards.When her eldest Michael and his family go to the Bahamas for Christmas he convinces her to come with him. On the way, Ellen meets a Sub sandwich called Hoagie. In an effort to make this film good "Hoagie" is Michael Caine who missed an Oscar ceremony to stay on set filming this. Anyway the shark somehow manages to swim all the way to the Bahamas in pursuit of the Brodys. While hunting for shells, Michaels boat is attacked by the shark. For some reason Michael says they should not tell anyone of this incident. Since no-one else can deal with this shark apparently, Michael and his friend Jake try and track the shark but fail.Assuming everything is safe again, Michael goes down to the ocean to study shells. After his Submersible is wrecked by the shark, he escapes and goes into a sunken ship. After barely escaping that funny attack, he insists on looking for the shark the next day. Unable to find the shark in the ocean depths, it is soon realized it is going to attack Carla's art celebration party. The shark appears and eats a woman on a banana boat ride. Another mistake is the fact the woman deliberately puts her leg into the shark's mouth. You will not find it hard to notice this! Ellen, convinced she can stop a giant killer shark, steals Michael's boat and heads off to find the shark. Michael, Jake and Sandwich successfully find Ellen but then crash the plane. Although it looks like 'Hoagie' has been eaten, he emerges with a freshly ironed shirt. When Jake realizes he can use his flashlight-tracker thing, he decides he can put it directly in the sharks mouth where it won't be chewed or digested. The shark then leaps out and chews him up! Michael uses Jake's invention to make the shark levitate above the water. When Ellen takes control of the boat she rams the gunwale into the shark. It somehow manages to blow it to pieces like it had explosives strapped to it. Now several mistakes can be noticed in this rushed sequence of the film. Why does Ellen have flashbacks of an event she wasn't there for? Why does the shark roar like a tiger? Why did the shark explode? Why did it almost hover above the water? Why and how does Ellen have some sort of psychic connection to the shark? How did Jake survive? All these questions are never answered.To sum up, Jaws: The Revenge is not only a terrible sequel,it is just a terrible film. It drops suspense, horror and laws of physics completely. Why couldn't they just leave it at the third Jaws film? This one should just be forgotten.

Well, once you realise that a great white shark is actually roaring at you, you know you're watching a bad film. The ending is totally unclear and you basically want it to come quickly. Yeah, the fact that a shark actually follows a woman to the Bahamas, as if guided by some force is pretty darn impossible, and there are some little details that sort of add to the disaster, such as Ellen's flashbacks of her son Sean sitting at that kitchen table playing with his dad, which Ellen didn't actually see according to Jaws 1.Good points: The music is good, the setting of the Bahamas is beautiful, small things like Ellen's daughter in law's sculpture looking like a shark's face are quite cool, some of the acting is good, some scenes are memorable (like when Jake, Ellen's son's friend who's a stereotypical Caribbean man is in the underwater pod seeking out snails and Jaws sort of pulls up alongside and he goes on his microphone 'Oh god, we've got a big fish down here man'), and the bananaboat scene is good too, although you can spot that the fin racing behind it is just a fin attached to a piece of cardboard, and also there are some tense scenes like Michael being chased around a shipwreck by Jaws.Bad points: Sharks don't really roar (!), the shark swimming underwater looks the fakest out of all the Jaws films, many things are unclear such as how Jaws dies in the end, the story of a shark having a vendetta against a family is ridiculous, the name 'Hoagie' (Caine's character) is even more ridiculous, Ellen's shoulder pads are even more ridiculous than that, the final scenes are obviously filmed in a swimming pool with high walls as you can see that there are waves bouncing against a wall  a few metres from the characters, that has been painted grey with a few clouds here and there, and do you want me to go on?

reviews.review_title: I pity those fools who spent $6 to see this at the movie in 1987...
reviews.content: ***Spoilers********and to the previous films in this series***This "film" was and is a mistake, or at least a bad joke or someone lost a bet with the devil.  This movie is awful from death of a Brody, how in the name of all that is sacred did that happen.  In the three other movies they could be in dire straits but they made it out okay. reviews.content: This movie is by far the worst of the sequels. While Jaws 3 was bad, this was worse.First of all, the shark sets up an attack for Sean Brody, which sharks, while being very smart, still do not have the brains to do.Then there is the fact that sharks, even a their top hunting speed, couldn't have beat the Brody's to the Bahamas. It's simply impossible.Also, sharks do not telepathically communicate with humans! The shark wouldn't have even cared if Brody had killed it's parents, if it had any emotion, it would have been gratitude, because it's parents would have wanted to kill it! Lastly, SHARKS DO NOT ROAR! They are not capable of making any noise at all! (This is a spoiler) But, at the ending, the sharks leaps up, and holds it's self there, which a shark cannot do, roaring like Godzilla, while they impale it with the boat, and it EXPLODES. Come on! There where no explosives involved in this whole movie! reviews.review_title: The shark that roared ... no, I'm not kidding
reviews.content: Usually when a "3D" sequel of a movie franchise appears it is a sure sign that it has been milked for all its worth, and the final, derivative, intelligence-insulting rehash of a well-worn formula has arrived. Tragically, this was not the case with "Jaws".Just to highlight the remarkable capability of Hollywood's cinematic alchemists to turn gold into lead, I must hasten to remind the reader that the original "Jaws" was an excellent film that set a high standard for the horror genre. Spielberg's original (which I gave an IMDb score of 9/10) stands, with the original "Alien", as one of the exemplars of my #1 rule for horror films. Don't let the audience get a good look at the monster -- until it's too late! Who ever would have thought that a simple dorsal fin could be so scary? Who even knew what a dorsal fin was before they saw "Jaws"?But back to the grim task at hand, "Jaws: The Revenge" flagrantly violates this rule. If you get to see the shark all the time (and it's easy to see how poorly constructed the "shark" is as another reviewer has pointed out) then it's not scary. At all. Once that happens, what's the point of making a horror movie?Let's talk about the title -- "Jaws: The Revenge". They really, honestly, sincerely mean that. It's not one of those movies where the monster goes berserk and the body count soars with gruesome special effects galore. No, not that type of revenge. You know, the type of movie where a sleazy corporate lawyer talking too loudly on his cellphone wades a couple of feet into the water and then ... CHOMP! (And the whole audience cheers.) I could imagine enjoying a movie like that -- in the right mood.But I did not enjoy "Jaws: The Revenge". At all. When they say "revenge" they mean that other, human type of revenge. The shark actually has a personal vendetta against some poor woman throughout the movie, then jumps out of the water and roars at her. Now there are just three problems that I have with that.1. The shark has a personal vendetta against a human being.2. The shark jumps out of the water.3. The shark roars.Maybe it's just me, but I have a great deal of difficulty believing that any fish would or could do such things. Maybe in an animated feature where the fish also talk to each other and sing songs. Tragically, this was not such a movie.The last straw for me is the abuse of genuinely talented, famous movie stars in this picture. Tragically, Michael Caine, Lynn Whitfield, and Mario and Melvin Van Peebles were all tricked into appearing in "Jaws: The Revenge". That may be my biggest bad-movie pet peeve. A low-budget schlock-fest with no-name actors is one thing. I can almost forgive the makers of "Manos: Hands of Fate". (Almost.) But when a major Hollywood studio drags good actors we know and like through a festering pile of manure like "Jaws: The Revenge", I cannot forgive that. At all.IMDb Score: 1 out of 10 (only because I can't give it a 0)

This movie is an absolute waste of Humanity!I cant understand why Michael Cain (,a wonderful actor) would agree to do such a piece of crap. Im wondering if this was one of those situations.On a separate note, I really don't understand why there is a ten line minimum on these reviews. Im even trying to "pad" it right now, because the average "writer" (non professional) simply does not require ten lines to get their point across (just my opinion). It is customary on French TV to broadcast the same old movies every summer : Sissi, Angélique, awful French comedies from the 1970s... This year, they went for "Jaws". Three weeks ago I was delighted to see the original movie one more time. Two weeks ago I enjoyed watching Jaws 2. Last week I gave up watching Jaws 3 to do something more interesting (paint my nails). Until yesterday night I didn't even know that "Jaws : The Revenge" existed. I have seen it. Now I can die. I have seen everything. This movie is so bad I don't even know where to start. The plot is awful. If my whole family were chased and eaten by giant sharks every time they are near a coast, I would settle somewhere in Siberia, thousands of miles away from the nearest ocean. I would not become a sort of coast guard. Nor would I become a marine biologist. And I would definitely NOT go on holiday on an island! The acting is terrible. It was even more painful since I watched the French version. The dubbing made me laugh to tears, with word-to-word translations that don't even mean anything in French (you've got to translate it back into English to understand the meaning). Everything has already been said by more talented reviewers about this huge rubber puppet that can swim 2000 miles in 2 days, survive in warm water, roar (???!!) and stand on its tail above the water. And it must be filled with hydrogen or something like that because when it is impaled on a wooden stick, it EXPLODES! I watched the last 20 minutes without a word. I couldn't laugh any more, I couldn't cry. I was hypnotised. I had seen awful movies before, but this one... My life will never be the same. You should watch it at least once in your life. It's worth it.

0 out of 5. This film should be studied by everyone to understand what makes a terrible movie and a terrible sequel. The cinematography actually is ok camerawork and lighting wise. The music isn't good either, its a mix of boring generic cinematic music and the actual Jaws theme with literally no change to it from the first and its barely used. The editing and pacing are horrifically bad because its filled with boring subplots about Michael and his Mother that literally contribute nothing to the plot and are not well acted. The acting slowly gets worse in this. Easily Michael is the worst character and is terrible and makes just a dumb choice to not tell his family about the shark and never gets scared. Making the Mother have a telepathic connection with the shark is one of the stupidest ideas I have ever heard of for a character in a movie ever. The special effects are terrible as the shark is constantly stiff and looks fake even more so than the other films. It's such a shame because this is such a nice location this takes place in as well. The dumb choices characters make like not going to the final confrontation without any weapons, the dumb ways characters are written, the SUPER DUMB plot, the horrifically boring middle of this that contributes nothing to the plot, the bizarre in between movie backstory of what happened to Roy Schneider, and no tension in the slightest makes this one of the worst sequels and films ever made. You know I have to say the worst part for me wasn't even the Roaring Shark or the dumb plot...it was the beyond BORING subplots in the middle of the film where Michael and his Mom have there romance subplots and family issues...It's soooo boring. I'm honestly recommending this though for anyone who wants to learn what makes a terrible sequel and a bad movie in general.

I didn't see Jaws:The Revenge until recently, after hearing so many bad things about it. And I do wish I left it alone, this has a reputation on the whole as being one of the worst sequels ever, and as far as I'm concerned that reputation is deserved. Steven Spielberg's Jaws is brilliant, not only one of his best films but also the very movie that made me afraid to go into the sea.

Jaws:The Revenge didn't have that effect on me whatsoever. In alternative to giving genuine scares and thrills, the whole film is laughable. Especially in the plot, which is really quite inept, and in the climax, which is the epitome of WTF? Jaws:The Revenge also has some embarrassingly cheesy dialogue and poor pacing. Then there's the direction, Spielberg's direction was one of the many things that made the 1975 film so good, but the direction here from Joseph Sargent is incompetent.

The production values don't fare much better. The locations are quite nice but the cinematography and lighting are altogether unexceptional. The music is also disappointing, whereas the music was what made Jaws so unnerving in terms of mood, it was way too gimmicky here. The less said about Bruce the shark the better, he is not menacing at all, instead he is one of the many laughable assets of the film. Also he is not used well at all, and there is little to no build-up or suspense whenever he appears on screen. The acting is atrocious, the only actor who tries and the only redeeming quality is Michael Caine who deserves better. Lorraine Grey is annoyingly neurotic, while I was shocked that the talented late Judith Barsi would participate in such a mess, and her talents aren't even put to good use. Don't get me started on Mario Van Peebles, him, his character and his comic lines are annoying and get old fast.

Overall, a terrible film and one of the worst sequels I've seen and I have seen a lot. 1/10 Bethany Cox

I am only giving this a two star rating with how funny it is. It's so obvious they were trying to make a good film. But the studio was in a bind from the previous year that you can read about it online. Mostly the studio and the people involved making it laughed at the idea that they were trying to beat the clock with only five or six months from being released. They weren't prepared. Shocking as that sounds, they didn't have any time to think things through. When the movie came out, it shows that they acted from the director Ed Wood, with only one or two shots and they had a produced film that wasn't even 90 minutes. Run, gun, and get it done. Everyone can complain about the shark, or how terrible the dialogue was. Reading the book of this film made it more substantial and they should've included that part from the book's perspective. They knew they were in a bind, but hopefully could make it work. When you watch the film, the majority of people knew it was bad, so they tried their best at it. Now, given that I've seen the movie multiple times, little kids will love it. Adults will chuckle at how bad it is, and it ends with a climax that's all over the place. I admit, I can tell what they were thinking of...but they shouldn't have included scenes from the first film to counteract with what they were representing in the fourth film. It's in poor taste. Yet, I found myself enjoying this movie for a lot of reasons. The opening with the deputy, the ongoing battle with the shark, and hearing Michael Caine going, "Oh sh*@!" The plot is ridiculous and Lorraine Gray is terrible (but part of this is the writing).  However, Lance Guest delivers a strong performance, and Michael Caine brings a nice levity to the film.  Also, the shark effects aren't that bad, though there's no real menace or sense of terror to him (as he's really only after the Brodys and whoever gets in the way). The only redeemable feature of this movie is that the location scout had really good taste (not just the Bahamian locations, but also the New England locations). Even the locations chosen for interior shots (e.g., the New England homes) were effective (i.e., to convey crampness in the case of the mother's home and the wall-to-wall windows of the beachfront home were an effective substitute for a porch). There's a shot that transitions from the mother's kitchen to her living room that's extremely tight. Most interior shots nowadays are shot in fairly spacious homes to accommodate large cameras, and so the geography of the scene isn't that interesting.  But the location scouting was all that's redeemable in this movie. The premise of the movie is absurd, and the pseudoscience offered in the climax was uneducated. The lead actress was experienced and so she competently conveyed the emotions required of her role -- it's just that her character was irrational and somewhat annoying.

Although some of the actors appear to be trying -- the interactions between M. Cain and L. Gary are actually rather believable -- the film falters with a nigh-uncountable level of problems. Oddly, a simple recut could make the film better. And by that, I mean, remove the awful looking shark.

- The fourth and, until this moment, last installment of the 'Jaws'-saga is this 1987 'Jaws: the Revenge', directed by Joseph Sargent (The Taking of Pelham One Two Three, McArthur) with returning cast member Lorraine Gary (Jaws 1,2) as Ellen Brody. The movie got a lot of criticism and has many plot holes, and I must agree it's my least favorite one of the series. The ending is just ridiculous. It was nominated for 7 Razzie awards (bad movies). The original theme song and some flashes of Roy Scheider from the first movie were used. Next to Gary we see the respectful Sir Michael Caine (The Dark Knight Trilogy, The Prestige)and Lance Guest (Halloween 2, The Last Starfighter). Who's in for a swim? 

Now that Martin Brody has passed away after a heart attack, his son Sean has stepped into his shoes as a police deputy. A few days before Christmas Sean has taken a boat to clear a log from a buoy, but is surprised by a great white shark that tears of his arm. The man dies, leaving his mother Ellen (Gary) devastated and convinced that the shark has targeted her family.

Ellen is invited by her other son Michael (Guest) to come and spend some time with him, his wife Carla and daughter Thea at their home in the Bahamas. She agrees. On her way, she meets airplane pilot Hoaggie (Caine) to who she develops a friendship. But what Ellen feared, seems to be real. The great white shark has followed her to the Bahamas and has only one thing in its mind: to devour the Brody family...

Oh, boy. I just had to come back and revisit this one, didn't I? I didn't like it as a little kid and I hate it even more now as an adult, even though I'm a B-movie fanatic. Now I can really see why this film sunk the franchise for good, as it is easily the worst Jaws film, period (And this is coming from someone who is a die hard fan of Jaws 2 and even salvaged Jaws 3 for camp value). Still, I wanted to give this film another chance before writing it off for good, and sadly, it still sucked. Now let me explain why.

The plot mostly focuses around Ellen Brody, the wife of Chief Brody from the first two films. After her son, Sean, is killed by a shark, Ellen becomes convinced that her family seems to be cursed and will be endlessly pursued by this new Great White until it finishes off her family for good.

Despite her new fears, she decides to go to the Bahamas with her son, Mike, and his family to get her mind off her grief and even meets a charming pilot while she's there, whom she grows close to romantically. But, her worst fears are confirmed when the shark starts to come after Mike and his family, and now Ellen must do everything in her power to take down this shark.

Honestly, even though some of the ideas are hokey, the premise of Jaws: The Revenge sounded really interesting. I also admired the fact that it tried to go back to the roots of the original film and also tried to be more dramatic. Had the story been properly written and the film had been directed properly, it could have made for a hell of a drama mixed with harrowing shark attack scenes, and peppered with just the right amount of 80's cheese to make for a damn good Jaws film to close out the franchise. It could have been a thrilling, harrowing, and terrifying film, but it sadly didn't work out.

As a drama, this film falls flat on its face thanks to a poorly written script which drowns its talented cast in a sea of cliches, flaccid emotions, and unrealistic scenarios. Worse yet, the film can't even be salvaged as trashy fun because shark attacks are few and far between, and what does happen doesn't get interesting until the final confrontation (Which results in a bizarre and unintentionally funny death. The shark not only explodes when the boat rams it, but it also causes the boat to explode into pieces). It's a bad drama and it's also a crappy shark film that can't be salvaged for camp value.

I do feel, however, that the cast did their best with the material and I really enjoyed the performances by Lorraine Gary and Michael Caine who I felt managed to deliver even in the midst of so much awfulness.

In the end, Jaws: The Revenge is a disappointing conclusion to the franchise that is filled with a lot of interesting ideas that it never utilizes. The direction is bad, the story is crap, and the shark attacks are disappointing and filled with bad special effects. It's a probably a good thing they never made another Jaws film again because it would cause too much pain to fans to have to endure another one.
