Someone should probably exact revenge on Joseph Sargent for making this, the most terrifying "Jaws" of all, but not in a good way. Where "Jaws" influenced blockbuster filmmaking, "Jaws 2" influenced inferior obligatory-feeling sequels and "Jaws 3" influenced lame 3D gimmick third installments, about the only thing that this film seemed to influence was Sci-Fi Channel original films. I broaden that statement to include all Sci-Fi Channel original films, rather than just the killer shark Sci-Fi films in particular, because just about all of the films Sci-Fi produces seem to be about bad CG sharks. Seriously though, it's a shame that the series has come all the way down to this point, but hey, at least this film makes for the worthy wrap-up to a certain aspect in the series' progression, because where we started with a 100% critical approvement of the first "Jaws", with this, the final installment, we've finally brought things down to 0%. I think that this film was doomed when it came to the concept, and by that, I don't mean that the film was doomed once it thought that it would be a good idea to have a shark understand and take advantage of the concept of revenge ("This time, it's personal"... It's a shark, tagline guy!), I mean that the film was doomed once it decided to not have the shark don a yellow jumpsuit, whip out a samurai sword and track down the man responsible for almost killing him on his wedding day. Granted, "Kill Bill" came out almost two decades after this film (Quentin Tarantino's such a nostalgiac that he makes stories that pay homage to B-movie stories that never happened), but the point is that if this film was going to go that far stupid, then I would have to give it credit just for being so gutsy. ...No, it would have been worse, because, really, sarcasm aside, this film isn't even close to as bad as people are saying it is, yet make no mistake, it's still pretty bad, and no matter how amusing this film's stupidity gets or how undeniably charming Michael Caine is (Yeah, I say, "undeniably" as though we can expect anything less from Michael "Definitive Charming Englishman" Caine), nothing can save this film, which isn't to say that there aren't "some" things in the actual final product that tried.

Okay, now, I think that we can all ever so easily agree that not one of these sequels' scores have ever come close to touching John Williams' master work for the original, and yet, unexpectedly and undeniably, well, let me struck down if I don't think that this sequel came the closest. Granted, this film's score is a bit conventional, as well as used fairly rarely, yet when it does finally kick on, I did find myself won over, as Michael Small's adjustments to Williams' original themes, while definately not an improvement, still boast plenty of lively intensity and sweep that's both neat to listen to and stays faithful to the film's, and by extenion, the series' themes. The film's action is limp, as I'll discuss further later on down the roard, yet that score work breathes a certain essence of life into such moments as the action sequences, decidedly not to where it raises the action to genuinely intense, yet still raises to a certain degree, nevertheless. Still, as I said, the score work is fairly underused, and between those moments of musical glory, we're going to need some compensation, and, of course, we don't get that compensation, though not through lack of trying... or at least I don't think so. Okay, now, Joseph Sargent clearly couldn't have had his heart too deeply in this project, neither as producer or director, or else the film would be considerably more competent, so this film doesn't quite have the inspiration that "Jaws 3" had on a few occasions, yet it does have the charming ambition that "Jaws 3". Sure, with more inspiration and less missteps, this film's ambition would have been more charming, and therefore more capable of saving this project, yet I can't help but admit that I felt some degree of appreciation towards Sargent's intentions, no matter how tremendously unrealized they ended up being, and it certainly helped that, well, this film isn't nearly as bad as everyone and his or her grandmother is saying, for although the film is a disaster, I was going in expecting a towering testament to ineptitude and ended up finding not much more than your usual run-of-the-mill '80s mess, hardly worthy of evoking something like "The Garbage Pail Kids Movie", or "Troll 2", or "Battlefield Earth", or other films that seem more worthy of being placed among the worst ever messily crafted. Still, make no mistake, this film is still a mess and a disaster, surprisingly coming close to passable, though not close enough, as it find itself pulled down more than just a few fatal flaws.

"Jaws 3" presented CG that was truly abysmal, as well as a few practical effects that weren't quite as convincing as they probably should have been, yet what I didn't mention is that there were still quite a few production designs in "Jaws 3" that really were pretty decent, and certainly much more worthy of my appreciation after this film, for although CG has been removed and a few production designs are left standing as reasonably passable, on the whole, most of this film's practical effects fell flat, and when they seriously shouldn't, for although the more passable practical effects and, of course, Michael Small's score raise tension to a moderate degree, the laughable effects really do launch you out of this film and, certainly, the film's sense of conseqeunce. Still, it's not like you're ever truly invested in the story, because this really is a pretty bad screenplay, or at least the story that the script structures is. Many of this film's story concepts are pretty poor, and made all the worse in execution, as Michael de Guzman's screenplay goes riddled with cliches, uninteresting filler, holes, poor characterization, unbuyable character actions, unbuyable story actions and, of course, bad dialogue. Okay, maybe Guzman's screenplay isn't immensely inept, yet it does collapse into utter and sometimes glaring incompetence at every turn, and it's made all the worse by, well, "a few" poor acting jobs, for although there a couple of passable performances (Hey man, you've got to love Michael Caine, even if he is playing Michael Caine once again, just the way we like it; also, I must admit that I was digging the also immensely charming Mario Van Peebles), there are still quite a few performances that fall flat as bland, at best, which is a complaint to be had about "Jaws 3", yet there are a few more performances in this film that are just all-out bad, or if nothing else, obnoxious (Ah, that stupid little girl!). Still, at the end of the day, the performance that taints these waters the most is the key one off of the screen, for although I can appreciate Joseph Sargent's ambitions, seriously, come on man, you have to do something to fulfill ambitions, rather than contradict them. Outside of providing mild charm through ambition, Sargent's direction does very little, if anything to carry this film past its flaws, or even spark the film in the first place, for although it was blandness that made "Jaws 3" so mediocre, yet also saved it from collapsing any lower, here, we're presented with more blandness that really does bear down on the film, rendering it disengaging, though not so disengaging that you don't still notice the many, many flaws that bypass the potential for mere mediocrity amidst the blandness and leaves the film to collapse as both laughable and dull, and grow more so in progression. The film starts out, not necessarily strong, but fair, then proceeds to progressively decline in quality quite considerably as its blandness grows more and more intense and its flaws grow more and more pronounced, until by the end, I found my time wasted and a film in disastrous ruins, for although this film isn't nearly as incompetent as I'm making it sound, and certainly not nearly as incompetent as everyone else is making it sound, it is nevertheless still consistently incompetent, and through all of Sargent's charming ambitions and Michael Small's actually pretty good score work, it's the incompetence that ultimately prevails, thus leaving this film, and by extension, the film franchise that started out strongly to finally sink.

In the end, the occasional fine score piece livens things up, while Joseph Sargent's palpable ambitions spark a certain undeniable charm within this film that makes it difficult for me to dislike the film, which isn't to say the flaws helped in my dismissal of the final product, for although the film isn't nearly as inept as many are saying, it remains incompetent, with shoddy technical value landing a blow to consequence, while a poor story ultimately slays the compellingness, and does so with the help of a poor screenplay, executed generally blandly and occasionally a smidge poorly by the cast, as well as Joseph Sargent's direction, which offers plenty of blandness and not enough compensation, thus leaving dullness to set in and help in ultimately making "Jaws: The Revenge" a sloppy and unworthy major misstep that may be considerably better than it's said to be, but is still pretty bad.

I just saw the end of JAWS: THE REVENGE on latenight cable TV--where it belongs--and I'm still stunned by the incredible lameness of every aspect of this movie. For everyone who quibbles about the unlikelihood of finding a Great White in the warm waters of the Bahamas: this shark also roars. Like a lion or something. A roaring shark. You read that right.

The filmmakers also keep cutting shots from the original JAWS into the climax. As a reminder that there was actually a good film at one time here? A distraction from how horrible this one is?

They paid Michael Caine enough to be in this stink bomb--but obviously not enough to wear a wet shirt after climbing out of the ocean. His expressions often convey that he's there but you're lucky he's at least facing the camera.

Was there something better he could have been doing? Yes. Picking up his first Oscar for HANNAH AND HER SISTERS. But he missed the Oscars to be in JAWS: THE REVENGE. At least he went on national TV to admit that he did this movie because he had a home right there in the Bahamas (he even pointed at the house during the interview).

The demise of the roaring shark is a baffling, badly-edited violation of all of our natural laws and logic. Shark rises out of the water. Boat rams shark. Shark explodes. Boat explodes. Everyone survives, even the annoying Jamaican who got chewed up several minutes before. Roll footage clearly the same of the blown-up shark sinking from the original.

I can't seem to make myself give this movie a 00%, but I will say, while the movie itself sucked hardcore ass, I still think it isn't one of the worst movies I have ever seen.

Now, this movie sucked, yes, & undeniably one of the worst movies ever made, but it's not the worst I've seen, & believe it or not, I was actually able to sit through it without any problems & I can actually watch it again, & again without getting pissed off at it (not that I would watch it again). The major problem with this movie other than the fake-looking "Bruce" (the shark), is how BORING it is! Now, I have yet to see the other two, mainly because every time I watched any of the Jaws sequels, I never got passed the first 10 minutes of them.

Plot/Story: The story is cheesy, the plot is just referencing the first film & also seems to be pasting other stuff from other movies, & there are so many plot holes. And as the others have said, the plot is about the shark stalking & murdering the Brody family. Yes, the shark actually stalks the family that has killed it in the previous movies. But that's the least of this movie's problems.

The plot & story is also both illogical & makes little sense. Now, the one illogical thing this movie has is how the shark traveled from New York, all the way to the Bahamas. That's almost what...2000 km? The shark not only would have never made at the same time as the characters did, but it would have never even have had to make it in the first place, because, great whites don't like warm water! Now, I know some of you may know me for the fact that I'll take realism in a film, rub it in my ass cheeks & then toss it aside, but this film tries to portray a man-eating shark in a realistically fictional way, which doesn't work so well.

Then there's the problem with Ellen. But that part I'll save for later, so don't forget it. And then there's the part where the shark follows Michael through an entire sunken ship labyrinth. A great white shark is too damn stupid to do such a thing. But that won't get in the shark's brain because apparently this shark now grew a brain that of a human intelligence! It THINKS of what to do next if it doesn't seem to get to it's victim!

Cast/Acting: Lorraine Gray came back to reprise her role as the wife of Martin Brody, & then we have Michael Caine, the supporting actor. But everyone else in this movie is forgettable. And the acting is extremely questionable. There are points where the actors play their parts right, but then they are in another scene where they seem to be acting like they've been doing some drugs.

Characters: Remember when I said above to not forget about the problem with Ellen Brody? Well here it is now. Ellen now became the more heroic character of the movie, but that's not her problem, the problem she has is how she is always paranoid, & worse of all, she is haunted by flashbacks of events that she was never present in! Such as the scene where her husband shot the shark dead in the first movie & where her son was murdered in the beginning of the movie. Her character is also boring, not doing much but freaking out & pretending to be fine. I don't even wanna get to the other pointless characters.

Music/Score: The score is just fine, almost as great as the first one's score, but the problem with it was that it sometimes got a little too dramatic & loud.

Special effects: They sucked, ass. The shark looked way too fake, especially compared to how it was used in the first movie. And don't get me started on the scenes where the shark began to 'rise' out of the water. And the scene where the shark was finally killed, for that one frame of that second of the movie, you can see the cheap, primitive tool used. Don't even get me started on the idiotic scenes of how the shark began to roar. Yes, the damn shark roars like a lion or some other beast, which is completely illogical.

Chemistry: I felt lots of chemistry between Lorraine Gary & Michael Caine, that's pretty much it.

Dialogue: The dialogue in this movie is so poorly written & executed that I seriously wondered if the actors themselves questioned if they were supposed to be saying what they read in their scripts. It's just bad, plain out bad.

Final summation, this movie sucks, is boring, & one of the worst movies ever made, but not that I've seen. It was an unnecessary sequel.

If there ever were proof of the law of diminishing returns, the fourth entry in the Jaws series is it. The original was a taut thriller that launched the career of one of Hollywood's most celebrated directors. By comparison, Michael Caine often looks as if he is incredibly upset to be missing his award ceremony in order to appear in this piece. Lance Guest and Mario Van Peebles frequently appear to be wishing to have better things to do, while Lorraine Gary frequently looks stoned in moments when she is supposed to look frightening.

Clearly, the budget spent on this film didn't go into the research, script, or mechanical shark. Exactly why Michael Brody and his pals are putting what are apparently tracking devices on conch shells is never explained. Perhaps any explanation they thought of was so incredibly stupid that they thought it best to give up. An alternate explanation of why Michael is working in the water was never thought of, either. The true Ed Wood moment of the film comes towards the end of the piece, when the shark rises out of the water, and roars at Elaine. This is the first time I've heard of sharks having vocal cords. Given the box office draw this stinker had, I suspect it will be the last.

The shark takes a real beating here, too. The reason the shark wasn't seen often in the original was because Spielberg noticed that if one put it in front of the camera for long enough, the audience would notice that it doesn't move like a real shark. In this edition of the Jaws story, not only do they keep the camera focused upon the shark for more than enough time for the audience to notice the model's flaws, in so doing they make it crystal clear that this shark was made on the cheap. There are some shots in which the support structure of the shark is visible under the outer layer. There is even what appears to be a seam in the back of the shark's main fin.

To its credit, Jaws: The Revenge is well-photographed. While the 2.35:1 frame is often sparsely populated, depth of field is used with great effect in several shots. The fact that even frames with one character in them won't make sense when cropped to fit analogue television is a credit to the director and cinematographer. If only this kind of workmanship could have been seen in other aspects of the film.

Another area where Jaws: The Revenge deserves due credit is the score music. While the score is very much inspired by that which John Williams provided for the original, it distinguishes itself and genuinely works in its own right. In fact, one could almost say that the score music is more than the rest of the film deserves. The music is literally able to inject dramatic tension into scenes that, by all rights granted under the accepted rules of film-making, really shouldn't have any.

When all is said and done, I gave Jaws: The Revenge a one out of ten. It works as a comedy in the sense that it is a stinking pile of crap, but there are precious few moments when the people making it seem privy to the fact. As a result, the film winds up in a class all of its own. It's not just so bad its good, it is so utterly bad it is incredible.

Ellen Brody flees to the Bahamas when she fears a great white shark is stalking her, only to find it pops up in the Caribbean, too. Michael Caine provides the bumbling love interest as Hoagie.

Lorraine Gary, who was Chief Brody's wife in the first two films, is in reality married to the head of Universal Pictures. Here, she finally gets her star billing in a soggy sequel that refuses to be called Jaws 4 because it avoids all reference to Jaws 3 and tells an alternative story about different versions of Roy Scheider's grown-up children's brush with a vindictive killer fish. Michael Caine, trying to win back his reputation for appearing only in complete rubbish after accidentally being in the rather good Hannah And Her Sisters, is a dissolute pilot who takes a shine to the widowed Gary (yep, Scheider finally broke that contract, and appears only in borrowed footage for flashbacks), and accompanies her from Amity Island to the Bahamas when a shark kills one of her sons.

The shark follow the family and keeps up the vendetta. After the initial chomping, the film turns annoyingly bloodless as it spares all the major characters from death in a soppy, clearly much-rewritten ending that makes no sense.

Significantly worse than the rest of the series, the film is one of the worst bell-flops in recent cinema.

OMG.   I had never seen this last, sad, unintentionally hilarious coda to the Jaws films until today.   It's clearly supposed to be taken seriously, but the premise is incredibly laughable.  Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary), widow of Amity Island shark killing Sheriff Martin Brody (Roy Scheider, who is notably absent save scenes culled from the original; if the actor saw this script, he certainly was wise to pass on it!), thinks that the shark is out to get her and her family.  After yet another incident at Amity, the same shark apparently goes so far as to pursue her to her son Michael's Bahama island home.  Is that enough for you?  It's just getting started.  Forget that Brody blew up the previous sharks in the first two films - and it's not entirely clear, if it matters at at all, if anyone remembers the third movie - but, apparently, someone's out for revenge.  While it might seem like it should be Ellen Brody out for blood, it appears that this movie is really about the shark taking revenge.  Maybe it's P.O.'d for how the Brodys have treated its relatives?   There are so many absurd elements present - and Michael Caine does his best to play it straight - I watched it from beginning to end with a smile and laughed out loud at times.   If I was grading this as a comedy, it would probably be a three star one.   So I wonder when someone is going to reimagine this series?  Please don't.  Watch the original.  If you need more, see the first so-so sequel with Scheider.

rt_summary: The family of widow Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) has long been plagued by shark attacks, and this unfortunate association continues when her son is the victim of a massive great white. In mourning, Ellen goes to visit her other son, Michael (Lance Guest), in the Bahamas, where she meets the charming Hoagie Newcombe (Michael Caine). As Ellen and Hoagie begin a relationship, a huge shark appears off the coast of the island, and Ellen's trouble with the great whites begins again.
